column2: Walerian Borowczyk's "Immoral Tales," the fourpart French film that opened yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater, is a nice old-fashioned erotic film.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 10 (AP) A Laotian officer has flown a light observation aircraft into Thailand in the second airborne escape from Communist Indochina in two days, the Thai Interior Ministry said today.
John Michael Kelly, an American national decathlon champion in 1913, died Tuesday in Leominster, Mass. His age was 90.
HONOLULU, March 10 Hawaii Democrats may not know for three more weeks whether their 17-member delegation to the national convention will go uncommitted or be split.

A top official of Jimmy Carter's New York campaign charged yesterday that supporters of Senator Henry M. Jackson were trying to deny New York Democrats a "free and open" Presidential primary by forcing Carter delegates off the ballot in many of the state's Congressional districts.

The Gold Seal Company of Bismarck, N.D., whose Snowy powder bleach lost its dominant dry bleach market position to Clorox 2, is starting a highly competitive, comparative advertising campaign on Monday.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Democratic majority of the Congressional Joint Economic Committee assailed President Ford's economic policy today and called for a larger budget deficit to spur the economy more rapidly toward full employment.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Legislation to keep the Federal Election Commission functioning as the watchdog and a provider of funds for the 1976 elections cleared a major hurdle today as the House Administration Committee gave final approval to a bill over strong Republican objections.

It was Felix J. Rohatyn's turn to tell "Why I Love New York" at the New School Tuesday night. "I'm rather sentimental about New York because it took me in," said the Vienna-born investment banker. "New York was the United States. New York was Franklin Roosevelt. It's been good to me. It's an intellectually exciting place to be."
Henry H. Nordlinger, a retired lawyer, died yesterday at his home at 115 Central Park West. He was 82 years old.

SEOUL, South Korea, March 10 The opposition party's most recent presidential candidate and 10 other critics of South Korea's leadership have been arrested and charged with agitating to overthrow the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

L. E. Sissman, a poet who made successful careers in literature and advertising, died yesterday at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. He was 48 years old and had suffered since 1965 from Hodg kin's disease.

NAIROBI, Kenya, March 9 Mozambique has been the most vocal African opponent of white minority governments in the southern part of the continent, but until it closed its border with Rhodesia last week it did business with the Rhodesians.

The man was sitting with three friends in the crowded back room of Jimmy Weston's, an East Side supper club, his two bodyguards a discreet distance away. A woman, one-quarter of two couples two tables away, rose and walked over to the man and touched him on the shoulder.
Now that Andy Messersmith finally knows when he'll be a free agent next Tuesday does anyone know what effect, if any, the latest Andy Messersmith decision might have on the baseball dispute?

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 Large numbers of Lebanese Moslem soldiers were in open revolt against their commanders today. The head of the army proclaimed a general amnesty for deserters and urged them to return to their units.

Following are the final vote totals in Tuesday's Presidential preference primary in Florida, the number of convention delegates awarded as a result of that primary and the total number of delegate preference votes so far:

MIAMI, March 10 Despite Jimmy Carter's impressive victory in Florida yesterday, his strategists concluded today that the former Georgia Governor would be unable to mount a major campaign in the primaries on April 6 in New York and Wisconsin.

Time is running out for George C. Wallace. The voting in Florida's Democratic primary suggests that the Alabama Governor, who first started running for President in 1964, is beginning to wear out his welcome even among those voters most favorably disposed to his familiar message. He polled only 392,000 votes, less than one-third of the total, as against 526,000 votes he attracted in the same primary four years ago.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) The director of the National Cancer Institute told the Food and Drug Administration today that it was impossible to say for sure whether the artificial sweetener cyclamate was capable of causing human cancer.

Gov. Ella T. Grasso of Connecticut and legislative leaders rode into town yesterday on a Greyhound bus and made a brief foray into the Wall Street area in search of buyers and low interest rates for $100 million of her state's bonds.
HONG KONG, March 10-The continuing campaign in China against those who are said to insist on following a "capitalist road" received formal endorsement today by the Chinese Communist Party.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 (AP) After hearing months of testimony and receiving instructions on 74 possible verdicts, jurors began deliberating today in the year-old trial of four black men accused in the random "Zebra" killings of whites.
Lead prices took a turn upward yesterday after several months of softness with the announcement of price advances by several major producers.
Margot Kelly, an actress, died yesterday in Summit, N.J., at the home of her daughter. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LONDON, March 10 (UPI) Lord Camoys died yesterday, two months after moving from Stonor Park in Oxfordshire, the family home for 900 years. He was 62 years old.

On the Republican side, the returns from Florida indicate that Ronald Reagan has achieved what seemed unattainable at the beginning of the year. He has forced President Ford to become a competent national candidate.

LOS ANGELES, March 10-William Wyler, the film director, whose work spans almost 50 years and ranged from silent westerns to "Mrs. Miniver," "The Best Years of Our Lives," "Ben-Hur" and "Funny Girl," received last night the fourth Life Achievement Award of the American Film Institute.

Hofstra was never mentioned last December as a team with a chance to reach the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament that starts Saturday. The Flying Dutchmen were forgotten because of four straight losing seasons, obvious disciplinary problems and a lack of interest in the team among students at the university in Hempstead, L. I.

As an esteemed avantgarde moviemaker and teacher (Harpur College), Ken Jacobs illustrates independence and a provocative personal style in the four films ranging from deceptively simple home movies to 3-D that opened at the Whitney Museum yesterday. That this is an uneven, occasionally self-indulgent program, does not essentially detract from the overall professionalism evident in the largely affectionate treatment of most of his subjects.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Every Tuesday is another election day, which is a warning to pundits not to interpret Florida's primary vote as the certain springtime of Jimmy Carter or the unbreakable fall of Ronald Reagan.

New York City's decline is not inevitable. Properly managed, retrenchment can lead to redevelopment rather than ruin. By the early 1980's, the city's economy should begin to recover provided the city government soon undergoes a revolution whereby its policy and management processes finally are placed in a compatible rather than incompatible relationship with the larger economic forces shaping the city's future.
Pat Day has worked oil rigs ridden broncos and bulls in the rodeo, managed a gas station and has been a cowboy. But when the 22-yearold jockey ended a honey

WASHINGTON, March 10 Administration officials refused to take sides publicly today between Prime Minister Rabin and President Sadat over whether the United States had picdged to Egypt that Israel would not attack Syria.

Is it the sneaky, underhanded, diabolical quality implicit in a trap that blinds us to the opponent's resources in extricating himself? Perhaps, delighted with our own cleverness, we exaggerate and suppose we enjoy a monopoly of it.

Every month or is it week? seems to bring a new rock band from Britain, eager to catch a few leftover crumbs from the Anglophilia of the 1960's. Most fail completely; others latch onto an FM cult success; a very few, unpredictably, make it big Elton John (if he can be counted a British act anymore), Led Zeppelin, Bad Company.

It is going to take a good deal longer than expected to determine how much reinforcement is needed on DC-10 jet engines to avoid catastrophic damage if birds are ingested on takeoff runs, the engine builder, General Electric, reported yesterday.
Yale University's women crew members who disrobed in their athletic director's office last week to protest a lack of showers where they practice in Derby Conn., are to get a private locker room.
WASHINGTON In the neo-Orwellian world of Presidential primaries, all losers, it would appear, are winners.

MINEOLA, L.I, March 10 The Nassau County District Attorney today identified William Smith, former Comptroller of the Town of Hempstead, as one of five present or former town officials indicted on charges of soliciting money for the Republican County Committee.
The financially troubled Singer Company confirmed yesterday that it planned to begin doing its own advertising for the United States Sewing Products division.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) President Ford will send a private letter to Japan in the next few days in which he is expected to promise that Japanese authorities will be granted conditional access to United States information about Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payoffs, United States officials said today.
The Levittown School Board adopted a controversial plan last night to furlough its 1,200 employees, including 725 teachers, for five days without pay to help cut the Nassau district's budget deficit.
A heavy volume of corporate bonds was marketed yesterday and investors bought most of the new securities even though they were offered at yields that were often slightly lower than ...

WHITESBURG, Ky., March 10-Less than 24 hours before a methane gas explosion ripped through a section of the Scotia Coal Company mine yesterday, killing 15 miners, a Federal mine inspector issued three safety violation notices in the section.

The director general of the International Air Transport Association, Knut Hammarskjold, yesterday urged that the governments of the world meet to review "the whole concept" of economy charter air flights.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The House Armed Services Committee recommended today that the Administration's defense budget be increased by about $2 billion, primarily to finance an expanded naval shipbuilding program.
An Austrian industrialist who is the sole nominee to be the next president of Rotary International was accused yesterday of having been a Nazi party member and a storm trooper during World War II.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., March 10 Jury selection began here today in the trial of Steven Soliah, companion of Patricia Hearst for a time while she was a fugitive. He is accused of taking part in a $15,000 bank robbery in the Sacramento suburb of Carmichael last April.

ROME, March 10 William Simon, the Secretary of the Treasury, today prescribed austerity as a remedy for Italy's economic problems and said that the failure to solve these problems would help bring the Communists into power here.

The man was sitting with three friends in the crowded back room of Jimmy Weston's, an East Side supper club, his two bodyguards a discreet distance away. A woman, one-quarter of two couples two tables away, rose and walked over to the man and touched him on the shoulder.
Wheat futures dropped slightly yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, despite a Government report late Tuesday that exports would not be off as much as many traders had expected.

Four years after inspectors found a wide range of serious violations at Wadsworth Hospital, a 50-bed private institution in Washington Heights, the Fedderal Government has moved to withhold the Government funds that are the institution's major source of support.

The first major bridge charity effort of the Bicentennial year will be played across the continent next Wednesday. The focus of the event will be the Spring Nationals In Kansas City, Mo., but there will be games at more than 500 other centers, with most of the proceeds going to the Arthritis Foundation.
Dr. Paul Gyorgy, nutritionist and pediatrician, died March 1 at Morristown (N. J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Villanova, Pa.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Ford Administration agreed today to study a proposal by three Senate supporters of Israel that would avoid a major fight in Congress over opening a new military relationship with Egypt but that would allow the limited sale of six C-130 military transports to Cairo.
ROME, Ga., March 10 (AP) Esther Watson Tipple, daughter of Tom Watson, co-inventor of the telephone, died today in a nursing home on the 100th anniversary of the invention. She was 86 years old.

MIAMI Jimmy Carter's campaign in this part of Florida was handled by two young men who got into politics here as opponents of the Vietnam war and supporters of George McGovern. Michael Abrams, 28, and Sergio Bendixen, 26, stayed active in the Democratic Party after 1972. Abrams was elected Dade County chairman, Bendixen, a national committeeman.

A three-judge Federal court yesterday reaffirmed and broadened a decision it handed down in 1972 that barred New York State from withholding Medicaid reimbursement for voluntary abortions. As a result, patients may now apply for such reimbursement for the first time.

"Farewell to Manzanar," a "world premiere movie" on NBC-TV at 9 this evening, deals with the true story of the internment of West Coast Japanese-Americans during World War II. The script is based on a book by Jeanne Wakatsuki Houston and her husband, James D. Houston. Both writers collaborated on the script with John Korty, the film's direc

Traffic executives of more than 20 big railroads operating west of the Mississippi at a meeting in Chicago yesterday agreed to raise their freight rates on 30 days' notice by up to 7 percent in the so-called northeastern part of the territory they serve.

who in 1890 was, in the words of a local journal, "disgracefully raped by a vagabond." According to Mr. Borowczyk, the maiden in question had earlier been even more successfully abused by her own imagination fired by her readings from "The Stations of the Cross."
ALBANY, March 10 Governor Carey insisted today that he could not possibly accept the upward revisions in state tax revenue estimates proposed by the Legislature to soften some of his budget cuts.

NEWARK, March 10-State Transportation officials have ordered a study of the impact on inner-city residents of the strike that began Tuesday by the Amalgamated Transit Union against the Transport of New Jersey bus company, Alan Sagner, State Transporta tion Commissioner, disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Richard M. Nixon said in sworn testimony made public today that he ordered a program of telephone wiretaps in 1969 to locate news leaks, but that it was Henry A. Kissinger, then his national security adviser, who suppiled the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the names of the original targets of the program.
A fire flared briefly on the eighth floor of a 60-story skyscraper in the Wall Street area yesterday afternoon, spreading smoke through the building.

In his 1558 edition of what was to be the earliest collection of women's biographies, Giovanni Boccaccio proclaimed that "if men should be praised whenever they perform great deeds . . . how much more should women be extolled." With this sentiment in mind, the Barnard College Library and Women's Center opened yesterday an exhibition of rare book, and manuscripts entitled "Five Centuries of Feminism."

TOMS RIVER, March 10 David J. Bardin, the state's Environmental Protection Commissioner, said today that the Federal Government had failed to implement its policy requiring land-use safeguards around nuclear plants and that the state should step in and do so.

HONG KONG, March 6 Analysts in Hong Kong apparently have not been the only people bewildered by the new campaign in China against so-called rightists. To judge from some reports in the Chinese media, and accounts of travelers from China, the Chinese people themselves are uncertain and wary about the attacks on Teng Hsiao-ping, the senior Deputy Prime Minister, and other "unrepentant capitalist roaders within the party."

PRINCTON, N.J., March 10 The New Jersey Board of Medical Examiners, which licenses physicians, deferred action today in the case of Dr. X, the surgeon now under investigation in connection with the death of nine or more patients at Riverdell Hospital a decade ago.

After a long neglect that has proved to be the opposite of benign, New York City's problem economy finally is getting the broad public attention it deserves. Hardly a week goes by without the promulgation of some new stra tegy to reverse the economic decline of the city, a decline that is measured by the oft-cited, but still shocking, loss of more than 500,000 jobs since 1969.

ARCADIA, Calif., Mach 10 (AP) Bill Shoemaker won a race today at Santa Anita, which left him at 6,999 in the bid for 7,000 career victories aboard thoroughbreds. He rode Raise Your Skirts to a third-place finish in the $43,350 Santa Gertrudes Handicap and he finished second aboard Ascari in the finale.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Moving with unusual haste to correct what many representa tives regarded as an international faux pas, the House Rules Committee revived today a bill to send a 25-member Congressional delegation to London to bring back one of the original copies of Magna Carta for display during the Bicentennial celebration.

Albert Silver helped a lot of people with legal work. He tried cases in local courts, right on through to the State Court of Appeals. He served as City Attorney of Glen Cove, L.I., and according to the Mayor, he was superb at the job.

WASHINGTON, March 10 The Ford Administration agreed today to study a proposal by three Senate supporters of Israel that would avoid a major fight in Congress over opening a new military relationship with Egypt but that would allow the limited sale of six C-130 military transports to Cairo.

The National Broadcasting Company and the Mobil Oil Corporation are engaged in a lively public dispute over whether Mobil should be allowed to buy air time on NBC to rebut the five-part series on gasoline prices shown here last month.
It was Felix J. Rohatyn's turn to tell "Why I Love New York" at the New School Tuesday night.
A six-pack of English lager was redeemed from Customs yesterday and will be shipped empty to a 14year-old collector of beer cans in Kenosha, Wis., thanks to the Beame administration.

TRENTON, March 10 A statewide personal income tax took a faltering step closer to a vote in the Legislature tonight when the Assembly Taxation Committee approved a bill designed to raise $900 million to pay for property-tax relief and provide money to finance the Education Act of 1975.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 10 (UPI) Two hostages being held by a young gunman demanding $390,000 and a plane to fly him to Cuba jumped their captor, grabbed his gun and shot him today. The police identified the gunman as Rudi Manz, 24 years old, and said he was injured in the clash in a Frankfurt courthouse.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Bert A. Gallegos has been ousted by President Ford as director of the Community Service Administration, the much investigated surviving unit of the antipoverty programs of the 1960's, administrative and Congressional sources said today.

Jimmy Carter's plurality in the Florida primary Tuesday was a reflection of the more moderate brand of politics emerging in the "new South" and of the massive influx of newcomers that is changing the social and economic complexion of the state, analyses of The New York Times/CBS News primary poll and of ac-, tual voting patterns indicate.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Labor Government was defeated by 28 votes tonight in the House of Commons on its controversial plan for a $6 billion cut in public services.
Robert C. Baker, a Washington banker, died yesterday while vacationing in Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 73 years old and a resident of Washington.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 10 (UPI) The University of Minnesota said today that it would accept without appeal a three-year probation imposed on the school's basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
WASHINGTON, March 10 The Administration is counting on William J. Usery, the new Secretary of Labor, to use his skills as a mediator in a halfdozen critical labor-manage-, ment negotiations.

Jimmy Carter's plurality in the Florida primary Tuesday was a reflection of the more moderate brand of politics emerging in the "new South" and of the massive influx of newcomers that is changing the social and economic complexion of the state, analyses of The New York Times/CBS News primary poll and of actual voting patterns indicate.

Justice Burton B. Roberts dismissed a criminal indictment in State Supreme Court yesterday against three major oil companies that had been charged with violating the state's antitrust law in anticipation of the oil crisis of 1973-74.
An Austrian industrialist who is the sole nominee to be the next president of Rotary International was accused yesterday of having been a Nazi party member and a storm trooper during World War II.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) Senator Frank Church said today his Subcommittee on Multinational Corporations has been unable to prove that the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation tried to bribe West German officials in the early 1960's to influence the sale of F104 Starfighters.

TRENTON, March 10 Representatives of the British and French governments buttonholed startled legislators today in the halls of the State House and on the Assembly floor for support of flights to the United States by the Concorde supersonic jet transport.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10 A Belgrade lawyer was sentenced today to one year in prison for having given a courtroom speech in which he agreed with the views of a political dissident he was defending.
ASSEN, the Netherlands, March 10 Seven youths who captured a Dutch train and killed three passengers last December went on trial for murder today in this northern Dutch town under tight security.
Dr. Sidney E. Rolfe, an internationally known economist and author of several books on the world monetary system, died yesterday of cancer at his home in East Hampton, L. I. He was 54 years old.
Optimistic appraisals of the economic outlook helped send prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market higher yesterday in slower trading.

There was a fashion bash at Saks Fifth Avenue the other night, and it was called "Couples" not after the unhappy, bickering couples of John Updike's 1968 novel, but in celebration of some of the so-called "fun couples" of Manhattan, who served as models for the event.

MONTCLAIR While the town's commissioners grapple with a plan to create a $90,000 shopping plaza described by its proponents as a major step toward stemming decay in the downtown business area, the residents of this Essex County community are similarly uncertain about the ramifications.
LONDON, March 10 (AP) The British pound dropped to a new low today under heavy pressure from selling when New York orders hit the market late in the afternoon.

ALBANY, March 10 A bill that would scrap the current legal distinctions between husband and wife in divorce actions and mandate an "equitable division" of the assets of a marriage was introduced in the Legislature today with broad bipartisan support.

TORONTO, March 10 (UPI)-The St. Louis captain Garry Unger, playing in his 631st consecutive game, became the National Hockey League's leading iron man as his Blues battled to a 2-2 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight.

Israeli Asserts in Parliament Freedom of Action Against Syria Is Not Restricted TEL AVIV, March 10 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin, pressed in Parliament over what he had promised Egypt through Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, denied today that he had given any secret commitment restricting Israel's freedom of military action against Syria.

Albert Silver helped a lot of people with legal work. He tried cases in local courts, right on through to the State Court of Appeals. He served as City Attorney of Glen Cove, L.I., and according to the Mayor, he was superb at the job.
TEL AVIV, March 10 (AP)-Israeli troops fired into the air today to disperse stonethrowing Arab rioters on the West Bank of the Jordan River, a military spokesman said.
MADRID, March 10 A military court today sentenced nine Spanish officers to prison terms ranging from two and a half to eight years on charges of having conspired to rebel.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 John Elliot Cook, the 77year-old attorney who is a key figure in Joe Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League because he is the one whose advice Kapp followed, took the stand today in United States District Court. Under direct examination, Cook explained why he told Kapp not to sign the standard players' contract with the Boston Patriots.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Former President Richard M. Nixon has renewed his contention that the public disclosure almost seven years ago of the secret United States bombing of Cambodia forced him to stop the bombing at the cost of countless American lives.
The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter 1975 net income rose by 21 percent but profits for the full year declined 11.7 percent from 1974.

Some old familiar faces stand between Power, Memorial and the basketball championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association. Power defeated Rice, 67-66, last night in a semifinal game at St. John's University in Queens, following Tolentine's 65-64 victory over Loughlin, the defending champion. Power and Tolentine have split two decisions this season.
Shares of U. S. Industries Inc. have been trading heavily this week as investors ponder a possible turnaround for the billion-dollar conglomerate.

TEHERAN, Iran, March 10 Iran's ambitious goals for expansion of its steel industry are likely to fall far short because of lagging oil revenues, manpower shortages and other economic factors, well-placed business informants say here.
LONDON, March 10 (Reuters) The British Government today announced its acquisition of an additional important share in the oilfields being developed beneath the North Sea.

The Durst Organization, owner of the Luxor Baths, yesterday withdrew its eviction action against the occupants of the nine-story building at 121 West 46th Street, who hav allegedly been converting the building into one of the most lavish massage and prostitution establishments in the country

JOLIET, Ill., March 10 Insisting that he will not succumb to pressure to withdraw from the race for the Presidency, Ronald Reagan said today that President Ford could not take pleasure in the outcome of yesterday's Florida primary.

Medicaid cutbacks proposed by Governor Carey would force 49,300 employees out of their jobs in the next two years and could precipitate a devastating hospital strike this summer, hospital officials warned yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 The bloody 10-month confrontation of Moslems and Christians in Lebanon has sent ripples of tension into other corners of the Arab world, where adherents of Islam and Christianity have lived in harmony.
An unusual cluster of cases of a rare liver cancer among residents of Wisconsin has suggested that farmers exposed to arsenic-based insecticides may be at risk of developing this cancer.

BANGKOK, Thailand, March 10 (AP) On March 20 Cambodians will elect a 250member People's Assembly of farmers, workers and soldiers that will be the lawmaking body of the country, Radio Phnom Penh said today.
The Inland Steel Company became yesterday the first major steel company since 1951 to propose a public offering of common stock.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., March 10 Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama said today that a "phony health issue" had been instrumental in his secondplace finish in yesterday's Florida primary, and he began considering a new strategy to persuade voters that he was in good physical condition.

Why does my young child have to take a test given by a stranger to get into school? How can it possibly measure his capabilities? How can I prepare him (or her) for it? What if he takes it on a day he's not feeling well? How can the school judge a child on the basis of a test anyway?

SEOUL, South Korea, March 10 The opposition party's most recent presidential candidate and 10 other critics of South Korea's leadership have been arrested and charged with agitating to overthrow the Government of President Park Chung Hee.

Five days a week, David C. Merriam presides over a San Bernardino County Municipal Court in Ontario, Calif., where he is a judge. On weekends, he presides over rings in various parts of the country as a judge of dogs. On Saturday he will be seen at Harrisburg, Pa., ruling on a dozen terrier breeds.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10 The troubled labor front in baseball shifted today to Florida, where the spring training camps stayed empty for the 10th straight day. But the exiled players, riding a winning streak in the Federal courts, suggested that the club owners had played out their legal options and would soon have to come to terms.
The Dow Jones industrial average tiptoed briefly into the terrain above 1,000 yesterday, but it soon retreated in a performance that resembled Tuesday's market.

It was good that Joseph Kalichstein ended his recital Tuesday night at the 92d Street Young Men's-Young Women's Hebrew Association with a Chopin group, because in so doing he redeemed some but not all of the problems that had plagued his playing earlier in the evening.
Fourth-quarter net income of 1,727 companies increased 3 percent to $13.8 billion from the third quarter last year and 6 percent from the final quarter of 1974.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 10 Large numbers of Lebanese Moslem soldiers were in open revolt against their commanders today. The head of the army proclaimed a general amnesty for deserters and urged them to return to their units.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Following are excerpts from the first public testimony by former President Richard M. Nixon on the use of national security wiretaps during his Administration. The former President gave the deposition in San Clemente, Calif., in January in connection with a civil action now before the Federal Court here.

Richard E. Bell, Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, said yesterday that the Soviet Union probably would buy more corn soon from last year's record United States crop and would "place orders later for some wheat from the new harvest which will begin in June."

The overall intent of the Celebration of Contemporary Music, a nine-day festival currently making the Juilliard School ring with new and newish sounds, is to impress upon us the international stature of American works by placing them side by side with pieces from other countries. A plausible bit of reasoning, though such cosmopolitan programs are not unknown in New York, or elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Justice Department and other knowledgeable Government officials disputed today an assertion by former President Richard M. Nixon that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had wiretapped an unnamed British newspaperman for several years before Mr. Nixon took office in January 1969.

WHITESBURG, Ky., March 10 Less than 24 hours before a methane gas explosion ripped through a section of the Scotia Coal Company mine yesterday, killing 15 miners, a Federal mine inspector issued three safety violation notices in the section.
OSLO, March 10 (AP) Bill Koch of Guilford, Vt., failed to pass his physical today and will not compete in the Holmenkollen Ski Festival startine tomorrow.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, March 10 (AP) Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today dealt a blow to black nationalists' hopes for an early constitutional settlement by denying that he had produced a new set of proposals for study.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10 Armed groups, apparently linked to security forces, have unleashed a wave of violence against political extremists and labor groups opposed to President Isabel Martinez de Peron.

ALBANY, March 10 A bill that would scrap the current legal distinctions between husband and wife in divorce actions and mandate an "equitable division" of the assets of a marriage was introduced in the Legislature today with broad bipartisan support.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Richard M. Nixon said in sworn testimony made public today that he ordered a program of telephone wiretaps in 1969 to locate news leaks, but that it was Henry A. Kissinger, then his national security adviser, who supplied the Federal Bureau of Investigation with the names of the original targets of the program.

Justice Burton B. Roberts dismissed a criminal indictment in State Supreme Court yesterday against three major oil companies that had been charged with violating the state's antitrust law in anticipation of the oil crisis of 1973-74.

JOLIET, Ill., March 10 Insisting that he will not succumb to pressure to withdraw from the race for the Presidency, Ronald Reagan said today that President Ford could not take pleasure in the outcome of yesterday's Florida primary.

MOSCOW, March 10 Ernst Neizvestny, the sculptor who gained attention in 1962 for his shouting match with Nikita S. Khrushchev over modern art, emigrated from the Soviet Union today in a search to expand his creative horizons.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (UPI) Abbott Laboratories reported today that it had paid more than $500,000 to officials in unidentified foreign countries in the last three years.
ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 10 (AP) The wife of Senator Henry M. Jackson, the Democratic Presidential aspirant, said today that she and her husband disagreed on the issue of abortion.

Mary Petty, the cartoonist for the New Yorker whose drawings of bloodless patricians frozen in the prewar world of croquet and tennis and the graceful picnic are compared with the illustrations of Daumier and Hogarth, died Saturday. She was 77 years old, lived at 12 East 88th Street and had been staying at the Pine Rest Nursing Home, Paramus, N.J.

ALBANY, March 10 The Assembly Democrats today presented what they described as an election-year package of bills to reform the state's utility industry and to make the deliberations of the Public Service Commission more accessible to the public.

Texasgulf, Inc., a giant natural-resources company that has had its headquarters in New York since 1918, has decided to close its offices in the Pan Am Building and move all 135 of its jobs here to southern Connecticut.
Does it pay for a wife to work?
ORLANDO, Fla. Edgar Ross, 153 pounds, Orlando, Fla., knocked out Tim Ford, 151, Jacksonville, Fla., 4 rounds.

The City Center Joffrey Ballet is back in town at the City Center 55th Street Theater. It opened last night with the New York premiere of a new ballet by Margo Sappington, a revival of Gerald Arpino's "Fanfarita," featuring the return of the company's Spanish prodigal son, Luis Fuente, and a repeat of last season's Bicentennial bonanza, "Drums, Dreams and Banjos." It was fun and it got better as the night wore on.

MINNIE'S BOYS Puccini's "Girl of the Golden West" is the Italian master's American horse opera, set in the California gold-mining country and usually incling a genuine horse or two in its stagings at the Metropolitan. The work, adapted from David Belasco's drama of the same title, originally opened at the old Met back in 1910, with Arturo Toscanini conducting a cast that included Caruso.
The Arol Development Corporation rented the main building at the Bronx Terminal Market in June 1971 for $25,850 a month, but according to a search of city records, Arol never paid any of it.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 10 Dr. Joel Fort, a key expert witness for the prosecution in Patricia Hearst's bank robbery trial who insisted that she was a liar, was excused today after four days on the stand, two of them under rigorous, sometimes angry cross-examination that left him unshaken.
Maintaining that the industry is not yet ready for such trading, the Securities Industry Association proposed yesterday a "go-slow" approach on trading in put options.

WASHINGTON, March 10 Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota, the ever-buoyant noncandidate for the Presidency, looked to many studious leaders of the Democratic Party today like the passive centerpiece of a "stop everybody" movement. More than ever, he looked very much afloat as a compromise candidate himself.
A Federal judge has dismissed a suit that Bernard Bergman, the nursing-home operator, filed against an Assemblyman, a state official and a reporter for The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP) Calvin J. Collier, President Ford's choice to head the Federal Trade Commission, acknowledged today that he had been a contact man in the Commerce Department for "Operation Responsiveness" run by aides to former President Richard M. Nixon.
WASHINGTON, March 11 The United States Postal Service announced today a cutback in business deliveries in 25 Eastern and Southern cities, including midtown and downtown Manhattan.

ROCKFORD, Ill., March 11 President Ford, described as privately furious over Ronald Reagan's criticism of his policies, has become a more aggressive and confident candidate because of that challenge, his aides said today.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to ban for now any flights of the Concorde supersonic airliner here. The agency acted promptly after it was notified by British Airways and Air France that they intended to start Concorde passenger service to Kennedy International Airport about April 10 and training flights next week.
The Board of Education has moved against 79 school principals who have refused to provide ethnic data about their staffs or pupils.

In the Edwin Arlington Robinson poem "Richard Cory," the title character is the object of everyone's admiration and respect, "a gentleman from sole to crown," who "glittered when he walked" and who inexplicably, "one calm summer night, went home and put a bullet through his head."

The city has notified the Board of Higher Education that, effective this month, it will be placed on a strict monthly cash allowance because it overspent by $2.3 million the February allocation of $34.1 million by the State Emergency Financial Control Board.

The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith charged yesterday that 24 commercial banks and more than 200 American corporations were directly or indirectly assisting in the Arab countries' economic war against Israel.

MADRID, March 11 In the worst battering any Spanish Government has received since the days of the Second Republic 40 years ago, a weekly magazine today called on the Cabinet to resign. It was part of a swelling chorus of disapproval that has followed the bloody disorders of the last eight days.

WASHINGTON, March 11Donald C. Alexander, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, testified today that the Federal income-tax returns of 6,704 individual taxpayers were made available to the Justice Department in 1975 for use in criminal cases that were not related to taxes.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, in a spirited defense of the Ford Administration's record, lashed out today at a conservative and liberal critics alike, warning that together they could end up "by wrecking the nation's ability to conduct a strong, creative, moderate and prudent foreign policy."

Patrick J. Cunningham told the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court here yesterday that unless it overturned a low er-court order requiring him to appear before a special grand jury, his job as the State Demo cratic chairman would be lost.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (UPI) The United States intends to continue reducing the number of its military personnel on Taiwan, the Chinese Nationalist stronghold, the State Department said today.

There was something sinister about the man who stepped into Leo Brenner's liquor store on Broadway at 110th Street and asked for a half-pint of vodka. His coat collar was turned up, his fatigue cap was pulled low and there was a strange look in his eyes.

The indictment yesterday of the majority leader, Albert Blumenthal, on fresh charges involving bribery and perjury casts a darkening cloud over the State Assembly's Democratic leadership. Ellis Rabb, who is appearing in the hit revival of "The Royal Family," which he also staged, has decided to form a new repertory company designed after the disbanded Association of Producing Artists.

The city's most decorated uniformed court officer, who had made several arrests both on and off-duty, was shot to death early yesterday morning on a quiet street in Ozone Park, Queens, in what colleagues called an "ambush attack for revenge."

Foreclosure proceedings have been started against the skyscraper at 1166 Avenue of the Americas, between 45th and 46th Streets, an action that could result in what it is believed would be the greatest real-estate loss on an individual property in the city's history. Contrary to popular belief and widespread practice, it is Purim not Hanukkah that is the Jewish holiday most closely associated with the exchange of gifts.

Gulf and Western Industries has made a "no-strings attached" offer to contribute $100,000 toward the $1-million needed to restore cuts made in New York City's high school sports activities. The cuts have seriously affected Public Schools Athletic League teams.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Ten present and former executives of five grain corporations were accused in a Senate hearing today of having discussed fraudulent grain handling as part of normal business practices.

WHITESBURG, Ky., Friday, March 12 Ten miners were reported trapped early today in an explosion at a mine where 15 workers died in a blast earlier this week, the state police said.

The board of directors of the Rotary Club of New York voted unanimously yesterday against the choice of an Austrian industrialist with an acknowledged Nazi background as the sole nominee to be the next president of Rotary International.
SAYREVILLE, March 11 Thomas DeCaro is a new member of the Board of Education here. He is 19 years old.

ALBANY, March 11 A weeklong deadlock stalling consideration of Governor Carey's $2.6 billion rescue of the state construction agencies was broken tonight when the Legislature came up with an inventive, last-minute compromise and moved toward expected approval of the Governor's bills.
LOS ANGELES, March 11 The New York Rangers' hopes for a National Hockey League playoff berth dimmed to a tiny glow tonight when they were beaten by the Los Angeles Kings, 4-3.

Muhammad Ali has agreed to a championship fight in the Capital Centre near Washington for April 30, leaving him just three and a half weeks' rest before his next bout.

"We're much better than Spain," said a senior South Korean official a few months ago, attempting to impress a visitor with the democratic trappings of President Park Chung Hee's regime. After the murky events of the past few days in Seoul, even that questionable claim seems inappropriate.

WASHINGTON, March 11 Former President Richard M. Nixon said in a sworn statement made public today that he ordered the Central Intelligence Agency to try to keep Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens from becoming the President of Chile in 1970 but that he did not recall knowing that the C.I.A. attempted to foment a military coup d'etat that year.

ALBANY, March 11 Even as they rallied behind him with expressions of support and concern, Assemblyman Albert H. The left political trend in southern Europe, which could bring Communists into governing coalitions for the first time since 1947, has received new confirmation in France's local elections this week. It has also been evident at a national congress of the Socialist Party in Italy.

Marchesa Nicoleta di Villamarina of Marlia, Italy, widow of Marchese di Villamarina, was married in Palm Beach, Fla., yesterday afternoon to Craig Knowlton Mitchell of Palm Beach and Southampton, L.I.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP) The United States signed the Fifth International Tin Agreement today, becoming the last major tin-consuming country to enter into membership.

WASHINGTON, March 11 UOP Inc., in disclosing questionable foreign payments totaling at least $290,000 since 1970, said today it had adopted a policy requiring that overseas agents be told their activities may be reported publicly.

The march of the Dow Jones Industrial average to the 1,000 level has been followed by a growing number of investors abroad, according to United States invest ment firms with overseas offices and personnel.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychological barrier of 1,000 yesterday in a dramatic finish that provided an important prop to the nation's brightening business scene.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 11 Egypt called today for the establishment of an "independent Palestinian entity," strongly backed the Palestine Liberation Organization and reiterated its earlier requests that the Geneva conference on the Middle East be reconvened.

CHICAGO, March 11 Jimmy Carter's stake in Illinois's Democratic primary next Tuesday is a matter of appearances more than hard political reality, but he is making the most of it in a two-day blitz that included five television interviews today, a news conference and an interview with editors of The Chicago Sun-Times.

Governor Carey has made a significant initial attack on "redlining" in the banking industry. The phrase refers to the discriminatory practices of blanket refusal to make mortgage or home improvement loans in neighborhoods with concentrated populations of blacks or other minorities. The result of the practice is capital starvation in certain neighborhoods and inevitable deterioration and decay thereafter.

Martin Fisher, one of the Fisher Brothers, developers of some of New York's biggest and best-known postwar office buildings, died yesterday in Miami. He was 74 years old and had homes here, in Palm Beach, Fla., and on Manursing Island, N.Y.

Gregory Scarpa Sr., reputedly a member of the Joseph Colombo crime family, and 10 other persons were indicted yesterday in connection with the operation of a regional center for policy gambling in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

For years now the United States has tried only one approach to living in the same world with the Soviet Union. With the schedule overflowing in specials, this is doubtless the most untypical weekend of the year for television. There are two simple reasons lurking behind this startling largess. Monday is the deadline for entering Emmy Award contenders, and the commercial networks are being forced to show the few "quality" productions that may win Emmys, but that probably won't share blockbuster ratings.

The owners of High-Tor Manor in Haverstraw, N.Y., where a 65-year-old man starved to death, have agreed to sell the home in exchange for an agreement by the State Board of Social Welfare to end efforts to suspend their license.

The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to ban for now any flights of the Concorde supersonic airliner here. Two ancient New York types of crime, a pair that calls for artists rather than muscle-flexers, seem to be on the upswing in town. The world knows how good a tennis player Jimmy Connors is on a scale of 1-10, he is probably an 11. But until recently his personality rating was in the minus category. So this year Connors has conducted a Mr. Nice Guy campaign to change his image.

The owners of High-Tor Manor in Haverstraw, N.Y., where a 65-year-old man starved to death, have agreed to sell the home in exchange for an agreement by the State Board of Social Welfare to end efforts to suspend their license.

ALBANY, March 11 Governor Carey signed into law today a bill, unanimously passed minutes before by the State Assembly, allowing the names of Democratic Presidential candidates to be listed on the state's April 6 Presidential primary ballot.

Texasgulf Inc., whose plans to relocate its headquarters from New York City to southern Connecticut became known Tuesday, said through a spokesman yesterday that the move had been prompted in part by the need to save commuting time and improve the efficiency of employees who lived in or near Connecticut.

The Public Service Commission refused yesterday to reconsider a Feb. 6 order delaying construction of a power line from the Quebec border to central New York, citing environmental grounds. The action was denounced by the State Power Authority.

For all its fanfare, the Ford Administration has now retreated into waffling on the issue of the Arab boycott and how American business is expected to respond. By its present attitude the executive branch is virtually inviting business firms to flout stated principles of national policy in their pursuit of Arab oil money.

"Justice, though due to the accused, is due to the accuser also." Taking off from that opinion expressed by Justice Benjamin Cardozo in 1934, former United States Attorney General Herbert Brownell proposes "a Mirandalike program" of actions designed to protect the crime victim in his role as complaining witness.

Wheat prices dropped yesterday from 4 to 7 cents a bushel. The old-crop month of May closed at $3.70 a bushel, off 6 cents on the Chicago Board of Trade, while the new crop month of December closed at $3.81 , down 7 .

WASHINGTON, March 11 The House approved today, by a vote of 370 to 14, a bill that would greatly increase Federal aid to the 30 coastal states to enable them to deal with the financial and environmental impacts of energy development off their shores and along coastal areas.
NEWARK, March 11 The State Supreme Court gave a six-week reprieve today to a Tenafly citizens group trying to raise funds for preservation of a 274-acre natural woodland tract atop the Palisades.

ASWAN, Egypt According to legend, the Egyptian god Osiris was hacked into 14 pieces by his spiteful brother, Seth, who then buried the remains in different places. The goddess Isis tracked down the fragments and re-assembled her husband, thus performing one of the first acts of resurrection.
Nearly 1,000 people took part yesterday in a demonstration protesting the planned closing of Public School 144 in Harlem, which is highly praised by parents and its staff.

DENVER, March 10 Clarence and Selma Wolf, a retired couple in East Denver, are solar pioneers. Ignoring talk of solar energy as a thing of the future, they are living comfortably right now in a home heated by the sun.

LAKEHURST, N.J. The new president of the Leisure Technology Corporation, Michael L. Tenzer, was born in New York City and grew up in California. He received a degree in photojournalism, and served as a photographer for Look magazine and as a cameraman in the Signal Corps.

COLOGNE, West Germany, March 11 At least four American cities are vying for a Volkswagen assembly plant in the United States, as the West Germany company's deadline of April 23 for a decision approaches.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (Reuters) President Ford today wrote a letter to Japanese Prime Minister Takeo Miki outlining the United States policy for turning over information on the Lockheed Aircraft corporation scandal.
MIAMI, March 11 A movement by some Northern and Eastern liberals to "stop Carter" is opening a long-hidden cleavage between them and many of their ideological friends in the South.

WASHINGTON, March 11 A Federal judge here has stayed pending appeal his order requiring immediate announcement of the decisions of the Federal Reserve's key Open Market Committee, which are not now made public until 45 days after each meeting of the committee.

WASHINGTON, March 11 House Republican leaders denounced today campaign legislation sponsored by Representative Wayne L. Hays of Ohio as "an arrogant power play" by the Democrats to reduce the Federal Election Commission to a "puppet subsidiary of the majority party."

Acknowledging that he might have been better off if he had "just Xeroxed 100 copies and thrown them on the street," Daniel Schorr, the correspondent for CBS News who gave a copy of a report by the House Select Committee on Intelligence to The Village Voice, took advantage of a rival network's offer last night to make his first network television appearance since being relieved of his reporting duties at CBS on Feb. 23.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed above the psychological barrier of 1,000 yesterday in a dramatic finish that provided an important prop to the nation's brightening business scene.

WASHINGTON, March 11 More than 5 percent of the deposits of the six largest United States banks, totaling more than $11 billion, are from the Middle East and North African oil-producing countries, according to information compiled by the Federal Reserve System.

CHESTER, Pa. For 16 weeks now, members of the striking Newspaper Guild here have marched in front of the entrances to The Delaware County Daily Times carrying signs reading "Scab," while inside the old brick building, editors, their wives and newly hired employees have been putting out the paper.

WASHINGTON, March 12 The accusers confronted the accused at a Senate hearing today on the affair of the Rysy II, the glant Polish supertanker that Agriculture Department officials have charged was loaded with improperly graded, low-quality corn.

Fortunately for the Republicans in control of the State Senate, the confirmation procedures of that body give them a chance to undo the folly perpetrated by the Committee on Crime and Corrections when it refused to approve the nomination of Herman Schwartz to be chairman of the State Commission on Corrections.
MIAMI, March 12 Mark Hayes noticed today that his swing was getting a trifle fast, but he insisted it was not a sign of nervousness. Still, he added, "I'll have to swing a bit easier."
UNIONDALE, L.I., March 12 The bench of the New York Nets in the persons of Tim Bassett and Chuck Terry provided the needed defensive help tonight in a 124-106 victory over the Kentucky Colonels.
"It has been causing me many sleepless nights," said Wesley Jackson, a junior at Medgar Evers College, commenting on a proposed reorganization of the colloge.

WASHINGTON, March 12 The Ford Administration has decided to continue the 12-year ban on loans to South Africa by the Export-Import Bank, despite heavy pressure by American business interests and a group of conservative Congressmen, according to State Department and White House officials.
Milton Waldman, a writer, editor and publisher who specialized in Renaissance biographies, died last Saturday in a London hospital. He was 80 years old.

A jury in State Supreme Court last night convicted Frederic S. Rice, the city's former tax collector, of filing a fraudulent state income-tax return in 1971, but acquitted him of a similar charge involving his 1970 return.

LISBON The only significant plus recorded by United States foreign policy during the past year a period marked by disasters in Southeast Asia and southern Africa, by setbacks in India and Canada and by worrisome stalemates in the Middle East and the Aegean has come in little Portugal. And one cannot attribute the remarkable change in outlook here to the wisdom, foresight or craft of American planners.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 12 The Nigerian Government announced today that the former defense minister and 29 others had been out to death for their part in last month's attempted coup, in which the chief of state was assassinated.

The City Council, frequently characterized as an ineffective appendage of municipal government, was urged by State Senator Roy M. Goodman yesterday to "seize the golden opportunity" afforded by the revised City Charter to transform itself into "a true legislative body."

NEW ORLEANS, March 12 Mayor Moon Landrieu, who is being honored by New York City for his help during its fiscal trouble, is a shorttempered, hard-headed and frequently effective public official who believes in oldfashioned politics.

Dr. Robert P. Whalen, the State Health Commissioner, yesterday approved the decision of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation to close four municipal hospitals, a neighborhood family healthcare center and major services at two other city institutions.
WHITESBURG, Ky., March 12 Eleven men were killed last night in the second of two explosions in a mine near here within three days, bringing the toll to 26.

A midnight roundup of legislators by state police saved another state agency from default early yesterday; but the incident does little to avert the larger fiscal crisis toward which other agencies and the state government itself are hurtling.
STRASBOURG, France, March 12 The nine-member European Parliament called today on Common Market heads of government to make sure that the first European elections take place by May 1978.

WASHINGTON, March 12 The second death-dealing explosion in less than three days deep in the Scotia Coal Company mine in eastern Kentucky raised new questions here today about both the effectiveness of the Federal mine safety program and the procedures that exposed the latest 11 victims to the threat of death under ground. The cause of both blasts remains a mystery.
Prices declined yesterday for the first time this week on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 12 "On the final out of the ninth inning of today's game," Tom Seaver said as he watched the baseball exiles at work, "we're putting a sign on the door saying, 'Gone fishing.'"

WASHINGTON, March 12 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has officially reprimanded two of his closest State Department associates for having disclosed without specific authorization excerpts from Mr. Kissinger's secret conversations with Middle East leaders.

The bacterium that causes syphilis has been grown in a test tube for the first time and then used to develop an experimental vaccine against the potentially fatal venereal disease, a team of researchers in Florida reported yesterday.

The Who, the veteran British rock band that made it into Madisan Square Garden Thursday night, would seem to depend in its performances on the physical and psychological health of two of its four members.

WASHINGTON, March 12 Senator Henry M. Jackson today abandoned plans to contest the North Carolina Presidential primary election March 23 to devote his "full attention to the New York and Pennsylvania primaries."

TROY, N.Y., March 12 City College, playing in its first postseason tournament since 1957, hit on 70 percent of its second-half shots tonight and defeated Rochester Institute of Technology, 94-69, in the opening round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III Eastern basketball playoffs.

PARIS, March 12 After sharp declines in the British pound and Italian lira, speculative pressure against the French franc has increased, stirring fears that Western Europe may be headed for competitive devaluations that could jeopardize its economic recovery.

LAGOS, Nigeria, March 12 The Nigerian Government announced today that the former defense minister and 29 others had been put to death for their part in last month's attempted coup, in which the chief of state was assassinated.

ROCHESTER, March 12 Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona picked up additional support today from former backers of Senator Birch Bayh of Indiana in his effort to marshal this state's liberal Democrats behind his drive for Presidential delegates in the April 6 primary.

WASHINGTON, March 12 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger told reporters today that he would not take to "the political stump" in this election year. But he served notice on all opponents of President Ford, in both parties, that he would continue to react strongly to criticism of the Administration's foreign policy.

More than 200 paintings, pieces of sculpture and other treasures from the State Art Collection in Dresden, East Germany, will be exhibited at the Metropolitan Museum of Art next year in the biggest show of important general art ever brought to the United States from a Communist country.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 12 (Reuters) A court handed out heavy jail terms here today to four Yugoslavs charged with being Stalinists, including a former Deputy Prime Minister of Croatia, for allegedly plotting to overthrow the Government.

Opponents of a $1 billion plan to reconstruct the West Side Highway are hopeful of crippling the project by deleting a $14 million planning appropriation from the proposed state budget, State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, March 12 The former chief lobbyist in Washington for the Gulf Oil Corporation was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on two felony counts of making illegal campaign contributions.

Air France and British Airways plan to file a suit in Federal District Court here next week in an attempt to overturn a ban on Concorde flights to Kennedy International Airport, airline sources said yesterday.
MOLINE, Ill., March 12 Gov. George C. Wallace stuck cosely today to the politics that has worked for him for a decade as he stumped through the small cities that ring Chicago.

NEW DELHI, March 12 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government today assumed direct control over the west coastal state of Gujarat, which has been the last bastion of opposition to the new political order that she has brought to India in the last eight months.
Wall Street has made money for years on the assumption that the nation's growing fleet of passenger cars would constantly and increasingly need replacement parts.

Israel's fashion industry which wound up a week's showing yesterday at the New York Hilton Hotel, expects to export $130 million in apparel this year, an increase of 11.5 percent over the level of 1975, according to an Israeli official
WASHINGTON, March 12 An attempt to rescind the ratification of the equal rights amendment to the Constitution was defeated today in Kentucky.

CHICAGO, March 12 Ronald Reagan's campaign chairman in Illinois questioned today the integrity of President Ford and said he was unfairly using the White House to "buy" votes in the state's primary election next Tuesday.

CAIRO, March 12 (AP) Egyptian authorities today announced the arrest of 12 more Libyans as agents for sabotage and assassination and said that Libya's leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, was also trying to cause political trouble in Iraq.

LOS ANGELES, March 12 Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's 29 points and 26 rebounds led the Los Angeles Lakers to a 113-95 National Basketball Association victory over the New York Knicks tonight. The Laker center also had seven assists and five blocked shots.

Interior Secretary Thomas S. Kleppe warned yesterday that in the face of restrictive legislative moves, the nation's coal producers are "left in a state of uncertainty" by Administration pleas to increase production.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., March 12 The Spring National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began the first of 10 days of play here this afternoon. Some 4,000 players will take part in six major events, including the Vanderbilt Cup, and many minor ones. Two hundred fifty-six pairs entered the men's pair championship, and 300 the women's pairs.

BONN, March 12 A treaty that provides for the emigration of up to 125,000 ethnic Germans from Poland was ananimously ratified today by the West German Parliament after a week of tense round-the-clock negotiations between Warsaw and Bonn.

ALBANY, March 12 From motel rooms, parking lots, bars, restaurants, and as far away as 40 miles down the Thruway, enough startled Assemblymen were rounded up early this morning by the state police and frantic staff members to produce the votes to keep a state agency out of default.

TOLEDO, Ohio, March 12 Frank Le Blond Kloeb, a former United States Representative from Ohio's Fourth District who was on the United States District Court bench here for 37 years died yesterday at the age of 85. He retired in 1964 from active status but remained until July 1974 as a judge sitting by assignment in criminal and civil matters.

In an operation that will take several days, workmen have begun to remove the Grant sign from atop the building at 1515 Broadway, former headquarters for the large retail chain that went into bankruptcy last fall.

Charles Ellis, a painter and former actor, died Thursday in Pittsfield (Mass.) General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived with his wife, the former Norma Millay, actress and sister of Edna St. Vincent Millay, the poet, at Steepletop, an art colony in Austerlitz, N.Y.

New Jersey's Congressional delegation in Washington has received good marks in a rating of their voting records on consumer issues, according to the Consumer Federation of America, the largest such group in the United States.

The Arabian American Oil Company announced yesterday that a general accord had been reached on major issues involving the total takeover of the company by the Saudi Arabian Government. Four major American oil companies that make up Aramco now own 40 percent of the company and Saudi Arabia the rest.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped sharply amid profit taking yesterday after closing above 1,000 on Thursday for the first time in more than three years.

WASHINGTON, March 12 The Senate Armed Services and Appropriatoins Committees recommended today that Congress make no reductions in the $1.14 billion defense budget proposed by the Administration for the next fiscal year.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, the General Tire and Rubber Company and the Westinghouse Electric Corporation are the latest in a growing list of companies that say they have been involved in questionable or improper payments overseas.

The State Health Department said yesterday that it would move to revoke the nursinghome license of Bernard Bergman, who on Thursday pleaded guilty to Medicaid fraud and the bribery of Albert H. Blumenthal, the Assembly majority leader.
TUCSON, Ariz., March 12 (AP) Iowa's Hawkeyes regained the lead tonight as they try to repeat as the National Collegiate wrestling champions. Iowa passed its strongest challenger, Iowa State.

ROISSY-EN-FRANCE, France, March 8 Most Frenchmen are proud of the Concorde as a feat of French engineering and are unconcerned by its noise pollution, although those living, in the plane's flight paths here are worried.

The Mobil Oil Corporation offered yesterday to acquire the balance of Marcor Inc., the Chicago based holding company that owns Montgomery Ward Company, for a package of common stock and debentures carrying a market value of about $798 million.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 12 (UPI) Foremost-McKesson Inc. disclosed today that it was under investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission over possible violations of Federal securities laws involving disclosure of information, The company is a wholesale distributor of drugs, liquors and other products.

ORANGE COVE, Calif. Jacques Giddens, a 59-yearold farmer, is in trouble with the Federal Government, His crime; selling 3,441 more cartons of navel oranges from his 40-acre farm here than the Government said he could.
HAMPTON, Va., March 12 (AP) Second-seeded Ilie Nastase of Rumania posted a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Ray Moore of South Africa tonight in the quarterfinals of a $50,000 tennis tournament.

WASHINGTON Liberals and conservatives agree that the food-stamp program should make it possible for every American to receive a nutritionally adequate diet and that this should be accomplished with maximum efficiency and at minimum cost to the taxpayers, with minimum opportunities for fraud.
The F. M. Schaefer Corporation, which had ranked as the nation's seventh largest brewer in 1974, lost $32 million in the fourth quarter of 1975, the largest deficit for any year in its history.

WASHINGTON, March 12 (AP) The nomination of a former Martin Marietta Corporation executive to a new post in the Pentagon is being held up following disclosure that he accepted a Pentagon post in 1963 after the huge defense contractor promised him a job when he left Government service.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported here yesterday that its profits for the three months ended Feb. 29 rose to $831.2 million, at $1.31 a share, a 20.6 percent increase over the $689.2 million, or $1.13 a share, reported for the corresponding period a year ago.

MERCURY, Nev., March 17 (AP) Two nuclear devices were detonated underground at the Nevada Test Site early today, causing a pair of earth tremors that were felt in Las Vegas. The first was set off at Pahute Mesa, 120 miles from Las Vegas, at 6:15 A.M. The second was detonated about 6:45 A.M. on Yucca Flat, 90 miles from the city.

In terms of basic reform, the fruits of the state's long investigation into profiteering and mistreatment of the elderly in proprietary nursing homes have been pitifully meager. In the name of economy, the State Legislature now seems bent on making them more meager still.

LONDON, March 17 Prime Minister Harold Wilson quoted a Conservative predecessor, Stanley Baldwin, in his resignation statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 17 Fifty years ago Attorney General Harlan F. Stone said the Bureau of Investigation, as the F.B.I. was then called, "is not concerned with political or other opinions of individuals. It is concerned only with their conduct, and then only with such conduct as is forbidden by the laws of the United States."

New York's baseball fans are disappointed, upset and even disgusted by the delay of spring training.

The National Playwrights Conference of the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Center will establish a "drama for television" project during its 1976 conference, which will be held in Waterford, Conn., from July 18 through Aug. 15. The program, developed by Lloyd Richards, conference artistic director, is being supported by grants from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Exxon Corporation.

Jascalevich, who was named yesterday as a New Jersey surgeon suspected of murdering patients at a hospital a decade ago, illustrates in a most unusual way the difficulties of doctors policing the medical profession. Reports on Tuesday of improving business inventories and housing starts helped prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market post gains yesterday in more active trading.

The Ford Motor Company was ordered yesterday by a Federal judge here to pay a small Yonkers distributor of auto-repair parts more than $1 million in damages and lawyer's fees as a result of unlawful price discrimination.

The production of Gaetano Donizetti's "Lucrezia Borgia" by the New York City Opera Company at the New York State Theater last nght was only its third performance here in this country, according to music experts.

ALBANY, March 18 (AP) A State Supreme Court Judge rejected today an attempt by supporters of Senator Hubert H. Humphrey to put the Minnesota Democrat's name on the New York Presidential primary ballot April 6.
ROME, March 18 The Italian Government announced today a series of austerity measures designed to ease the economic crisis and prevent its own political collapse.

HIGH POINT, N.C., March 18 Jimmy Carter had just finished telling a college audience here that "there are no big shot politicians endorsing me" when Gov. David Boren of Oklahoma declared his support by telephone for reporters following the Carter campaign.
The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market closed lower yesterday in slower trading.
A carrot-and-stick combination of fiscal incentives and pressures appears to be moving New Jersey at last toward overhaul of its chaotic tax structure, one of the most regressive in the nation.

Beth Israel Hospital has threatened to stop supplying doctors to staff the city's Gouverneur Hospital, on the Lower East Side, after inpatient service is ended at Gouverneur as an economy move this year.
An upsurge in the nation's money supply to a record level was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 18 (AP) Seven women, the first appointed to the Naval Academy, are among the initial group of 247 persons accepted for the class that will enter the Academy on July 6.
BRUSSELS, March 18 (UPI) European currencies continued under strain today, with speculation aimed at the revaluation of the strong West German mark.

The Public Service Commission yesterday denied an application of the Long Island Lighting Company for an interim electric rate increase of $26.4 million, pending decision on its application for a permanent increase of $90 million a year.

WASHINGTON, March ,18 The Senate aging subcommittee on long term care has produced material that it says points to a growing scandal in the care of the elderly the "warehousing" of old, mentally ill people who have been pushed out of state mental hospitals into substandard profitmaking boarding houses that are supported by a Federal welfare program.

Judge Charles L. Brieant Jr. of the Federal District Court here, in a decision handed down on Wednesday, upheld the right of three customers of Merrill Lynch, Piece, Fenner Smith Inc. to bring a class action against the big brokerage house for alleged fraud.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 Renewed charges from the United States that Mexico is not doing enough to curb the northward flow of narcotics have brought an angry defense of the Mexican Government's latest drive against the illegal drug traffic.

The grand drama with which America picks its President turns now to three disheveled offices in midtown Manhattan. There, bands of Democrats, familiar political faces for the most part but projecting group personalities as varied as the men they support, toil to win delegates in the New York primary election on April 6.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 196.9 from l95.3 last week.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) The physical fitness of American boys and girls, which showed significant gains from 1958 to 1965, has not improved in the last 10 years, the Office of Education said today.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., March 18 The National Park Service, venturing cautiously into a metropolitan setting unfamiliar to its guardians of forest and wilderness, offered the public three choices today for developing the 26,000-acre Gateway National Recreation Area, which extends from this wild strip of the oceanfront to the crowded beaches of Queens.
