TRENTON, March 18 A study made for the state's Department of Public Advocate released here today challenges a conclusion of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission that risks of deadly accidents at floating nuclear ener- gy plants are "exceedingly small."

ALBANY, March 18 Governor Carey today vetoed a bill that would have required New York City to spend a fixed proportion of its budget on its schools, thus setting up a potentially embarrassing confrontation with the Democraticcontrolled Assembly, where the bill has overwhelming support.
Paul Jennings, the 58-yearold president of the International Union of Electrical Workers, announced in Washington yesterday that he was resigning, effective June 1, for health reasons.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (Reuters) The State Department has halted publication of two official booklets that made it easy for outsiders to identify Central Intelligence Agency personnel posing as diplomats.

ALBANY, March 18 The Bank of America, the country's largest bank, has demanded further action by Governor Carey and the Legislature to strengthen the security of state notes and revenues as a condition for its assistance in meeting the state's critical borrowing needs this spring.

THE HAGUE, March 18 (Reuters) Prime Minister Joop M. Den Uyl said tonight that a Dutch railway engineering company paid almost $12 million in "commissions" to secure a huge order in Argentina in 1951.
HICKORY, N.C., March 18 Ronald Reagan, struggling for survival in the Republican primaries, blithely suggested today that President Ford leave the Presidential race.

WASHINGTON, March 18 The amount of taxes that the Federal Government fails to collect because of special preferential provisions in the tax law has risen even faster in the last 10 years than Federal spending has, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today.

The Transport Workers Union, whose contract with the Transit Authority expires at the end of this month, appealed to Governor Carey yesterday to have the Emergency Financial Control Board join the negotiations in an effort to avert a bus and subway strike on April 1.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) President Ford has not asked or authorized anyone to get in touch with Ronald Reagan and urge him to drop out of the Republican Presidential nomination race, the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

Aqueduct race track will be closed today because of a strike by 187 maintenance workers at midnight last night. Money is the key issue, and the union and the New York Racing Association were reported "far apart. " Page 41.

It has been a long time between drinks. The last time New York saw a staged production of Donizetti's "Lucrezia Borgia" was at the Metropolitan Opera in 1904, and it had only one performance there. Last night, the New York City Opera gave a "Borgia," staged for Beverly Sills at the New York State Theater.

MOSCOW, March 18 (AP) Photographs of contenders for this year's Democratic and Republican Presidential nomination have been placed on display here in a United States Information Service exhibit called "The Struggle for the White House Lead."
ST. PAUL, March 18 (AP) "Minnesota Man" is now "Minnesota Woman;" by order of the State Legislature.

WASHINGTON This winter more than 8,500 Jamaicans were cutting sugar cane less than 35 miles from Palm Beach, Fla. They were flown into the area on chartered planes, and when the season is over they will be flown back home.

There was a time when it would have been unlikely for three stewardesses, or flight attendants, as they are called nowadays, to spend even part of an evening on the town discussing the provisions of their new union agreement, but this was indeed the case a couple of nights ago.

Donald G.C. Sinclair, a longtime Brooklyn civic leader who retired two months ago as a senior accounts executive with White, Weld Company, investment bankers, died Wednesday, apparently of a heart attack, at New York Polyclinic Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I.
MADRID, March 18 The Spanish Government sought today to regain the initiative by approving more political changes and taking measures to appease labor discontent.
WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Vice President Rockefeller said today that Congress should not attempt to solve the problems of unemployment by legislating new constraints on the free enterprise system.

New York State is prepared to buy a big section of the bankrupt Erie Lackawanna Railroad from here to Ohio to keep freight service from being downgraded under the new Federal rail corporation, the State Transportation Comissioner, Raymond T. Schuler, said yesterday.
Demonstrations were held yesterday on at least five campuses in various parts of the state, with students staging sit-ins in administrative offices and warning of more to come.

CRISTOBAL, Panama Canal Zone, March 18 (AP) Only six ships passed through the Panama Canal yesterday and more than 100 were backed up today in a job action by United States employees that has created the most expensive traffic jam in the canal's 62-year history.

HILLSDALE, Mich. George C. Roche 3d, the president of Hillsdale College, got an unexpected letter recently containing a donation of $10,000 to the college, accompanied by a note saying, "Give them hell, George."

A fundamental domestic issue how to establish a full-employment economy under conditions of relative price stability has been thrust into the forefront of a Presidential campaign in which all the candidates in both parties have shown greater readiness to hide behind slogans than to define realistic solutions.
LISBON, March 18 Manuel da Silva Aguardenteiro is a 54year-old sharecropper with sunburned face and calloused hands who was driven from his land by the Portuguese revolution.
Joe Frazier and George Foreman, two boxers with one thought in mind another shot at Muhammad Ali's heavyweight championship came face to face here yesterday to announce formally their rematch.
Weakness in some chemical issues and strength in the oil group appeared in the market yesterday as most stocks drifted downward on relatively low volume.

Dr. Paul A. Younge, a gynecologist and pioneer in the prevention of cervical cancer, died of a heart attack yesterday at Newton-Wellesley Hospital in Wellesley, Mass. He was 71 years old and had homes in Wellesley and in Laconia, N.H.
Kelly, Nason Inc. was once a small ad agency that specialized in travel accounts. That was once, before it got its new owners and management.

KASSEL, West Germany Edgar Keenon, the giant American bass-baritone, who is the Flying Dutchman in the new Kassel production of Wagner's opera, sits as the makeup artist paints his face ghostly pale and cautions a visitor about the performance. "Now, don't be shocked," he says.
The Mobil Oil Corporation yesterday withdrew its controversial proposal to acquire the balance of the common stock of Marcor Inc. after the Marcor directors voted to reject the oil company's offer.
The American Hospital Supply Corporation of Evanston, Ill., said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to acquire the Consyne Corporation of San Marcos, Calif., for stock

DETROIT, March 18 (AP) Leonard Woodcock, President of the United Automobile Workers, said today that a push for reduced work time but no reduced pay would be the union's top goal in talks on new labor contracts with the automobile industry this summer.

The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn yesterday upheld an Orange County court ruling that bans a strike by county employees. But leaders of the walkout by some 600 members of the Civil Service Employees Association said the strike, which enters its third day today, would continue.
WARSAW, March 16 Polish Communists are saying privately that strong dissent from official policy in recent months has markedly influenced the recent amending of Poland's constitution.
NEW DELHI, March 16 India, which has one of the world's major population problems, has begun a national debate about a drastic solution to it compulsory sterilization.
LONDON, March 18-Scotland Yard, seeking to thwart Irish Republican Army terrorism on London's trains, assigned 1,000. policemen today to the city's subway system.
ALBANY, March 18 The state plans to hire the fishermen who were thrown out of work by the recent order closing the Hudson River to commercial fishing.

WASHINGTON, March 18 President Ford's advisers have urged him to use his office in his contest with Ronald Reagan for the Republican Presidential nomination. He has taken the advice literally, using not just the Presidency but the Oval Office itself to reach voters in the primary states.

LE HAVRE, France, March 18 (AP) Striking printers, out of work for a year, occupied the laid-up liner France today in a demonstration against "abandonment for the sake of wastage and profit" and to publicize their cause.

SANDY HOOK, N.J., March 18 The National Park Service venturing cautiously into a metropolitan setting unfamiliar to its guardians of forest and wilderness, offered the public three choices today for developing the 26,000-acre Gateway National Recreation Area, which extends from this wild strip of the oceanfront to the crowded beaches of Queens.

A Beame administration bill designed to eliminate corruption in the construction industry by substituting private engineers and architects for city building inspectors was strongly attacked yesterday by members of the City Council's Housing and Buildings Committee.

TUXEDO, N.Y. The term that the Sterling Forest people like to use to describe their prospective great leap forward in staged growth is "planned integrated community."
TRENTON, March 18 Teachers, librarians, counselors and other nonsupervisory administrators at the eight state colleges began voting today on whether to strike next Wednesday.

MEXICO CITY, March 18 Mexico's state oil monopoly, Pemex, announced today that crude oil production here would exceed one million barrels a day by the end of 1976, but it continued to withhold any estimate of the country's newly discovered reserves.

LONDON, March 18 Queen Elizabeth II has consulted lawyers about the rift in the marriage of her sister, Princess Margaret, and the Earl of Snowdon, and a Buckingham Palace source said the couple appeared headed for a legal separation but not a divorce.

Sixty books, including 50 copies of "The Fixer," by Bernard Malamud, have been removed from school libraries and classrooms in Levittown, L.I. by school board members who found them objectionable, according to the teachers' union there.

Emily Coye Wood, a former social worker who served the Travelers Aid Society and the Red Cross here in the 1930's and 40's, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital in Cleveland. She was 85 years old and lived in Shelter Harbor, Westerly, R.I.

A waning of the entrepreneurial spirit is a principal cause of New York State's economic decline, according to two scholars who have made a new assessment of the state's problems and published their findings in Search, the quarterly of the State University of New York.

GREENSBORO, N. C., March 18 Instead of Phil Sellers, it was Steve Hefele. Instead of Jim Bailey, it was Abdel Anderson. Instead of Mike Dabney, it was Hollis Copeland. The leading characters may change, but the Rutgers basketball show goes on.

Beame administration officials are planning to seek the services of dozens of additional executives from the business world as dollar-a-year volunteers to help deal with what is termed a growing "management crisis" the loss of a third of the city's cadre of career management specialists since the fiscal crisis began.

LONDON, March 18 The scramble to succeed Harold Wilson as Britain's Prime Minister was widened tonight when Denis Healey, the controversial Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced that he would seek the post.
Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has named 13 members of a Special Task Force on Taxation, it was announced yesterday by Governor Carey.

UNIONDALE, L.I., March 18 In what they hope was a preview of the American Basketball Association playoffs, the New York Nets defeated the Denver Nuggets tonight, 110-98, in a tough, controlled effort at the Nassau Coliseum.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 18 The prosecutor in Patricia Hearst's bank robbery trial told the jury in his summation today that her "story" was "just too incredible to believe," but her chief defense lawyer said, "This is not a case about bank robbery it is a case about dying or surviving."

WASHINGTON, March 18 The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics has asked one of its members, Arthur Kranish, to resign because he published information given confidentially to its Washington chapter in a background briefing by senior officials of the Central Intelligence Agency.
Today's thoroughbred racing program at Aqueduct was canceled last night after maintenance workers called a midnight strike.

WASHINGTON, March 18 A retired vice admiral who was in charge of nuclear targeting said today that the Defense Department was proposing to revoke the authority given to the North American Air Defense commander to use nuclear weapons in certain circumstances.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 18 A United Nations committee announced today that it would sponsor an international seminar in Havana in May "in support of the struggle for liberation in South Africa."

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Federal officials have disclosed that there have been at least 175 instances of violence or threats of it against nuclear facilities across the nation since 1969.

ELMONT, L.I., March 18 The wife of a bank executive who was handcuffed to a spinet piano in her home this morning dragged the piano through her living room to call for help and successfully thwart a bank holdup.

WASHINGTON, March 18 A retired vice admiral who was in charge of nuclear targeting said today that the Defense Department, was proposing to revoke the authority given to the North American Air Defense commander to use nuclear weapons in certain circumstances.
The American Jewish Congress has received assurances from 22 leading United States concerns that they would not become involved in the Arab boycott of Israel.

People are calling the Department of the Public Advocate in increasing numbers these days since the office recently expanded its costfree phone line for citizen complaints to a round-theclock service.

A Board of Education meeting with district superintendents that was scheduled to be held yesterday was suddenly postponed after representatives of the city's community school boards called for a boycott of the session.

ALBANY, March 18 A special commission on child welfare proposed legislation today aimed at improving the process by which foster children under state care are taken from unsuitable families and put up for adoption.

Carlyle J. Frarey, senior lecturer and assistant to the dean at the School of Library Service of Columbia University since 1964, died of a heart ailment Saturday at his home here. He was 57 years old

It was an unusually timely and relevant speech that the Taoiseach Prime Minister Liam Cosgrave of the Republic of Ireland delivered to a joint session of the United States Congress on St. Patrick's Day.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 18 (Reuters) A Yugoslav court has turned down an appeal by a Yugoslav-born United States citizen against his conviction and seven-year jail sentence on charges of espionage, informed American sources said here today.

GATLINBURG, Tenn., March 18 (UPI) A station wagon belonging to Bradford Bishop Jr., a State Department official wanted in the slaying of his wife, mother and three sons, was found today in a hikers' parking lot in the Great Smoky Mountains.
WASHINGTON, March 18 The J.I. Case Company has reported to the Securities and Exchange Commission three instances of very small questionable payments, it was disclosed today.

DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, March 17 Vast additional oil fields, equivalent in size to more than 20 percent of the United States total proven reserves, were discovered in Saudi Arabia during 1975, executives of the Arabian American Oil Company reported here today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18 (AP) Democratic Party officials in Ohio say that campaign aides to Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California are exploring the possibility of his making a late entry as a candidate in this state's Presidential primary election.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 18 (AP) Ray Floyd, who reached the turning point in his career in this event three years ago, posted a solid, four-under-par 68, and tied for the first-round lead today in the $175,000 Greater Jacksonville open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (AP) Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld issued today orders aimed at tightening, and eventually reducing, use of the Air Force's 25 special-mission planes for official Government travel.

BRIGHT AND BREEZY The music you hear piano and bass upon entering Le Chevalier (288-9031), a French restaurant at 1464 Second Avenue (between 76th and 77th Streets), is as lively and relaxing as the atmosphere of the entrance bar. Michel (who turns out to be the owner) extends a greeting and invites a stranger to join the cocktail crowd and enjoy himself.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., March 18 (AP) Fifteen Las Vegas strip hotels struck by service employes refused today to submit to binding arbitration, despite a union offer to send employees back to work.

The city's two-year-old Industrial Development Agency has arranged its first tax-exempt financing of a factory expansion, and the agreement is permitting a Bronx manufacturer of metal cabinets to move into a new plant and, double its staff of 67 workers.

Heavy commercial buying sent corn prices higher once again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. May corn gained 2 cents a bushel to close at $2.73 .

The London Symphony Orchestra's second concert of its current New York run Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall confirmed some of the problems that had been reported after its opening concert on Tuesday. Sears, Roebuck Company, the world's largest retailer, reported yesterday that it rang up record sales in the quarter and fiscal year ended Jan. 31, with earnings 102 percent higher for the quarter and 5.4 percent higher for the year.

WOR-TV/Channel 9 announced yesterday that it would devote five successive evenings in September, from 5:30 to around midnight, exclusively to the showing of programs from Thames Television, the London independent television station and production company.
ST. PAUL, March 18 (AP) "Minnesota Man" is now "Minnesota Woman," by order of the State Legislature.
MAURICETOWN, March 18 More than half the people who live in this tiny historic village on the banks of the Maurice River in lower Cumberland County are retired, and many have failing eyesight.

The Conference Board said yesterday that its latest survey of consumer intentions indicated that 10.7 percent of the 10,000 families studied intended to buy a new or used car in the next six months. This compared with 7.5 percent voicing such intentions in December.

Prudencio Unanue, founder and board chairman of Goya Foods Inc., processors and packagers of beans, rice, hot sauces and other foods popular in the Hispanic community, died Wednesday at his home in Rio Piedras, P.R. He was 89 years old and also lived in Bogota, N.J.

CINCINNATI, March 18 The executive council of the National Black Political Convention announced today that it would recommend the drafting of a black member of Congress. Representative Ronald V. Dellums, Democrat of California, to run for President as the candidate of the new Independent Freedom Party.

IDAHO CITY, March 18 Senator Frank Church of Idaho officially declared himself a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nomination today, telling a crowd of about 2,500 people standing in the muddy streets of this gold-rush town. "It's never too late nor are the odds too great to try."

WASHINGTON, March 18 The Senate aging subcommittee on long term care has produced material that it says points to a growing scandal in the care of the elderly the "warehousing" of old, mentally ill people who have been pushed out of state mental hospitals into substandard profitmaking boarding houses that are supported by a Federal welfare program.

PRAGUE March 18 (AP) Norbert Fryd, a Czechoslovak writer who described his experiences in the Nazi concentration camps of Auschwitz, Dachau and Terezin, was reported dead today. He was 63 years old. The cause and date of death were not made known.

WASHINGTON, March 18 (UPI) The Justice Department, in a policy reversal, announced today that it did not oppose the take-over by White Consolidated Industries Inc. of the financially troubled White Motor Corporation.

ALBANY, March 18 The state board charged with policing possible conflicts of interest among top state employees will decide tomorrow whether Ogden R. Reid, the Commissioner of Environmental Conservation, must sell substantial holdings of stock in companies that are regulated by his department.

State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist has replied to the Beame administration's threat to end all fiscal support for the City University's senior colleges as of July 1977 with the counter-threat that this would free the state to shut the colleges down two months later. Mr. Nyquist insists, moreover, that Albany will not consider enlarging its present support of CUNY unless the city rescinds its free-tuition policy.

The Arol Development Corporation operator of the Bronx Terminal Market, denied yesterday it had obtained its lease by fraud and charged that the city's Investigation Department was pressing such an allegation reluctantly, because of the "clamor of publicity."

Betsy Ross and Molly Pitcher were good "helpers," but they just don't inspire patriotic ecstasy. Indeed, the whole masculine, militaristic flavor of the celebration turns me off.
CAIRO, Friday, March 19 (AP) Ali and Mustafa Amin, twin brothers, have lost their positions on the newspapers they founded 30 years ago, the Cairo daily Al Gumhouria reported today.

WASHINGTON, March 19Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz was aware that Howard H. Callaway, as Secretary of the Army, discussed his Colorado ski resort with J. Phil Campbell, an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, last July.

ROME, March 19 The new austerity measures announced by the Italian Government were described by bankers and other experts today as useful but inadequate to deal with the underlying ills of Italy's economy.

Archbishop Molloy and Bishop Loughlin won opening-round games last night in the Cardinal Cooke Interdiocesan basketball tournament at Christ the King High School in Queens. The statewide event is being held for the first time.

WASHINGTON, March 19 (AP) President Ford said today that the longer he and Ronald Reagan continued their Republican primary battles, the more likely it became that they would foster party divisions that could hurt the party in November.

BATON ROUGE, La., March 19 Al McGuire, Marquette's basketball coach, admitted he was rooting for Indiana to beat Alabama last night: he wanted the Indiana-Marquette showdown that will take place tomorrow in the Mideast Regional final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 19 Baseball players kept streaming into the spring training bases from around the country today, restoring the scene to something like normal after the 17-day shutdown caused by labor problems.

Mayor Beame has been subpoenaed by the Securities and Exchange Commission to produce his official papers by March 31 to help the Government agency in its continuing investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities.

Carlo Montano of Italy won a fence-off against Bernard Talvard of France and took the foil title last night on the opening day of competition in the Martini Rossi international challenge tournament at the New York Athletic Club.
DURHAM, N.C., March 19 North Carolina, the site of a potentially pivotal Presidential primary election next Tuesday, is a state where reputation and reality constantly seem to rub shoulders.

The first Woman Athlete of the World award was presented to Chris Evert yesterday at a luncheon held in her honor at Gallagher's Steak House. PALM SPRINGS, Calif., March 22 (AP) Stan Smith had to struggle to defeat Mike Cahill of Wilmington, Del., 6-4, 7-5; Steve Krulevitz of Baltimore upset Vijay Amritraj of India, 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, and Bill Brown of San Luis Obispo, Calif., pulled the second upset of the day by downing Jeff Borowiak, 4-6, 7-6, 6-1, at the start of the $200,000 American Airlines tennis tournament today at the Mission Hills Country Club.

Princess White, whose stage career as a dancer and singer began in 1886, collapsed and died backstage at the Emelin Theater for the Performing Arts in Mamaroneck, N.Y., Saturday night after singing two numbers with Clyde Bernhardt's Harlem Blues and Jazz Band. She was 95 years old and lived at 387 South 18th Street in Newark.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 22 Tom Seaver replied to some public sniping today, insisted he was neither "militant" nor "reaching for the moon" and said he would be "really surprised" if the New York Mets traded him.
Senior tournament tennis (ages 45 to 70) is alive and vigorous in the metropolitan area, despite perennial complaints of aches and ailments among its partisans.

Carnegie Hall will open today a drive for $6.5 million that will be highlighted by a concert on May 18 that will include such artists as Vladimir Horowitz, Leonard Bernstein, Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, Mstislav Rostropovich, Isaac Stern, Martina Arroyo and members of the New York Philharmonic.
TRENTON, March 22 A subcommittee of the Legislature said today that the housing for patients at state institutions had been allowed to deteriorate to a "deplorable condition"...

The Gallup Poll reported yesterday that Senator. Hubert H. Humphrey remains the top choice of rank-andfile Democrats for the 1976 Presidential nomination although he has not indicated his intention to enter the Democratic primaries.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 22 Public hearings on whether to license the manufacture of the world's first floating nuclear power plants will open here tomorrow.

As might be expected, the board chairman of the Carnegie Hall Society Inc., which today begins a two-month task of raising $6.5 million for the new Carnegie Hall National Endowment Fund, is a devoted lover of music.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The State Department has proposed to the Soviet Government that it exchange Sarkis O. Paskalian, who pleaded guilty last September to a charge of spying for Moscow, for an American intelligence agent now in Soviet custody, an American official confirmed today.

The stock market, generally unmoved by last week's rather glowing economic reports, remained little changed in neutral ground yesterday. Volume again was moderate and well below the pell-mell pace set in January and February.

WASHINGTON, March 22 The Government charged the General Motors Corporation today with monopoly control of crash replacement parts for its autos, a practice that is allegedly costly to the public and to independent repair shops.

Ralph Blane, who ended the sixth season of the "Lyrics and Lyricists" series at the 92d Street Y.M.-Y.W.H.A. on Sunday evening, proved to be the first lyricist to appear there who is basically a singer.

When California voters passed the highly publicized "Proposition 20" nearly four years ago, they had every right to think they were creating the first really effective coastal planning body in the nation. What they could not foresee was that at the first major opportunity, the oil industry would scorn that body and in doing so enjoy Department of the Interior backing.
Television is no longer a forbidden zone for the New York Cosmos.

It is 13 years since the accompanying analysis of women's magazines appeared in the book that is generally credited with having started the women's liberation movement. Since then, American women by the millions have questioned their own dearly held assumption and reassessed their lives. They have changed their attitudes, their priorities, their life styles, and even in some cases, their partners.

WASHINGTON, March 22 (UPI) Secretary of the Interior Thomas S. Kleppe has decided to bar waterfowl hunters from using lead shot, which may poison nearly 2 million ducks a, year, this fall in designated areas of the Atlantic Flyway, it was announced today.

LAKELAND, Fla., March 22 (AP) Jerry Martin's sacrifice fly in the ninth inning gave the Philadelphia Phillies a 1-0 victory today over the Detroit Tigers in the first exhibition baseball game of the delayed spring training season.

LONDON, March 22 Britain proposed a two-stage plan today to end the Rhodesian crisis, and offered to join other countries in making available financial aid to Rhodesia to insure an orderly transition to a multiracial society.

LOS ANGELES, March 22 (AP) Thirty-two persons were arrested and a policeman was shot today in raids that the police described as the dismantling of a drug ring that had supplied up to a quarter of the heroin on Los Angeles streets.

WASHINGTON, March 22 Sargent Shriver became today the fifth Democrat to abandon pursuit of the party's Presidential nomination, contending that his six-month campaign had been a "remarkable success" in the light of the handicaps he faced.

While Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways were lobbying in the Legislature for larger shares of betting revenues, the tracks were being financially "drained" by their parent corporations, the State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday.

Negotiations for a new transit workers' contract moved into high gear yesterday with the Transport Workers Union offering a detailed chart-and-slide presentation to show that its 34,000 members were underpaid.
KINSHASA, Zaire, March 22 The command post here of the Angolan nationalist faction that was backed by Zaire in the Angolan civil war is empty.

Marie DiStefano Miller, a 34-year-old sociologist from Hillsborough who has taught criminology on the college level, announced yesterday that she had received the Democratic Party's endorsement for sheriff of Somerset County.

WHITE PLAINS, March 22 The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, asked the Board of Legislators today to approve major modifications in a countywide solid-wastedisposal system described two years ago as among the most advanced in the nation.
Frank J. French, former president of the Allied Chemical Corporation's fibers division, died Sunday of leukemia in Farmington, Conn. He was 69 years old and lived in Pine Plains, N.Y.

Mayor Beame yesterday filed notice that the city would withdraw from the Social Security system two years from now if studies confirmed tentative estimates that withdrawing might save the city up to $200 million annually.

AMHERST, Mass. Few economists of any generation manage to achieve a reputation for greatness in the rarefied world of economic theory, where deep and difficult questions are pondered about how economic systems actually work.

BRUSSELS, March 22 (UPI) The Italian lira and the British pound held their own on European money markets today with an easing of speculative pressures that had buffeted foreign exchanges last week. The dollar was mixed.
MIDDLETOWN, R.I., March 22 Helen Elizabeth Curtin, former chief dietitian at Veterans Administration Hospitals in New York and Boston, died at a nursing home here Saturday.

Two men have gone into the publishing business to make sure that no one has to leave an Off Track Betting office emptyhanded. They are not going to supply sure winners but they will distribute a free magazine.

BOSTON, March 22 (UPI) David Rockefeller, chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has agreed to become an informal financial adviser to President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, The Boston Globe reported tonight.

The Lever Brothers Company, the United States subsidiary of Unilever, Ltd. of Britain and its partner, Unilever, N.V. of the Netherlands, had a net profit last year of $11.3 million, an increase of 9.7 percent from the $10.3 million earned in 1974.
Ethan Allen Inc., the furniture manufacturer, is betting that the public is ready to buy again and is putting up more than $1 million to implant its name in the consumer consciousness.

WASHINGTON, March 22 President Ford received last week former President Nixon's report on his recent trip to China and found it "very interesting and useful," the White House press secretary, Ron Nessen, said today.

Mayor Beame yesterday filed notice that the city would withdraw from the Social Security system two years from now if studies confirmed tentative estimates that withdrawing might save the city up to $200 million annually.

A majority of New Jerseyans interviewed in a poll by The New York Times support a state income tax and casino gambling in Atlantic City. Most believe that living in New Jersey is better than outsiders may think. They are pleased with their life style, proud of their beach resorts and satisfied with the environment, but they are wary of government officials, unhappy with the tax structure and worried about the economy.

While Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceways were lobbying in the Legislature for larger shares of betting revenues, the tracks were being financially "drained" by their parent corporations, the State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn is reported to be investigating whether $250,000 to $275,000 was paid to organized-crime figures to abduct the two young daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon from her home here last Friday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 22 The Argentine armed forces, now visibly preparing to overthrow the Government of President Isabel Martinez de Per n, plan to close congress, arrest many Peronist political and union leaders and impose martial law, according to military sources.

SPRING BONUS New Yorkers who have not recently visited the Frick Collection, one of the city's most splendidly housed art troves, as well as flower lovers who are mindful that the Conservatory of the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx is temporarily closed for reconstruction, can enjoy a double treat tomorrow through Sunday, when a large-scale assembly of orchids will adorn the museum at 1 East 70th Street.
National Airlines has decided to drop its "no frills" bargain fare to Florida May 1, and competing airlines that never liked the idea in the first place are following suit.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn is reported to be investigating whether $250,000 to $275,000 was paid to organized-crime figures to abduct the two young daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon from her home here last Friday.

A group of volunteer tutors sitting in the office of the principal of Public School 169 in Bayside, Queens, were talking intensively about their firstgrade pupils before they begin instruction: "I knew I wanted to help a child try to read well," one tutor said, "because if they can't read now, they may drop out of school later."
The Temporary Commission on City Finances urged yesterday that wages be frozen for Transit Authority workers and that the transit fare be held at its present rate until July 1, 1978.
Dollie Booth Hepburn, former acquisition and personnel director of the Columbia University Libraries, died Friday in New Paltz, N.Y. She was 85 years old.

LONDON, March 22 Britain proposed a two-stage plan today to end the Rhodesian crisis, and offered to join other countries in making available financial aid to Rhodesia to insure an orderly transition to a multiracial society.

The Southern Railway and 12 of 20 labor unions announced acceptance yesterday of labor conditions laid down by Transportation Secretary William T. Coleman last week for Southern's acquisition of a 460-mile line of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad through the Delmarva Peninsula.

Declaring that "in the eight years of '60 Minutes,' no single piece has caused more controversy" than "Syrian: Israel's Toughest Enemy," which was broadcast in February, 1975, Mike Wallace and the CBS News series returned to the subject of Syrian Jewry this last Sunday.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 Don Shula, head coach and part owner of the Miami Dolphins, gave Joe Kapp relatively low marks today as he rated quarterbacks from the witness stand in Kapp's antitrust suit against the National Football League.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Supreme Court upheld today ordinances that require municipal employees to live within a city's boundaries.

Drivers, clerks and mechanics of New Jersey's largest bus company, Transport of New Jersey, overrode their union leadership last night and voted, by a slim margin, to accept management's latest contract offer and end their two-week strike.

The Court of Appeals, in an unusually quick action, yesterday ordered oral arguments next week on an appeal brought by Patrick J. Cunningham, the Democratic state chairman, to reverse a lower court order requiring him to appear before a special grand jury investigating the sale of judgeships in the Bronx.
The diminishing number of people who work for the State Racing and Wagering Board are wondering who will be the next to go.
The Anaconda Sales Company, which raised its price for full sheet copper cathodes by 5 cents a pound on Saturday yesterday rescinded 2 scents of that increase and...
Esther Ann Redway Smith Wherry, a former fashion copywriter for John Wanamaker and Franklin Simon stores here, died Sunday in Middlebury, Vt., at the age of 87.
It seems that every other woman with a washing machine is dashing off to buy an Ultrasuede dress to toss into it.
MOSCOW, March 22 Soviet and American communications experts have successfully tested a new network of space satellites that will eventually replace the existing Washington-Moscow hot line.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, March 23 Supported by heavy artillery fire, right-wing Christian militiamen counterattacked yesterday in a daylong bid to recapture their hotel stronghold in downtown Beirut, and close-quarter fighting was still under way last night.
TEL AVIV, March 22 An 11-year-old Arab boy who was shot last Wednesday as Israeli soldiers sought to disperse demonstrators in the occupied West Bank died today in a Jerusalem hospital.

Kareem Abdul-Jabbar called Bob Rakel a racist. Earl Monroe threw a ball at Jake O'Donnell and Norm Van Lier hit Ken Sussman with a wad of chewing gum. Kevin Loughery collected six technical fouls in one game, Hubie Brown accosted Norm Drucker after a game and was fined $1,000, and Sunday night in Kansas City Ed Badger, the Chicago Bulls' assstant coach, heaved a chair toward a fan after having been ejected from the game.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 23 A young Japanese actor apparently tried to kill Yoshio Kodama, the rightist power broker involved in the Lockheed scandal here, by crashing a light plane into Mr. Kodama's home this morning.

TOKYO, Tuesday, March 23 A young Japanese actor apparently tried to kill Yoshio Kodama, the rightist power broker involved in the Lockheed scandal here, by crashing a light plane into Mr. Kodama's home this morning.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Tuesday, March 23 Supported by heavy artillery fire, right-wing Christian militiamen counterattacked yesterday in a daylong bid to recapture their hotel stronghold in downtown Beirut, and close-quarter fighting was still under way last night.

The Board of Higher Education passed a resolution last night designating the week of April 12 as the week its employees may be furloughed without pay, but it left open the possibility that continuing negotiations may avert such a furlough.

WASHINGTON, March 22 Sargent Shriver became today the fifth Democrat to abandon pursuit of the party's Presidential nomination, contending that his six-month campaign had been a "remarkable success" in the light of the handicaps he faced.

ALBANY, March 22 The State Court of Appeals today extended until May 31 the right of savings banks to offer so-called NOW checking accounts. Opponents of a measure that would give such banks full checking powers used the court's decision to force a delay of the measure in the Assembly and Senate.
WASHINGTON, March 22 The Federal Election Commission lost most of its authority today when Congress failed to meet a supreme Court deadline for reconstituting the agency to make it Constitutional.

Walter Jodock Kohler Jr., three-term Governor of Wisconsin, whose loss to William Proxmire in 1957 in the race to fill Joseph R. McCarthy's Senate seat shocked Republicans across the country, died on Sunday of a heart ailment at Sheboygan (Wis.) Hospital. He was 7l years old.

WNET/13 raised a record $685,512 in pledges from viewers during the 10-day national subscription campaign, "Festival '76," which ended Sunday night. The fund-raising event was built around 15 special programs acquired by the Public Broadcasting Service, most of them produced abroad, and classic movies from the Janus Films library recently licensed to public television.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., March 22 Representatives of Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization clashed in debate before the Security Council today as the Council began discussing anti-Israeli unrest in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.
WASHINGTON, March 22 Yields declined on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.
SAN FRANCISCO, March 22 Pressure has begun to build on Patricia Hearst to testify against her former associates and thus possibly obtain leniency from the Federal Government.

ALBANY, March 22 Judges on the state's highest court would be appointed by the Governor and voters would be able to decide in local referendums whether they wanted their Supreme Court judges to be elected or appointed under a package of proposed state constitutional amendments introduced today by a bipartisan Senate task force.

PHILADELPHIA, March 22 (AP) The Philadelphia Inquirer filed in Federal court today a $70,000 damage suit against Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and Police Commissioner Joseph O'Neill for permitting picketers to force a curtailment of the newspaper's operations on Saturday.
Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, a former world champion, captured the $8,000 first prize in the Louis D. Statham masters-plus tournament in Lone Pine, Calif., with a score of 5 1 .

From time to time of late there may have been a howl or two in the executive suites of companies, whose stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange as letters arrived from the exchange concernine listing fees.

DALLAS, March 22 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger warned Cuba again today that the United States would refuse to countenance the use of Cuban troops to bring about another Angola even against white minority regimes opposed by this country in Africa.
Prices moved higher in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

The New York Times Company said yesterday that it would hold its 1976 stockholders' meeting April 20 in Wilmington, N. C., where the company last year purchased The Wilmington Star-News, a daily newspaper. It will be the first time the annual meeting has been held outside New York City.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., March 23 Members of the technical staff of the Nuclear regulatory commission testified today that manufacturing the world's first floating nuclear power plants here, the first two of which have been proposed for operation off Atlantic City, would have no serious adverse environmental impacts on Jacksonkville.

Interest rates on corporate bonds have declined enough this year to raise a new concern for investors. The high-yielding bonds they bought in 1969, 1970 and 1971 may be called out from under them as corporations try to cut costs.
With the results of survey research being used increasingly in business, politics and government the time has come for some form of auditing that will give people faith in the numbers.
Horace D. Gilbert, a pioneer in industrial miniaturization, died Friday in Los Angeles. He was 65 years old and lived there and in Keene, N.H., and Vienna.
Ralph G. Caso was 60,000 feet above the ground as the aircraft shifted into supersonic speed. Far below him, the coasts of England and France resembled a page in a miniature Atlas.

Overwhelming rejection by the Roman Catholic laity in the United States of the 1968 papal ban on artificial birth control has led to drastic declines in religious devotion and annuaily costs the church nearly a billion dollars in income, according to a survey of Catholic attitudes released yesterday by the National Opinion Research Center.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has scheduled a public hearing in Mineola for tonight on a proposed "simplified" fare structure for Nassau County buses.
CORDOBA, Argentina, March 23 Argentina's left-wing guerrillas, once a terrorist middleclass elite, have emerged in recent months as a major force in the factories.
Food proved the main attraction for a big male eland yesterday at the Central Park Zoo when he was put in a large outdoor pen for the first time with a recently acquired female, 19-month old Ginny.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The House of Representatives rejected today a move to extend voting representation in Congress to the District of Columbia for the first time since the District was created in 1790.
LONDON, Wednesday, March 24 Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, the most famous British soldier of modern times, died early today, the Ministry of Defense announced. He was 88 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, March 23 (UPI) The Westinghouse Electric Corporation of Pittsburgh was accused today in a stockholder's class action suit of concealing the extent of the pretax losses in the years from 1954 through 1974 in its consumer appliance division.

The temporarily successful effort last week to prevent publication of The Philadelphia Inquirer was a serious blow against the First Amendment rights of every American. The incident provided warning of the way totalitarianism might come to this country if the defenders of freedom regardless of their political orientation relaxed their vigilance.

PORTSMOUTH, England, March 23 (AP) The French yacht Pen Duick VI, skippered by Eric Taberly, appeared a sure winner after crossing the finishing line first today in the Rio de Janeiro-to-Portsmouth Gold Tankard race. Pen Duick VI was thought to be about 1,000 miles ahead of her nearest rivals and was expected to win on handicap when the final placings are worked out after the slower boats arrive in about two weeks, race officials said.
Papers filed by the Arol Development Corporation in its effort to quash a subpoena have raised new questions about its leasing of the Bronx Terminal Market.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (Reuters) Senator William Proxmire today released the names of six more high-ranking military officers entertained by the Northrop Corporation contrary to Defense Department regulations.

On a cold January night, when Morris K. Udall was just one of many Democratic Presidential hopefuls, a group of West Siders, talking of peace marches and protest days gone by, gathered to start a grassroots Udall-for-President organization.
WASHINGTON, March 23 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals held today that national banks must comply with state laws before establishing remote computer hookups in supermarkets and elsewhere.

About 200 wine enthusiasts, wine makers and wine sellers gathered at the Four Seasons Restaurant here the other night for what most of them considered an extraordinary wine tasting and dinner.

Andy Messersmith, the Los Angeles Dodgers' star pitcher who became a free agent recently, may not find it easy to get a team to meet his terms. The Cincinnati Reds said yesterday they had rejected a $1.5 million deal offered by his agent. The Reds said the proposal included a bonus and a four-year, no-cut contract. It came from Herb Osmond, Messersmith's agent, in a phone call from Los Angeles.

Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington brought his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination back to New York City yesterday with renewed insistence that "the overriding issue" facing the voters in the state's April 6 primary election is jobs.

Braniff Airways has agreed to a record civil penalty of $300,000 resulting from failure to report an illegal $40,000 contribution to the 1972 reelection campaign of President Richard M. Nixon and from a $1 million scheme to hide ticket discounts, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced yesterday in Washington.

ALBANY, March. 23 Governor Carey warned today that the cuts the Legislature made last week in his budget requests for state agencies and departments were "unworkable and counterproductive" and could "make it impossible for us to do the job" of running the state.

TRENTON, March 23 An 84cent-an-hour wage offer over two years and fears of the possible loss of jobs and pensions were given today as read sons that members of the Amalgamated Transit Union rejected their leaders' recommendations last night and voted to accept Transport of New Jersey's latest contract proposals.

Checking accounts and savings deposits at the First Women's Bank of New York, organized last year to promote financial parity for women, have grown substantially in recent months, the bank's shareholders were told yesterday at its first annual meeting.

The Board of Higher Education will advise the Emergency Financial Board today that it is prepared to accept the bulk of the controversial Kibbee Plan for consolidating and restructuring the City University, sources in the board reported yesterday.

It was to be a simple paint job for the bathroom. But no sooner had Annie Baker and David Wolman picked up their brushes than it was decided that what the bathroom really deserved was a neon-bright four-walled mural, based on "Lord of the Rings' by John Tolkien, their favorite fantasy.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., March 23 A group of residents in the Island Trees School District said today that they intended to protest to the State Education Commissioner the removal of 11 book titles from the junior and senior high school libraries.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, proposed today that the Federal Government spend $412.8 billion next year, $18.6 billion more than President Ford recommended.

LOCARNO, Switzerland, March 23 (AP) Swiss and Italian police recovered today three Renaissance paintings that were stolen from the Ducal Palace Museum in Urbino, Italy, early last year in one of the largest art thefts in Italian history.
Dr. Carl A. L. Binger, a psychiatrist, died Monday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 86 years old.
Wallace E. Olson, president of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, said yesterday that corporate financial statements should include more explanations of the data they contain.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Senate passed a $6.4-billion foreign aid appropriation bill today for the 15 months of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30. The 52-31 vote sent the measure to a conference with the House, which approved a $5.4 billion total on March 8.

WASHINGTON, March 23-As it reads now, the Humphrey-Hawkins Full Employment Bill would convey to the President no authority to regulate prices and wages. PARIS, March 23 A West German warning to Italy that it had to act to stop the flight of capital if it expected further German financial aid, was behind a harsh economic program adopted by Italy last week a high European financial official reported today.
The campaign roadshow has arrived here, but so far it has meant little to the ordinary television viewer.

Federated Department Stores Inc., which includes Bloomingdale's and Abraham Straus in the metropolitan New York area, reported yesterday earnings increases of 33.8 percent for the fiscal fourth quarter and 32.3 percent for the year ended Jan. 31. The year-to-year gain was the company's largest in 20 years.
A nuclear plant near Oswego, N.Y., was shut down Monday because of a leak in a water cleanup system, similar to others found last Friday and last November.

The origins of the possessions of the Metropolitan Museum of Art have been fully catalogued, but until now the provenance of the visitors to the institution has gone unstudied.

Soviet experimenters have reported producing the first fusion reactions induced by converging electron beams on fuel pellets. The achievements adds one more candidate to the competing approaches for extraction of nuclear energy by fusing small atoms into bigger ones.
WASHINGTON, March 23 The Statue of Liberty is a hard act to follow.

ROME, March 23 A magistrate investigating the widening Lockheed scandal today issued two more warrants for the arrest of high-level employees of a company that allegedly accepted and rechanneled funds from the aircraft company to favor the sale of planes in Italy.

In hopes of making its own name as familiar as the name of its products, Matsushita Electric Industrial, Japan's largest manufacturer of consumer electric and electronic products, is preparing to initiate a three-year advertising, public relations and promotion campaign that will cost about $1 million in the first year.

WASHINGTON, March 23 President Ford signed into law today legislation prohibiting banks, retailers and others from discriminating on the basis of age, race, color, religion or national origin in the granting of credit.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Wednesday, March 24-Moslem militiamen, bolstered by strong help from Palestinian guerrillas, advanced yesterday into downtown sections here traditionally held by Christian Phalangists. Militiamen of the Phalangist Party were pushed out of the Holiday Inn, and fierce battles were fought around the Starco shopping complex and the unfinished Hilton Hotel.

Jerome Robbins's "N.Y. Export. Op. Jazz" was created for Italy's Spoleto Festival in 1958, and it was the perfect dance expression of its time. It was "West Side Story" without the West Side and without the story. Somehow it encapsulated the feel and manners of a dislocated generation gang warfare and gang-bangs, the rhythmic patterns of a new tribal society, young lovers totally lost in a flurry of apparent communication and solitary partings.

ROME There are hints that "homo boobus," H.L. Mencken's affectionate term for the political American, is at last starting to realize his country is plummeting down the power slide. The coming splash could be a dismal experience for the freedom whose second century he celebrates this year. Overseas one encounters more than hints.

WASHINGTON, March 23 In an eight-page letter to the World Bank protesting the bank's recent decision to grant a $33 million credit to the Government of Chile, Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin, has charged that the bank "succumbed to political pressure to shore up an inhuman right-wing dictatorship tottering on the edge of bankruptcy."

TRENTON, March 23 An 84 cent-an-hour wage offer over two years and fears of the possible loss of jobs and pensions were given today as reasons that members of the Amalgamated Transit Union rejected their leaders' recommendations last night and voted to accept Transport of New Jersey's latest contract proposals.

Improved productivity is emerging as an important issue in the current transit contract negotiations, in which the union is talking about higher pay and protection against inflation while the Transit Authority is stressing its economic limitations.

HONG KONG, March 23 The lengthy list of charges being made against Teng Hsiao-ping, China's senior Deputy Prime Minister, indicates that he apparently provoked the current conflict among Peking's leaders sometime last summer when he moved too forcefully and bluntly in promoting his own pragmatic policies.

Three Broadway musicals, "A Chorus Line," "Chicago" and "Pacific Overtures," captured the bulk of this year's Antoinette Perry (Tony) award nominations. "A Chorus Line" received 12, "Chicago" 11 and "Pacific Overtures" 10.

OXFORD, England A characteristic sight in the streets of English cities is the meter maid, in neat uniform, with yellow trim, calm, quiet, walking slowly, pencil and notebook in hand, on the lookout for cars illegally parked: a notoriously incorruptible figure, unpersuadable, authoritative and of uncertain age; a British institution; a bourgeois social service.

The Detroit Pistons have a play they call "No. 12." Eric Money, the playmaker, made good use of it, especially in the second half last night and the payoff was a much-needed 122-116 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden.

ST.PAUL, Minn., March 23 (AP) The office of Judge Miles Lord of United States District Court said today that a group of private health and accident insurance companies had agreed to accept a $12.5 million settlement from five drug companies accused of overcharging for some antibiotics.
Some 35 Jackson-for-President delegates face removal from the New York State ballot or shunting aside into an "uncommitted" listing, Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.

Students boycotted classes at Long Island City High School in Queens yesterday in support of their suspended principal, Dr. Howard L. Hurwitz. Dr. Hurwitz was suspended Monday by School Chancellor Irving Anker for refusing to readmit a student who, the principal said, had a record of serious misbehavior.

WASHINGTON, March 23 Representative Brock Adams, Democrat of Washington, who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, proposed today that the Federal Government spend $412.8 billion next year, $18.6 billion more than President Ford recommended.

As we all too often find out, "new" does not always mean "good" where food products are concerned. But for a change, this group of new or newly discovered cheeses, bacon, cakes and charcuterie are well worth the buying and eating.

KINGSTON, Jamaica Fourteen years after independence from Great Britain, Jamaican men have beam liberated from the tyranny of jacket and tie. The Kareeba, the styled, open-neck, over-the-pants shirt and matching trousers suit has become the universally accepted dress for formal occasions, work and leisure wear.

"I grew up in hairdressing," said Joseph Weir. "My mother was a hairdresser. She always told me, 'Joseph, if you're going to make it in hairdressing, you've got to make it in 20 years,' She meant that after you reach a certain age you may have the technical ability but you don't have the appeal for clients."

Overwhelming rejection by the Roman Catholic laity in the United States of the 1968 papal ban on artificial birth control has led to drastic declines in religious devotion and annually costs the church nearly a billion dollars in income, according to a survey of Catholic attitudes released yesterday by the National Opinion Research Center.
More than 400 people turned out at a benefit party for Joseph Monserrat, the Board of Education member who placed himself on leave until conflict-ofinterest charges against him are settled.

SAN DIEGO, March 23 (UPI) The San Diego County grand jury today amended a 58-count indictment against C. Arnholt Smith, charging him with tax evasion and grand theft in connection with the sale of the San Diego Padres.

WASHINGTON, March 23 (AP) The Ford Administration unveiled today legislation limiting bugging and wiretapping in intelligence investigations within the United States and said the measure had broad bipartisan support.

Twyla Tharp, the choreographer, meets "Dance in America," the public television series, tonight at 9, and the result is something of an artistic standoff. More than half of the hour (about 35 minutes) on WNET/13 is devoted to a history of popular dances in the 1930's and 40's. The rest concentrates exclusively on Miss Tharp's "Sue's Leg," a work that refers directly to those dances with wit, admiration and superb technique.

WASHINGTON, March 23 The Justice Department's civil rights division, after a fourmonth study of Federal records relating to the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has found no evidence of government complicity or of a tangible conspiracy in the black leader's death, according to department sources.
TRENTON, March 23 Negotiations continued today in an effort to avert a strike tomorrow of teachers at the eight state colleges, which enroll 82,000 students.
Hong Kong, the world's largest exporter of men's, women's and children's apparel, will have a showing of quality fashions tonight at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LEXINGTON, Ky., March 23 (UPI) The stallion Candy Spots, winner of $824,718 in his racing career, died over the weekend at W. B. Perry's Domino Stud. Candy Spots won the Preakness in 1963 and was third in the Kentucky Derby that year and second in the Belmont Stakes.

The most astonishing thing about Georg Buchner's "Woyzeck" is when it was written. Jimmy Carter's thumping victory in the North Carolina Democratic primary was another severe setback for Gov. George C. Wallace. In winning, Mr. Carter drew only a few more votes than Terry Sanford had polled in losing four years ago. But in the interval the Wallace vote was virtually cut in half.

When Glen Campbell sings his hit recordings one after the other, their thematic unity becomes evident. The protagonist in the "Cowboy" is typical. He decries a neon-and-tinsel world he knows to be false, but his ambition drives him on.

DALLAS, March 24 On Monday of this week, the gleaming DC-9 of the Secretary of State arrived at taxpayers' expense in this Texas Republican stronghold for two days of politicking on behalf of President Ford's campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 24 The number of Federal officials with the power to stamp Government documents "top secret," "secret" or "confidential" has declined by more than three-fourths over the last four years, according to an interagency committee responsible for reducing the volume of classified information within the executive branch.
OTTAWA, March 24 Canada and the United States have formally extended joint extradition procedures to curb airplane hijacking, terrorism and narcotics traffic.
WASHINGTON, March 24 In a landmark civil rights ruling, the Supreme Court decided today, 5 to 3, that blacks who were denied jobs in violation of the Civil Rights Act.

ATLANTA, March 24 Howard H. Callaway, the former Secretary of the Army who has stepped aside as President Ford's campaign manager pending an investigation of allegations that he used his influence in Government for private gain, said tonight that he had asked for a meeting with Mr. Ford to discuss his permanent withdrawal from the campaign.

SARASOTA, Fla., March 24 (AP) Cleon Jones, the former New York Met, and Bob Oliver, an ex-New York Yankee, hit home runs today to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 6-1 exhibition victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

JERUSALEM, March 24 (Reuters) An Arab boy was buried quietly in his home village near here early today, a week after he was shot by an Israeli soldier during a demonstration in the Israeli-occupied West Bank of the Jordan River.

PARIS, March 24 Le Monde, France's most serious daily newspaper, has started making news about itself. A book attacking the paper for persistent leftist bias and distortion has just appeared, and Le Monde (The World) replied with a front-page denunciation of the author, headed "Notice to Readers."
TRENTON, March 24 The 2,700 teachers in the eight state colleges were still on the job today, but the contract they agreed to last night faces an uncertain future.

A caretaker at the community house of the religious cult operated in Brooklyn by DeVernon LeGrand, a self-styled bishop, has sworn that he helped dispose of the bodies of two young sisters, members of the cult, by burning.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (UPI) Internal Revenue Service sources said today that the service was auditing the income tax returns of Senator Joseph M. Montoya, Democrat of New Mexico, who is head of a subcommittee that reviews the I.R.S. budget.

It was typical of the cynicism with which many Argentines view their country's politics that most people in Buenos Aires seemed more interested in a soccer telecast Tuesday night than in the ouster of President Isabel Martfnez de Peron by the armed forces. The script was familiar for this long-anticipated coup; the only unusual aspect was that it removed the first woman head of government in the history of the Western Hemisphere.

WASHINGTON, March 24 The Securities and Exchange Commission adopted a rule today that will force about 1,000 of the nation's biggest companies to compute and publish data showing how inflation is affecting their business. The action is seen as the first step toward an entirely new accounting system, one that breaks with the tradition of relying on historical costs.

MILWAUKEE, March 24 With scarcely a further word about his majority victory yes terday in the North Carolina primary, Jimmy Carter plunged today into Wisconsin back into the urban, industrial North, this time in a state where he said that he had "a good chance" to deal Representative Morris K. Udall a decisive blow.

WASHINGTON, March 24 A bipartisan group of senior senators agreed today that the stringent Federal coal mine safety law they helped to write six years ago had failed to protect adequately the lives of miners or to impress the Department of Interior and many mine owners with the necessity of compliance.

Imports of crude oil and petroleum products fell sharply last week from the record level of the preceding week, according to figures issued yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.
LUSAKA, Zambia, March 24 (Reuters) Leaders of four African countries held talks here today on white minorityruled Rhodesia.
LONDON, March 24 (AP) Britain will provide a full military funeral April 1 for Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Alamein.

John G. Heimann, the New York State Superintendent of Banks, announced last night that he would introduce legislation shortly to allow banks to expand across state lines. Mr. Heimann, who is New York's top banking official, predicted that nationwide banking would come about eventually as individual states make reciprocal arrangements pemitting banks to cross state fines.

With the continuation of a high pace of consumer sales, the nation's chain stores reported a gain of 13.7 percent in sales volume in February, according to Chain Store Age magazine in a compilation of results of 36 chain organizations.

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with Foreign Minister Ihsal S. Caglayangil of Turkey and said progress was made toward restoring United States access to military and intelligence facilities that the Turks shut last summer.

CORDOBA, Argentina, March 24 A few hours before the military coup that toppled President Isabel Martinez de Peron's Government, a group of businessmen gathered as usual for drinks at the bar of the Hotel Crillon.

WASHINGTON, March 24 Senator Philip A. Hart, who has been trying for years to break up the big oil companies, asserted today that arguments by the Exxon Corporation in two state tax cases showed the company's production, transportation, refining and marketing divisions "can stand on their own."

WASHINGTON, March 24 (AP) The number of race tracks may be reduced in future years, but not because of interstate offtrack wagering, Paul Screvane, head of New York City's Offtrack Bebting Corporation, told the House Transportation and Commerce Subcommittee today.

WASHINGTON, March 24 President Ford called today for a Government-supported campaign to vaccinate the entire United States population against a new influenza virus to forestall possible epidemics next fall and winter.

WASHINGTON, March 24 The Senate overwhelmingly approved tonight a compromise bill to reconstitute the Federal Election Commission and to make a wide variety of changes in the controversial campaign law. The vote was 55 to 28.

A decade-long effort to have laboratory tests done before rather than after hospital admission for patients scheduled to undergo elective surgery has shortened hospital stays and checked costs, the Blue Cross Association announced yesterday.
Christian C. Borth, an automotive historian, died Monday evening in Detroit of complications following influenza. He was 80 years old and lived in Fenton, Mich.

LOS ANGELES, March 24 Ronald Reagan will attempt in a television address next week to "redefine the contest" with President Ford for the Republican Presidential nomination, Mr. Reagan's strategists said today.

Denis Potvin has spent three seasons with the New York Islanders. He won the Calder Trophy for the league's rookie of the year in his first season and led the Islanders in points and assists in his first two seasons.

With less than a week to go before the expiration of the transit workers' contract, the Transit Authority was told by the state yesterday that it could not expect any additional money and that it must hold all expenditures to present levels.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 24 Twelve days late and one intracity feud later, New York's professional baseball teams began their Southern season tonight. The Yankees won, 7.1, but the Mets didn't go away mad.

To stem further housing decay here and rehabilitate buildings already deterio rated, the New York Urban Coalition proposed yesterday the creation of two new "public benefit corporations" a Consumer Housing Corporation and a Housing Trust Fund.

A majority of New Jersey residents polled by The New York Times are dissatisfied with the number of cultural activities in the state, enthusiastic about the entertainment, recreation and the schools, and convinced that medical care and shopping are as good in their areas as in New York City.

ST. ANTHONY, Canada, March 24 (UPI) The Greenpeace Foundation ended a campaign protesting Canada's annual seal hunt today after seals and sealing fleets moved beyond the rangs of the environmental group's aircraft.
The stock market advanced broadly yesterday in increased trading with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks, up 13.78 at l,009.21, closing at its best level in three years.

Congress set a poor precedent when it let the railway unions dictate featherbedding clauses in the law reorganizing the bankrupt Northeast railroads. The result is that one key element in the reorganization plan is already being destroyed.

It is sure to cause controversy, but that's nothing new to Muhammad Ali. The world heavyweight champion was a narrow choice over Joe Louis as the best fighter in the "Greatest Athletes of All Time" poll. Ali won his place in a poll of 500 sports editors, writers and broadcasters conducted recently by Cutty Sark. Louis, a close second, was followed by Jack Dempsey, Sugar Ray Robinson and Jack Johnson.

PROVIDENCE, R.L, March 24 If you can't buy swimming tickets for the Olympic Games in Montreal next July, you may do almost as well at the 53d annual National Collegiate championships here at Brown University's Smith Swimming Center.

BUFFALO, March 24 (AP) Jim Lorentz, Danny Gare and Brian Spencer scored within 2 minutes 12 seconds to spark a five-goal third period that gave the Buffalo Sabres a 7-3 National Hockey League victory over the New York Rangers tonight. The loss eliminated the Rangers from playoff contention for the first time since 1966.

Marian Hahn made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall in 1974 and was recognized as a young pianist of promise. She returned to the hall Tuesday night to give us a progress report with a recital that indicated her promise is being fulfilled. Her technique has been honed to a gleaming edge and her good schooling (she now coaches with Leon Fleisher) showed in interpretations of considerable maturity.

JERUSALEM, March 25 A 34-year-old Arab from Hebron who was severely beaten by Israeli soldiers during a demonstration there yesterday has died of his injuries in Hadassah Hospital here, according to a communique tonight by the army spokesman's office.

Few life-signs could be more encouraging for New Yorkers than the recent spurt of new restaurants in Little Italy. In the last year, five new eating places have opened there, and a sixth, long a favorite haunt of Italian-food buffs, has reopened after a five-year absence. Sponsored by the Little Italy Restoration Association, and backed in part by the Small Business Administration, this renaissance is an attempt to breathe life back into the area.
Matthew Guinan, president of the Transport Workers Union, said yesterday that he might be willing to agree to defer part of a raise for his 34,000 members if they got some money now.

Louis Arpels, one of the founders of Van Cleef Arpels, international jewelers, died at his home near Paris on Saturday. He was 89 years old.

Wilson has given an undergraduate course on civil liberties for nearly two decades at Princeton University, occasionally under the scrutiny of an agent for the Federal Bureau of Investigation. WASHINGTON, March 25 The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $1.1 billion, up 6 percent from the year-earlier $1.04 billion. Retail store sales totaled $12.5 billion, up 14 percent from $10.1 billion.

Many blind children in the 8-12 age group look forward each year to this anthology of children's literature from the Braille Institute of America. Through donations from civic groups and individuals the book is provided as an outright gift to any legally blind child. It may be the only book many actually own.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Congressional leaders in health affairs expressed support today for the Ford Administration's plan to vaccinate all Americans against the new flu virus, but some suggested that the effort also include immunization against polio, measles and other disease for those in need.
The problems of older American cities, which played a role in the political campaigns following the urban riots of the mid-1960's, have been muted in this year's Presidential campaign.

MOUNT ARLINGTON, N. J., March 31 Within hours after winning a State Supreme Court victory in their six-month struggle to establish their daughter's right to die "with grace and dignity," the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan said here this afternoon that they would waste no time in taking the steps that could lead to the removal of their comatose daughter's respirator.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 Joe Kapp is asking for $12 million in damages, it was revealed in court today as attorneys continued their closing arguments in his antitrust suit against the National Football League.
As the credit markets drifted yesterday toward lower prices and higher interest rates, Federal funds traded as high as 6 percent and the Federal Reserve twice injected temporary re

LOS ANGELES, March 31 Ronald Reagan made a broad appeal for popular support tonight in a 30-minute paid network television speech that appeared designed to attract fresh financial backing from Democrats and independents, as well as Republicans.
PHILADELPHIA, March 31 Walter M. Phillips Jr., the state special presecutor for Philadelphia, was dismissed today by Robert P. Kane, the Pennsylvania Attorney General.
BONN, March 31 Conservative West German politicians tore up posters by a Socialist artist last night, forcing a show of his work to close here today.

APPLETON, Wis., March 31 Jimmy Carter fired a rhetorical volley of warning shots across the bow of the "Stop Carter" movement that Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota is reported to be encouraging in the Wisconsin primary.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to legalize artists' living-and-working lofts in the area of lower Manhattan known as NoHo. Such arrangements have been permitted since 1970 in the larger SoHo district.

BONN, March 31 (AP) President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt today cautioned the Soviet Union to stay out of the civil war in Lebanon. But he said he had "no objections" to peace initiatives by the United States and other countries.

Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona said yesterday he was "no stalking horse" for Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and did not need his help in the Wisconsin and New York Presidential primary elections April 6.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Solicitor General Robert H. Bork, arguing on behalf of the Government, urged the Supreme Court today to overrule its 1972 decision that struck down capital punishment as then practiced in America and to hold that the death penalty is constitutional.

Thanks to a new Federal rent-subsidy program, Christopher and Desiree Gosein can now shop around for an apartment for themselves and their two small children, rather than continue to live with Mrs. Gosein's parents in four crowded rooms.

When he was asked about Cuba the other day on a Wisconsin television program, Representative Morris K. Udall gave a cautiously constructed, careful answer with expressions of disapproval of Cuban intervention in Africa.

BUENOS AIRES, March 28 The day after the military coup, the army major who was placed in charge of government public relations in C rdoba, Argentina's second largest city, gathered the local newspaper editors and imparted instructions for temporary press censorship.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 31 The proposed new penicillin manufacturing standards published by the Food and Drug Administration last month in the Federal Register are considered a factor in a pullout from the state of at least some of the facilities of E.R. Squibb Sons, one of the nation's largest drug companies and the biggest manufacturer of intravenous penicillin.

ALBANY, March 31 Governor Carey's office said today that it hoped that a newly reconstituted state lottery would begin in eight weeks, with tight controls designed to attract the patrons driven away when it was shut down last year amid revelations of lax management.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 31 Defying an injunction, municipal craft workers here went on strike today in an attempt to reverse salary reductions that had been ordered Monday by the city's Board of Supervisors.

The public agencies involved in the contract negotiations are the New York City Transit Authority and its subsidiary the Manhattan and Bronx Surface Transit Operating Authority. They operate the city's subways and publicly owned bus lines. Both are under the direction of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency.

SAN DIEGO, April 1 (UPI)Some 1,700 technicians and newswriters went on strike against the NBC television network at one minute after midnight this morning, turning down an appeal from Federal mediators for a one-month extension.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 31 (UPI) Neither Ronald Reagan nor Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will qualify a statewide slate of at-large Presidential delegates for Ohio's June 8 primary, Secretary of State Ted W. Brown said today.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 Patricia Hearst will testify that she was a prisoner of the selfstyled Symbionese Liberation Army and a "captive of" William and Emily Harris, according to her lawyers, when she sprayed bullets at a sporting goods store to help to rescue the Harrises, who were about to be seized as shoplifting suspects.

WASHINGTON, March 31 Despite new warnings of a Presidential veto, the Senate approved today a bill repealing the Hatch Act's 37-year-old ban against partisan political activities by Federal civilian workers.
