Contending that the Kibbee proposal for restructuring the City University would have its greatest impact on members of minority groups and the poor, the three minority representatives on the Board of Higher Education offered an alternative yesterday that they said would allow all five colleges threatened with closing or reduction of services to maintain their present status.

MOHEGAN LAKE, N.Y., March 31 The owners of an adult home in Westchester County have been charged by Assemblyman Andrew J. Stein of Manhattan with victimizing the couple who operate the home in an effort to increase real estate profits.
WASHINGTON I have a new scrap of evidence to contribute to the renewed controversy over the Hiss case. But first I would like to explain how I came across it.

Steve Busby, ace of the Kansas City pitching staff, has been placed on the 21day disabled list and will miss the opening day of the season. Busby had an 18-12 won-lost record before he was sidelined with shoulder problems last year. He has been running behind in his conditioning this spring, chiefly because of the shortened training period and has not pitched in an exhibition game.
As negotiators raced to head off a transit strike threatened for today, the Transit Authority obtained an injunction in State Supreme Court barring an illegal walkout by 32,000 workers.

The American Stock Exchange issued yesterday its latest report on changes in stock ownership by officers, directors and leading stockholders of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make a list available yesterday.

A 39-year-old woman was killed and six men were wounded last night when two suspected members of a neighborhood youth gang walked into a crowded Chinatown restaurant and opened fire.
A stockholder lawsuit against the Eastman Kodak Company over a resolution dealing with the Arab boycott of Israel has been dismissed by agreement among the parties, Kodak announced yesterday.

CLEARWATER, Fla., March 31 The harassed New York Mets stretched their twin losing streaks to eight straight today: they did not sign Tom Seaver again and they also did not win a ball game again.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The Treasury auctioned oneyear bills today at an average yield of 5,781 percent.

SYDNEY, Australia, March 31 Vice President Rockefeller said here tonight that the United States would stand by Australia and all Pacific nations to which it was "bound by treaty, by mutuai self-Interest, by duty and by honor."

MADISON, Wis., March 31 Madison, which attracted national attention for its militant demonstrations in the student protests of the 1960's, has become the focal point of the first organized heckling of the 1976 Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, March 31 (AP) Without new postal subsidies, the cost of mailing a letter could increase to 34 cents by 1984, the General Accountine Office said today.

ALBANY, March 31 Incensed Republicans in the majority in the Senate sought unsuccessfully tonight to override Governor Carey's surprise veto last, night of the education-assistance formula in the budget. Democrats in the minority united to defeat the attempt.
WASHINGTON, March 31 President Ford pledged tonight that he would "never do or say anything to weaken" the Republican Party and said that all candidates for President should make the same promise.

ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, March 31 Teamster locals all over the country began preparing tonight to set up picket lines at trucking companies as negotiators here continued to try to reach a last-minute contract settlement.
PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI) Chris Evert and Evonne Goolagong advanced to the quarterfinals of a $75,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today with straight-set triumphs.
The multimillion dollar judgment and fine levied against Frank Lloyd and his Marlborough art galleries for their handling of hundreds of Mark Rothko paintings has been increased by $540,000.

TRENTON, March 31 The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the mechanical respirator that was keeping Karen Anne Quinlan alive might be disconnected if her attending physicians and a panel of hospital officials agreed that there was "no reasonable possibility" that she would recover.

Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the surgeon who is under investigation in connection with the possible murder of nine or more patients with curare at an Oradell, N. J., hospital a decade ago, agreed yesterday to refrain temporarily from operating at Christ Hospital in Jersey City.

PEKING, March 31 (Reuters) A powerful new voice, emerged today in a growing campaign against Deputy Prime Minister Teng Hsiao-ping, branded as a "capitalist-roader."

A burglar who broke into Jimmy Carter's headquarters on Fifth Avenue Monday night stole $20 worth of stamps and some political documents that the former Georgia Governor's aides said were of little importance.
TEL AVIV, March 31 Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin charged today that the rioting that cost the lives of six Israeli Arabs yesterday had been incited by the predominantly Arab Israeli Communist Party.

CHIREDZI, Rhodesia, March 26 It was a Friday at the Planters Inn in this sugar cane area 300 miles south of Salisbury, and as the night wore on and tongues thickened with drink, the contradictions of Rhodesian life swirled madly.

ARKADELPHIA, Ark, People here tighten their sunbelts, dodge tornadoes, witness ruefully the decline of George Wallace and look hopefully toward the likes of Jimmy Carter and California Gov. Jerry Brown.
MILLINGTON, March 31 The Millington School was transformed into a mock colonial village today as the 342 pupils in kindergarten to the fourth grade acted out American's life style of 200 years ago.
Stock prices snapped back yesterday after two days of decline as trading this week continued to lag at the slowest pace of 1976.
ALBANY, March 31 With cheers of self-congratulation, the State Assembly tonight overrode Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill to restore millions in funds cut from the city's public schools.

GAITHERSBURG, Md., March 31 The Juilliard String Quartet played today in a hall that the second violinist at least thought was as bad as any they had ever played in, and to an audience that did not applaud. The quartet seemed to be having a fine time.

Richard H. Mandel of 10 East 70th Street, who retired in 1968 from the All-State Welding Alloys Company, White Plains, which he founded in 1946, died Tuesday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 70 years old.

Charles W. Robinson, a former businessman, was nominated by President Ford yesterday to be Deputy Secretary of State, the No. 2 position in the department. He would succeed Robert S. Ingersoll, former chairman of the Borg-Warner Corporation, and Ambassador to Japan, who has resigned.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 31 Outside, the stars twinkled in a still and velvet sky. Inside, the twinkling came from 12 crystal chandeliers and 8 crystal sconces, casting a diffused glow on the green and white shirred fabric walls, the black and white murals depicting opera houses around the world, and the grass green carpet underfoot.

About 7,200 families were terminated from city day-care programs yesterday, leaving many uncertain on where to turn for help and many fearful they would be forced to quit their jobs and apply for or return to welfare.
The team with the least international experience in the 1976 Bermuda Bowl next month will be Hong Kong, which won the right to compete by capturing the Far East title in Bangkok last November.

WASHINGTON, March 31 King Hussein of Jordan reportedly told members of Congress today that probably only Syrian military invervention could restore order in Lebanon, but that the threat of Israeli retaliation had so far blocked such a move.

ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., March 31 (AP) Volkswagen of America said today that it was recalling 138,000 Rabbit and Sirocco models because of possible malfunction in their emission-control systems. Included in the voluntary recall are 18,000 1976 models and 120,000 1975 models.

A leading black political scientist has advised the Democratic National Committee that it would be acceptable to softpedal the racial issue this year as long as the party's Presidential candidates deal "firmly and unequivocally" with issues that affect blacks.
COLUMBIA, S.C., March 31 The South Carolina Democratice convention voted late tonight to keep 13 of the state's 31 delegates to the national convention uncommitted as to a Presidential candidate.

ALBANY, March 31 A special state commission that has spent the last year studying the financial collapse of the Urban Development Corporation recommended major changes today in the way the state borrows money and manages its debt.

Bloomingdale's department store in Stamford. Conn., will give 10 percent of Saturday's gross receipts to help save the financially troubled American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford.

Two hundred police officers, who were laid off during New York's fiscal crisis last June were rehired by the city yesterday, but returning to work, they expressed uncertainty about their future. If there are more layoffs, they would be the first to go.

PHILADELPHIA, March 31 (UPI) A drive to unseat Mayor Rizzo through recall was officially announced today by a group that called the Mayor a "tyrant."

MOUNT, ARLINGTON, N.J., March 31 Within hours after winning a State Supreme Court victory in their six-month struggle to establish their daughter's right to die "with grace and dignity," the parents of Karen Anne Quinlan said here this afternoon that they could waste no time in taking the steps that could lead to the. removal of their comatose daughter's respirator.

BOSTON, March 31 At least this much is clear by now: Jimmy Carter is the most Interesting new political phenomenon this country has seen in a long time. His appeal crosses some of the old lines of party and ideology. He has coolly withstood the worst that critics could throw at him, and polls show his national support deepening.

An investigation of possible fraud in the sale of New York City securities, now under way by the Securities and Exchange Commission, has been broadened to include $1.6 billion of the city's notes that were part of a swap offer of the Municipal Assistance Corporation last year, sources close to the Government investigation disclosed yesterday.

RANGOON, Burma. March 31 (Agence France-Presse) The Communist guerrilla movement in Burma's Shan State has taken on a "new dimension" since the end of the Vietnam War, the semiofficial Working People's 'Daily reported.

Joe Pass is one of the most fascinating of today's guitarists in what is turning out to be a golden age for the jazz guitar. The period is notable for its range and diversity of styles, as opposed to the great guitar greening in the postWorld War II decade, when a multitude of guitarists appeared, all sounding like offspring of Charlie Christian.

ALBANY, March 31 Incensed Republicans in the majority in the Senate sought unsuccess- fully tonight to override Governor Carey's surprise veto last night of the education-assistance formula in the budget. Democrats in the minority united to defeat the attempt.

CLEVELAND, March 31 (AP) Tim Moore of Cincinnati captured the three-meter springboard championship and Cynthia McInvale of Dallas took the one-meter springboard in the opening events of the national Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships tonight.
WASHINGTON, March 31 (UPI) The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that requests for special charter flight treatment by Mr. Callaway were "regrettable" but not illegal.

LOS ANGELES, March 31 (AP) Ronald Reagan said tonight that he did not want to live "in a world where the Soviet Union is No, l," and quoted Henry A. Kissinger as saying that his job as Secretary of State was to negotiate for an acceptable second-place position.
ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., Thursday, April 1 Teamsters struck trucking companies last midnight, leaving their jobs first in the East as negotiators here failed to reach agreement on a new contract.
Edward John Going 2d, who retired as a vice president of SSC Inc., advertising agency, in 1973, died of cancer Monday evening in Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Stamford.

WASHINGTON, March 31 King Hussein of Jordan reportedly told members of Congress today that probably only Syrian military invention could restore order in Lebanon, but that the threat of Israeli retaliation had blocked such a move.

Grandmasters Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania and Aleksandr Matanovic of Yugoslavia tied for first place in the European Zonal C tournament in Vratza, Bulgaria, and thus qualified for the Interzonal tournaments to select world championship contenders. The interzonals will be held in June in Switzerland and the Philippines.
The Collins Aikman Corporation, a large textile manufacturer, announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Mastercraft Corporation, a privately owned manufacturer of upholstery fabrics.

BALTIMORE, March 31 Thomas Pasatieri, about 30 years old, already has composed 12 operas, the last of which had its premiere last night at the Lyric Theater. It was named "Ines de Castro" and was presented under the auspices of the Baltimore Opera Company.
ST. PETERSBURG BEACH, Fla., March 31 A Nebraska cancer specialist is planning to test daily doses of an estrogen hormone as a means of preventing breast cancer in women.
SINGAPORE, March 31 (UPI) Britain officially completed its military withdrawal from Singapore at sundown today, ending 157 years of service on the strategic island.
ALBANY, March 31 With cheers of self-congratulation, the State Assembly tonight overrode Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill to restore millions in funds cut from the city's public schools.
Irregularities in options trading have been uncovered by the American Stock Exchange, the Amex disclosed yesterday.
BONN, March 31 West Germany has abandoned a plan to build a $600 million nuclear power plant in the Soviet Union in a major political setback to West German-Soviet relations.

An attorney for the W.T. Grant Company, which concluded the going out-of-business sales of its remaining stores, Saturday, told a Federal judge yesterday that 10 store managers and four field and area supervisors of Grant were involved in a scheme to prolong some store closing sales and pocket the proceeds.

WASHINGTON, March 31 The House decisively defeated (today a proposal to continue the Federal Election Commission's power to issue advisory opinions on campaign issues without Congressional interference.

The Rohm Haas Company, a large plastics manufacturer, said yesterday that it had made "improper payments" overseas, totaling $750,200 from 1971 through 1975. The company said the payments, which were made in nine countries, had been stopped.
One good game doesn't a season make, but the Rangers' exciting and well-played 3-1 triumph over the Islanders last night at Madison Square Garden should help soothe a lot of hurt feelings.

Francis A. Kettaneh, founder and a partner in F. A. Kettaneh of Beirut, Lebanon, a distributor of American and European products, died Tuesday in his home at 888 Park Avenue. He was 79 years old and lived also in Cuddebackville. N.Y.

ALBANY, March 31 A special state commission that has spent the last year studying the financial collapse of the Urban Development Corporation recommended major changes today in the way the state borrows money and manages its debt.

INDIANAPOLIS, March 31 (UPI) Billy Knight outscored Julius Erving, 32-23, tonight to lead the Indiana Pacers to the fifth and final playoff spot in the American Basketball Association with a 116106 victory over the New York Nets.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., April 1 Into Jefferson City they rolled, bus after yellow bus, convoys from all over the mid-Missouri countryside heading toward the brilliantly hued red-white-and-blue steam locomotive with the words "American Freedom Train" emblazoned an the cars it pulled.
Senator Henry M. Jackson stepped up yesterday his effort to win more black support in next Tuesday's Democratic Presidential primary.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The House and Senate budget committees both finished work today on their budget targets and both decided to recommend to Congress total spending of somewhat more than $413 billion for the fiscal year 1977, beginning next Oct. 1.
Copper and silver prices rose sharply in active buying in the London market when traders rushed to rid themselves of British pounds.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 1 (AP) Gay Brewer, wielding a new putter in competition for the first time, eagled two of his last four holes today for a five-under-par 66 that tied Jimmy Wiechers for the first-round lead in the $230,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

Julius Schachter, concertmaster for the National Broadcasting Company orchestras from 1950 to 1966 and a violinist in television, radio and recordings, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home, 166 East 35th Street. He was 67 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 1 Evidence that a treatment called photocoagulation reduces the risk of blindness in some diabetes patients was made public today by the National Institutes of Health.
ALBANY April 1 The State Capitol yesterday was a world turned upside down.

ALBANY, April 1 In a move that infuriated lawmakers and their fiscal aides, Governor Carey began the state's new fiscal year today by refusing to go along with the precise job and expenditure cuts that the Legislature had directed him to make when it passed the budget two weeks ago.

JERUSALEM, April 1 (UPI) Two of the most influential Arab moderates have resisted intensive Israeli pressure to get them to run for re-election as mayor in municipal elections in the occupied West Bank, Israeli military government sources said today.
UNIONDALE, L.I., April 1 The New York Islanders and the Atlanta Flames played tonight to what by now seems the inevitable when these teams meet a tie.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, greeted by politicians and the press with the attention customarily accorded an active Presidential candidate, which he insists he is not, described a "Marshall Plan for the Cities" yesterday to a roomful of mayors and other officials.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Attorney General Edward H. Levi announced today that he had assigned a panel of Justice Department lawyers to review the Federal Bureau of Investigation's domestic counterintelligence program and, under certain circumstances, to notify its victims of actions taken against them.

BOSTON, April 1 The prevailing impression one is left with of Roger Session's massive opera "Montezuma," which received its American premiere at the Orpheum Theater here last night, is of high-minded seriousness.

ALBANY, April 1 The Senate Finance Committee, as expected, voted today to recommend against confirmation of Herman Schwartz, Governor Carey's nominee to head the Commission of Correction. The full Senate is expected to vote next Thursday. No gubernatorial nominee in memory here has been denied confirmation.

ALBANY, April 1 The Assembly Ways and Means Committee inroduced a bill today to restore most of the money requested in Governor Carey's budget to expand the staff of the office of the special prosecutor for nursing homes.
BUENOS AIRES, April 1 (UPI) Assassins armed with machine guns today shot and killed a high-ranking federal police official and his bodyguard, defying the new military junta's crackdown on terrorists.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Army said today it would close Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Totten in Queens as an economy measure eliminating 604 civilian and 410 military jobs.

Experts from all parts of North America, plus a few from farther afield, are gathering here today, preparing to play in the Cavendish Club's second annual invitational charity Calcutta tournament, aiding the Children's Cancer Fund.

LONG BEACH, Calif., April 1 (UPI) Tim Shaw, the world record-holder in the 400-meter freestyle, failed to qualify this afternoon for the evening final of the event at the Amateur Athletic Union indoor swimming championships. He also failed in the 200-meter backstroke trials.
TRENTON, April 1 Governor Byrne turned 52 years old today and the State Assembly honored him seriously and in jest.
MANILA, April 1 Former President Diosdado Macapagal today denounced the martial law Government of the Philippines as a lawless dictatorship and then sought asylum in the United States Embassy.

WINDSOR, England, April 1 (AP) Britain laid aside economic and social concerns today and mustered traditional pageantry to bid farewell to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery, the cocky little commander who turned gloom to glory in World War II. Field marshals and guardsmen, dressed in scarlet, gold and black, marched in solemn procession at Windsor Castle for Lord Montgomery's funeral. Lord Montogmery died a week ago at the age of 88.
The National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday that it was "concerned" about a possible repetition of the "catastrophic engine failure" that destroyed a DC-10 jumbo jet here last fail.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 1 The first thing Herb Cauthers, the track superintendent, did when he arrived at rainsoaked Monticello Raceway early today was to ask one of his staff to get the grader "with the rubber blade" out of the garage and have it ready for use.
The stock market gave ground yesterday after one of its worries the possibility of a nationwide trucking strike became an actuality.
In the world of skateboarding, the kids who specialize in daredevil descents of steep roads, highway bridge underpasses or just about any slanted stretch of concrete are known as "road rash riders."

The Good Humor Corporation has pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to 50 counts of a 244count indictment charging the company and two officers with falsifying records to cover high counts of coliform bacteria in Good Humor products.
The Atlantic Richfield Company announced yesterday the successful completion of its offer to purchase 6 million common shares of the Anaconda Company. The oil company's...
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Apr. 1 Leonard Garment, the United States member of the Human Rights Commission today attacked the handling of rights issues in the United...

The unanimous decision of the New Jersey Supreme Court in the Karen Quinlan case unless it is overruled by the United States Supreme Court could begin an entirely new era in the complex border area between medicine and the law. The importance of this boundary has grown with the advancing capabilities of medical science, which now can sometimes extend metabolism beyond the limits of conscious, productive or meaningful life.

The Good Humor Corporation has pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn to 50 counts of a 244count indictment charging the company and two officers with falsifying records to cover high counts of coliform bacteria in Good Humor products.
WASHINGTON, April 1 "Robin Hood was right," says the sign in the South Bronx Congressional office of Representative Herman S. Badillo. It is a display of...
DEER PARK, L.I., April 1 Long Island's largest trucking concern, Pinter Brothers, was closed today by a strike of its 110 drivers.

After all the speeches on national and international issues, after days of dawn-tomidnight campaigning by the Presidential hopefuls, the convention delegate races in next Tuesday's New York primary, as often as not, will turn on the success a delegate has in getting his friends out to vote for him.
Investor concern over the nationwide trucking strike yesterday weakened prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market.

Paul Strand, one of the most influential practitioners of 20thcentury photography, whose work in both still and motion pictures has gained increasing critical acclaim, died Wednesday at his home in Oregeval, a French village west of Paris. He was 85 years old.

Buying off overpowerful municipal unions with money the city did not have was a major element in New York's fiscal decline last year to the edge of bankruptcy. Now, under threat of a subway and bus strike, the Transit Authority has sewn the city into a new pay pattern that imperils its climb back toward fiscal health.

Why was Senator Henry Jackson's visit to Congregation Sons of Israel in Bensonhurst on Wednesday night more exciting than the hundreds of other visits he has paid to Jewish houses of worship in other parts of the country since his campaign for the Presidency began?

MILWAUKEE, April 1 Jimmy Carter has begun to attract scattered liberal and labor support to his nonideological Presidential candidacy in Wisconsin, a state where the Democrat left has held sway for more than a decade.

ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 1 Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr. pressed both sides in the trucking strike today to compromise and reach an agreement, in the hope of avoiding a court injunction to end the walkout that began last midnight.

ATLANTIC CITY, April 1 Exactly 2.8 miles seaward of Little Egg Inlet just north of here, a rusty orange and white tripod tower festooned with instruments rises 30 feet out of the ocean, marking the spot where Public Service Electric and Gas Company would like to place the world's first floating nuclear power plant.
The State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that the Democratic chairman, Patrick J. Cunningham, must testify before a special grand jury investigating political corruption in the Bronx.
NEW HAVEN, Conn. On March 29, 1969, Ronald L. Ridenhour asked publicly for an inquiry into the events that he believed had taken place at My Lai, South Vietnam, a year before.

Southern California, the source of countless outdoor cults, is now peddling one tied to asphalt and concrete, and the New York metropolitan area, much of which lies under the two substances, is buying.

Grocery prices in the New York-Northeastern New Jersey area, adjusted for normal sea sonal variation, declined by 1.3 percent in February, the largest month-by-month decline since July 1974, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

When Madison Fund Inc. announced at its annual meeting in Dallas last week that the future annual distributions would amount to "at least" 6 percent of asset value, averaged over the previous two calendar years, the closed-end investment company was copying a system that the Niagara Share Corporation has had in effect for many years.
Edward Streeter, humorist and author of two best-selling novels, "Father of the Bride" and "Dere Mable," died Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., April 1 (UPI) Three policemen in plainclothes investigating what they believed was a stolen car were shot to death in a motel parking lot today.

A paralyzing transit strike was narrowly averted early yesterday morning at a cost that city officials feared they could not match for other public employees within the limits of the city's already shaky financial plan.

LUXEMBOURG, April 1 European government leaders struggled with limited success today to keep the Common Market from coming apart over economic differences. But they did move toward agreement on the political issue of how to apportion seats in a new European Parliament.

The basic framework of the transit agreement was worked out in private discussions Tuesday evening in the New York Hilton Hotel between Matthew Guinan, the Transport Workers Union president, and David L. Yunich, the Transit Authority chairman. But the final pieces of the package were not put together until the early hours of yesterday morning.

In a competition dominated by centers, Kareem AbdulJabbar of the Los Angeles Lakers was named the winner of the National Basketball Association's most-valuable-player award for the fourth time yesterday, edging out Bob McAdoo of the Buffalo Braves and Dave Cowens of the Boston Celtics.

A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed charges of traffic-ticket fixing brought against Norman A. Levy, former president of the City Tax Commission, and John R. Fratianni, former deputy commissioner of purchase.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The House and Senate budget committees both finished work today on their budget targets and both decided to recommend to Congress total spending of somewhat more than $413 billion for the fiscal year 1977, beginning next Oct. 1.

Anthony B. Akers, who was the United States Ambassador to New Zealand from 1961 to 1963 and three times lost battles for a seat in Congress representing the fashionable East Side 17th District in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday in Wrightsville Beach, N.C. He was 61 years old and lived in Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Apprehensions about a revived militancy by Prime Minister Fidel Castro of Cuba have caused the collapse of a conference of Latin American leaders scheduled for June in Panama, a Panamanian official said today.
TOKYO, April 1 During World War II, a teen-ager named Sadako Nakamura often left her home to hide in a backyard bomb shelter from American planes.
In the confusion surrounding the Yankees and Andy Messersmith and the American League and Toronto, Commissioner Bowie Kuhn solved neither problem yesterday. But he did complicate the second one.

John Williamson, a starting guard far the New York Nets, suffered a severe sprain of the left ankle in Wednesday night's 116-106 loss to the Pacers in Indianapolis. Williamson will be out of action for an estimated 10 days to two weeks, and could miss the first round of the American Basketball Association playoffs, scheduled to start on April 9.

BRADENTON, Fla., April 1 It took 11 innings and a lot of charity from the Pittsburgh Pirates, but the New York Mets finally broke their eight-game losing slide today and won their first game of baseball's late spring.

The national money supply declined moderately in the week ended March 24. Commercial and industrial loans outstanding also declined, according to Federal Reserve banking system data released yesterday.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 As fickle as a headstrong girl too sure of her charms, Spring lured the New York State trout fisherman with sweet scents and warm breath, then drowned his passion with tears when the hour of truth arrived.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The House decisively approved today a bill that would reconstitute the Federal Election Commission but curtail the independence of the agency considerably more sharply than the measure the Senate passed last week.

A paralyzing transit strike was narrowly averted early yesterday morning at a cost that city officials feared they could not match for other public employees within the limits of the city's already shaky financial plan.
SAN ONOFRE, Calif., April 1 (UPI) A small plane exploded and crashed into the ocean between former President Richard M. Nixon's seaside estate and a nuclear power plant yesterday.
OLSZTYN, Poland Thousands of German families living in Poland have been plunged into an agony of indecision by a new treaty, under which 125,000 Germans will be permitted to leave this country.
MOSCOW, April 1 The United States sent a note to the Soviet Foreign Ministry today protesting the continued harassment of American diplomats in Moscow.

"Dances for Isadora," one of Jose Limon's last works, was also one of his most controversial. In this danced essay about Isadora Duncan, Limon painted a graphic image of Isadora at the end of her career a dissolute figure confronted with the hopes of her beginnings.

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that it had suffered damages totaling $156,000 as a result of what it called "sabotage" in New York City on the first day of a strike by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, the engineers' union whose members also include maintenance personnel and news writers.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 1 (AP) Kathy McMullen, putting inconsistently, and Sue Berning, putting extremely well, each shot fourunder-par 68's today to share the first-round lead in the $200,000 Dinah Shore Winners Circle golf tournament.

Many of the details of the bribery of Japanese politicians by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the late 1950's, in connection with the sale of the F-104 fighter plane to Japan, were reported at that time to the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency in Washington, according to a former C.I.A. official and Japanese sources.

Southern California, the source of countless outdoor cults, is now peddling one tied to asphalt and concrete, and the New York metropolitan area, much of which lies under the two substances, is buying.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Members of the House Select Committee on Intelligence have been asked by House investigators to give testimony voluntarily tomorrow about the unauthorized disclosure of the committee's report dealing with secret operations of the Central Intelligence Agency.

Max Ernst, the Surrealist artist, who was conspicuous even before World War I for his exceptional gifts and his power to startle and provoke, died in Paris yesterday. He would have been 85 years old today.

WASHINGTON, April 1 United States officials said today that they regarded the cease-fire announcement in Lebanon as an encouraging development, but they still expressed concern that the political situation there could deteriorate further.

In America today, says Maureen Green, the father may be an endangered species. He is being muscled out of his family by an increasingly competent and aggressive mother. Because he is not sure what his role is, he finds it difficult to defend himself. A palace revolution took place while he was at the office, and now he is the odd man out trying to get back in.

ROME, April 1 The decision taken by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the controversial case of Karen Anne Quinlan was criticized today by a professor in an interview on the Vatican radio station. The subject matter of the station's programs cosely reflect Vatican policy.
WASHINGTON, April 1 After 11 years of intermittent hearings on competition in the oil industry, the Senate antitrust subcommittee approved today a bill to break up 18 large oil companies.

WASHINGTON, April 1 Treasury Secretary William E. Simon expressed "cautious optimism" today about New York City's finances, but Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, criticized what he called his "Pollyanna attitude" for believing that the city would be able to obtain credit when legislation providing Federal loans expires, in 1978.

Evidence has been found that Pluto, the outermost of the nine planets circling the sun, is partly covered with methane ice. This has raised the possibility that Pluto is much smaller, than has been supposed and may, in fact, be a former moon of Neptune.

There is happiness on the face of Troy D. Stevens Jr. these days. He is a 36-yearold black general contractor who has completed what he says is the largest housing rehabilitation project ever awarded to a minority developer. It consists of 90 apartments and a few stores covering six connected buildings on Pitkin Avenue at Christopher Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn.

ROME, April 1 The decision taken by the New Jersey Supreme Court in the controversial case of Karen Anne Quinlan was criticized today by a professor in an interview on the Vatican radio station. The subject matter of the station's programs cosely reflect Vatican policy.

Officials of the American Stock Exchange, now investigating options trades that never took place, theorized yesterday that the Amex specialists who were involved waited until just before the close of trading at 4 P.M. each day to make the phantom trades.
ALBANY, April 1 The state's highest court today upheld a recent law allowing voter registration by mail, reversing a lower court's decision that the 1975 law was unconstitutional.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Friday, April 2 Lebanon's warring factions agreed last night on a 10-day truce to give Parliament time to elect a new president to replace Suleiman Franjieh, the controversial Christian leader who has refused to resign.

ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., April 1 Secretary of Labor W. J. Usery Jr. pressed both sides in the trucking strike today to compromise and reach an agreement, in the hope of avoiding a court injunction to end the walkout that began last midnight.

A dinosaur put together from used auto parts in New Jersey junkyards will be outside the Equitable Life Insurance Building at West 51st Street and the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan today. The skeletal beast 32 feet long and 10 feet high will be part of a Bicentennial exhibition sponsored by the National Sculpture Society that opens Monday and continues through April 22.

The Board of Higher Education has agreed to limit the applocation of a controversial entrance standard requiring eighth-grade reading ability for admission next fall to City University, board sources said yesterday.
FAIR LAWN, April 1 The Fair Lawn Flyers leave tomorrow for Leominister, Mass., to compete for the first national street hockey championship.

Middle-income parents who remain in the city are often scorned by their suburban friends. It's getting to the point where city parents can't go to a party in Lynbrook, L.I., without being attacked for neglecting their children's needs for open spaces and freedom from fear.

Goldsmith Brothers, a 90year-old company that was once the country's largest seller of stationery and office supplies, will close its last retail store at 77 Nassau Street within six weeks after a liquidation sale beginning Monday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 Chris Evert said she was "really up" for this match. She said she "really wanted it." She wanted to beat Dianne Fromholtz so much that she almost, could not control her feelings. She wanted revenge against the first person since Denise Carter in 1971 to defeat her in the first round of a tournament.

Edward Albee's "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" is back in town. It opened at the Music Box Theater last night, dripping raw blood and rubbing alcohol, and directed by the author. It also starred Colleen Dewhurst and Ben Gazzara in two of the most knock-down, drawnout, smashing, slugging and...

Roger Sessions's opera "Montezuma" dates back some 40 years. In the 1930's G. Antonio Borgese, a Sicilian novelist, playwright and refugee from Fascist Italy, traveled to Mexico. On his return he conveyed his enthusiasm for the history of that country to his friend, Mr. Sessions, who then went to Mexico himself with the "Montezuma" subject in mind.
The General Foods Corporation, the nation's largest coffee retailer, yesterday joined the Folger's Coffee Company in raising prices.

Uniondale, L.I. Walter Seeley, 130 pounds, Sayville, L.I., was awarded a victory when Natalio Jiminez, 128 , Dominican Republic, was disqualified by the referee in the ninth round for repeated low blows.
As usual, the alarm clock in the Long Island home of Jacinto Vasquez will go off at 5 o'clock this morning. By 5:15 A.M., the jockey who rode Foolish Pleasure to vic-...

CLEVELAND, April 1 (AP) Tim Moore of Cincinnati won the one-meter springboard final and 16-year-old Jennifer Chandler of Lincoln, Ala., won the three-meter springboard tonight in the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor diving championships.
ALBANY, April 1 They state's highest court today upheld a recent law allowing voter registration by mail, reversing a lower court's decision that the 1975 law was unconstitutional.

"One of our national treasures" was how Arthur Rubinstein was described by President Ford yesterday as he presented the 89-year-old pianist with the Medal of Freedom, the nation's highest civilian award, in the East Room of the White House. Mr. Rubinstein tried to blush but failed.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, greeted by politicians and the press with the attention customarily accorded an active Presidential candidate, which he insists he is not, described a "Marshall Plan for the Cities" yesterday to a roomful of mayors and other officials.
Rules changes have been adopted by the New York Stock Exchange, the exchange said yesterday, to "facilitate dealing in odd-lots" when its 380 specialists also become odd-lot dealers on May 24.

JERSEY CITY, April 1 (AP) Christ Hospital tonight re instated the surgical privileges of Dr. Mario Jascalevich, who is under investigation in connection with the mysterious deaths of 13 patients at another hospital in 1966.

Dick Stewart, self-described as a tall, skinny college guard who could not shoot but clawed and scratched his way up, was selected yesterday as Fordham University's basketball coach. Stewart played three seasons as a starter for Rutgers when the Scarlet Knights began their climb to national prominence during the 1966-67 season.

Welfare has become a national blight, destructive of many of the people it is designed to help and threatening the solvency of state and local governments. Outlays for public assistance keep mounting, in good times as well as bad; resentment grows among those on the relief rolls and among those taxed to pay the bill while other community services wither.

OTTAWA, April 1 Preliminary financing problems have delayed the signing of a contract between the Canadian Government and the Lockheed Aircraft corporation for the purchase of 18 long-range patrol aircraft from the American company at a cost to Canada of more than $1 billion.
Credit market prices continued their slide early yesterday as they reacted nervously to the Federal Reserve's decision to sell $300 million of Treasury bills, and later they recovered

NEWARK, April 1 The Foundation of the College of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey announced today the receipt from the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as the start of a $12 million fund-raising effort for the state's medical-education complex.
TEL AVIV, April 1 Legal proceedings in Israel against Tibor Rosenbaum, the financier whose European business conglomerate collapsed in 1974, have been dropped.

ST. JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, April 1 Prime Minister Jacques Chirac, invoking the nationalist spirit of Charles de Gaulle, today summoned the Gaullist party to "combat for the defense of the Fifth Republic."

TRENTON, April 1 Joseph T. Quinlan visited his comatose daughter today as controversy mounted over the New Jersey Supreme Court decision yesterday authorizing him to terminate her life and state officials studied the opinion to determine whether to appeal the ruling.

NAME IT, HEAR IT La. Difference, a large elegant restaurant in the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue, at 45th Street, comes by its name naturally on at least two counts. It has Continental kosher cuisine. It also has a pianist a smiling bundle of energy named George Parker who immediately plays requests, and then some. Ask for "any Cole Porter" and you get an instant cavalcade.

LONDON, April 1 (AP) The British pound sank below $1.90 for the first time today, undermined by wildcat strikes crippling the nation's biggest automaker and casting doubt on Britain's ability to achieve economic recovery.

DENVER, April 1 The na tion weathered the first day of the truckers' strike with little immediate impact on the economy, but widespread dis locations were predicted if the shutdown continued after to morrow.

Urging hundreds of millions of dollars in new aid for New York and other cities, the three leading aspirants for the Democratic Presidential nomination courted primary votes in the city yesterday by facing a group of Democratic mayors who accommodated them with easy questions.
YONKERS, April 1 A former prostitute charged with manslaughter was freed today from the Westchester County Jail on $1,500 bail raised by county residents who say they believe she is innocent.

The dismissal of two grand juries that for years have been looking into the 1971 revolt at the Attica Correctional Facility puts an end to one set of injustices but perpetuates another. The loose grab bag of indictments against more than 60 inmates about 1,300 charges in all, most of which proved insupportable had already been dropped by the state, and the dismissal of the grand juries means no more such charges will be brought.
The Schell Commission named by Governor Carey to investigate the collapse of the Urban Development Corporation has produced an interim report that is refreshingly lucid, thoughtful and constructive.

Leisure Dynamics, a fairly new company in the field of games and hobbies, has consolidated its $2 million advertising account at McCaffrey McCall.

Max Ernst, the Surrealist artist, who was conspicuous even before World War I for his exceptional gifts and his power to startle and provoke, died in Paris yesterday. He would have been 85 years old today.

Just back from the Garden that's Madison Square Garden where the circus opened last night and limp from an exciting day that began with the city hanging by its toes over a threatened transit strike and that ended with all sorts of people whirling about in midair.

The impact of the nationwide strike by teamster truckers who haul general freight began spreading across-the metropolitan area yesterday in what appeared to be an irregular pattern.
In the world of skateboarding, the kids who specialize in daredevil descents of steep roads, highway bridge underpasses or just about any slanted stretch of concrete are known as "road rash riders."

What do a champion figure skater, a modern dance choreographer and any number of women from a high school student to a middleaged beauty salon patron have in common these days? A short hairdo that falls over the forehead, bares the ear lobe and becomes a triangle in back.

The Kellogg International Corporation, London, and Kellogg India Ltd., New Delhi, have been awarded contracts for a 1,000-ton-a-day fertilizer ammonia plant for phulpur in North India by the Indian Farmers Fertilizer Cooperative Ltd. Both companies are affiliates of the Pullman Kellogg division of Pullman Inc. Cost of the entire project is estimated at $109 million.

The Avco Corporation, the diversified industrial company, had its highest first-quarter net income in nine years with a large increase on a revenue gain of 6.5 percent, according to the company's report issued yesterday.

Smith appears to be laying the groundwork for a new initiative one that will most likely seek to supplant nationalist politicians with traditional tribal chiefs in constitutional talks.

WASHINGTON, April 1 The whoelsale price index rose slightly in March after two months of decline, the Labor Department reported today. But the basic pattern of moderating inflation in the economy was unchanged.

George Bernard Shaw described melodrama as "a simple and sincere drama of action and feeling." Quite often that simplicity and sincerity are ignored in pursuit of the epic and extravaganza. For that reason, despite some shortcomings, two current Off Off Broadway melodramas, "The Count of Monte Cristo" at the Jean Cocteau Repertory and "The Hound of the Baskervilles" at the CSC Repertory, are to be commended.

Two men who allegedly abducted two 16-year-old girls at gunpoint outside a Queens high school Wednesday were seized on the Lower East Side last night after one victim was found shot and critically wounded and the other managed to escape unhurt from a Bronx apartment where she had been left bound and gagged.

WASHINGTON, April 1 John B. Connally was far back in the group when 16 members of President Ford's Foreign In- telligence Advisory Board emerged from the White House today to take the oath of office in a Rose Garden ceremony.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 1 (UPI) The Mayor took a cold shower at City Hall and travelers at San Francisco International Airport ate from paper plates today, the second day of a strike by city workers.

For Ronald Reagan, of all people, has come forward with an attack on his own Republican Administration that is a masterpiece of Democratic propaganda.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1 As fickle as a headstrong girl too sure of her charms, Spring lured the New York State trout fisherman with sweet scents and warm breath, then drowned his passion with tears when the hour of truth arrived.

Ted Bates Company, which pulled in some $60 million in new billings last year, is understood to have been named the agency for Mr. Coffee, the automatic dripolator made by North American Systems, Cleveland. FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 1 Two Yankee uniform shirts, one white, one gray, each with No. 47 on the back, hung in a locker in the Yankee clubhouse at Fort Lauderdale Stadium today. Andy Messersmith's Yankee shirts.
WASHINGTON, April 1 The Army said today it would close Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn and Fort Totten in Queens as an economy measure eliminating 604 civilian and 410 military jobs.

PHILADELPHIA, April 1 The Consolidated Rail Corporation, taking over the bulk of the transportation properties of the Penn Central and other bankrupt Northeast railroads, today borrowed $309 million from a Federal agency for working capital and to repay an undisclosed amount of loans obtained recently to prepare for its initial operations.
"Insiders" corporate officers and directors apparently stimulated by the rise in the market, have become heavy sellers, a study of trading figures released by the New York Stock Exchange shows.
A Brooklyn Appellate Court held yesterday that it was not necessary to get a traveler's consent to search his luggage if X-ray equipment at an airport found it contained a weapon.

Many of the details of the bribery of Japanese politicians by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in the late 1950's, in connection with the sale of the F-104 fighter plane to Japan, were reported at that time to the headquarters of the Central Intelligence Agency in Washington, according to a former C.I.A. official and Japanese sources.

Morris K. Udall lashed out with more than accustomed emotion yesterday at Jimmy Carter, saying that Mr. Carter was evading the question of whether he supported Congressional Democrats who are pushing full employment legislation.

The stock market registered its fourth declining session of the week yesterday as concern over the nationwide teamsters strike and its possible harm to the economic recovery raised caution signals on Wall Street.

The state's largest union of public employees, the Civil Service Employees Association, has approved a two-year contract with tightened provisions for job security, but no first-year increase in wages.

GLASSBORO, April 2 The American Civil Liberties Union said today that food and vegetable growers in the state were systematically cheating Puerto Rican migrant farm workers out of tens of thousands of dollars in wages every summer.

OLHAO, Portugal A siren wails to announce the arrival of a small trawler with its hold brimful of glistening sardines. The catch is good but almost everyone in the industry, from the fishermen and boat owners to canning factory owners and workers, talks about the crisis."

CHICHESTER, England, April 2 (AP) Ruby Miller, former music hall star, dancing partner of King Edward VII and coast of the stage-door Jonnnies, died in a nursing home here Friday. She was 86 years old.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 The New York Mets said today that they would like to sign Tom Seaver to a contract relating his pay to his performance over the next few years, but they warned meanwhile that "you can't be throwing these millions around for a few players."
After a seven-hour hearing to a no-decision in Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's office, Andy Messersmith suggested yesterday that the owners had conspired to hold their offers low.
Billie Jean King plans to buy herself a miniature Liberty Bell. Governor Carey is in the market for some appropriate Steuben glass.
GREENWICH, Conn The hundreds of symbol-splashed tarot cards exhibited here have been tools used by gypsies over the centuries to tell fortunes.

Leonard Bernstein paid his respects to American music in this Bicentennial year in a three-by-three program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night: Roy Harris's Symphony No. 3, David Diamond's Violin Concerto No. 3 and Aaron Copland's Symphony No. 3.

GREENSBORO, N.C., April 2 (AP) Al Geiberger birdied three of his last four holes today for a six-under-par 65 that put him in a four-way tie for the lead in the second round of the $230,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.
MILWAUKEE, April 2 Mention Wisconsin and people almost automatically think of a land of milk and beer.

ALBANY, April 2 The Federal Government praised Governor Carey this week for the money-saving Medicaid reforms he signed into law Tuesday, but warned that some of them continue to violate Federal regulations in a way that might cause them to be overturned in court.

TRENTON, April 2 Promulgated during the civil rights drive of the last decade, two of the state's toughest laws against racial discrimination in housing and employment that have rarely been enforced in the past are in jeopardy under budget cuts proposed by Governor Byrne.

Officials of the Transit Authority expressed confidence yesterday that they would be able to meet the added expense of their new labor contract through improved productivity and efficiency of operation.

The final days of the Nixon Administration were no picnic for the White House men in charge of the atom bomb. David Eisenhower was constantly phoning to make sure the President hadn't asked to have it sent up to the Lincoln bedroom, and Henry Kissinger was so worried that he had it secretly sent to Nelson Rockefeller's estate at Pocantico Hills for safekeeping.

A Public Service Commission examiner recommended yesterday that the Long Island Lighting Company be granted a permanent increase of 4.9 percent in its electric rates, less than a third of what the utility sought.

WASHINGTON, April 2 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger was virtually assured of Congressional approval for the sale of six C-130 military transport planes to Egypt after he told a Senate committee today that no further military sales to Egypt beyond prior commitments would be made this year. The prior commitments involve some communications equipment previously approved by Congress.

WASHINGTON, April 2 A noted religious thinker and biblical scholar criticized today that school of thought that would seek an end for diversity in Jewish life by merging the various branches of Judaism into a single religious philosophy.
WASHINGTON, April 2 The House of Representatives passed by a wide margin today a bill to reform the nation's scandal-ridden grain-inspection system. The vote was 246 to 33.

NEW DELHI, April 2 (AP) Final action on a compulsory sterilization bill providing jail sentences for unsterilized couples with three or more children has been deferred by the Maharashtra state assembly for at least three months.

WORCESTER, Mass., April 2 (AP) "I just lit a big one, You better hurry," an anonymous caller told fire officials early today as a blaze swept through an apartment house, killing five persons and sending five others to the hospital.

PRAGUE, April 2 (Reuters) At least 18 persons have been arrested in the last two weekss in what appears to be a largescale campaign against unorthodox artists and pop music groups in Czechoslovakia, dissident sources said today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 2 Shots were fired into the Soviet Union's Mission to the United Nations during the night and an underground group called the Jewish Armed Resistance claimed responsibility later today.

VAIL. Colo., April 2 (UPI) As preliminary investigation, monitored closely by the Secret Service, has determined that a frayed cable was responsible for derailing two gondola cars and killing four persons at the ski resort where President Ford spends his winter vacations.

Charles Marks, a former State Supreme Court justice, who presided at the Malcolm X murder trial in the 1960's, died of a heart attack Thursday in the Miami Heart Institute. He was 82 years old and lived in Miami Beach and formerly had lived in New York.
ROME, April 2 (UPI) Carlo Cardinal Grano, a veteran Vatican diplomat and a former chief of ceremony, died today at his home. He was 88 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 2 (Reuters) Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger has decided against visiting South Africa during his tour of black Africa later this month, United States officials said today.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, March 31 King Khalid of Saudi Arabia fell regally silent, the story goes, when aides once grew too insistent in urging a policy followed by his half brother and predecessor, King Faisal.

David Eisenhower and Edward F. Cox, the sons-in-law of former President Richard M. Nixon, yesterday denied having held views or made statements attributed to them in "The Final Days," a newly published account of Mr. Nixon's departure from the White House.

Some Wall Street observers are wondering whether the excellent reception accorded the million share offering of Hy-Gain Electronics Corporation stock at $19.25 each on Wednesday is a harbinger of a new speculative era.

DOUBLE DUTY Which Marcel Marceau do you prefer the performing mime on stage or the man himself autographing his new book in a Fifth Avenue store? Energetic New Yorkers can have both. Tonight at 8:40 the artist performs at Queens College's Colden Center (793-8080), at Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway in Flushing. Tickets are $4.50 to $6.50.

Partial settlement of the nationwide truck strike through the peacemaking efforts of Labor Secretary Usery eases a grave threat to continued economic recovery. Even in its first two days the tie-up had begun to spread a shroud of secondary unemployment over automobile plants and other industries just starting to cull out of the worst slump in four decades.
THE HAGUE Marshall Tito's official visit to Stockholm this week brought into friendly confrontation two contemporary types of independent socialism.

Frank D. Gilroy, a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, won a verdict worth more than $1 million yesterday because a television network, a production company and two publishers had used the character Amos Burke, whom he had created in books, without his permission.

"The Final Days," the new book by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein about President Nixon's last eight months in the White House, is generating questions from journalists and historians about its methods of reporting history, denials from some of those named in the book about actions or remarks attributed to them and a spirited defense from the authors.

WASHINGTON, April 2 The increase in the number of socalled problem banks has slowed markedly in recent weeks and may be approaching its peak, data compiled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation indicated today.

Fewer than 2 percent of members of the city's police force fired their pistols in the line of duty last year as the number of gun incidents declined for the third consecutive year, according to a Police Department report.

The world sugar trade, still groggy from the sharp rise and fall of prices the last 18 months, has been thrown into confusion by recent contracts for massive Philippine sugar sales to two big American refiners.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 2 The National Football League scored a major legal and financial victory today when a Federal District Court jury found that Joe Kapp was not entitled to any damages in his antitrust suit against the league. MANILA, April 2 (AP) Former President Diosdado Macapagal was reported in hiding in the Manila area today after the United States Government refused his request for political asylum. The asylum attempt followed publication of a book by Mr. Macapagal attacking the martial-law Government of President Ferdinand, E. Marcos as dictatorial.

ALBANY, April 2 The State Department of Social Services started a new adoption service this week to recruit adoptive families for 2,000 hard-to-place children now waiting for homes.

HARRISBURG, Pa., April 2 (UPI) Pennsylvania's Public School Building Authority voted today to strip the Mellon Bank of its control over $300 million in board funds after Gov. Milton J. Shapp accused the Pittsburgh bank of "betraying its trust."
STAMPORD, Conn., April 2 A four-year-old high speed patrol boat similar to those used by the United States Navy in Vietnam was launched here today as a floating ambulance.
UNIONDALE, L. I., April 2 The New York Nets took all the ifs out of the American Basketball Association playoff schedule tonight with a 111-87 victory over the Kentucky Colonels at Nassau Coliseum.

SOFIA, Bulgaria April 2 Todor Zhivkov, whose tenure as a Communist Party leader exceeds that of any of his Soviet-bloc counterparts, was redesignated today as head of the Bulgarian Communist Party for five more years.
GREENWICH, Conn. The hundreds of symbol-splashed tarot cards exhibited here have been tools used by gypsies over the centuries to tell fortunes.
As the three major contenders in next Tuesday's Presidential primary in New York campaign around the state, the effect they have on the crowds they address is strikingly different.

BUENOS AIRES, April 2 Minister of Economy Jose Martinez de Hoz announced tonight an economic-recovery program for Argentina based on a major expansion of agricultural production and the granting of contracts to foreign oil companies to develop petroleum resources.
ALBANY, April 2 Senator Henry M. Jackson of Washington in the last few days has shifted the emphasis of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination in next Tuesday's New York primary.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2? A 10-day truce officially took effect in Lebanon today, but fighting continued in the capital and the countryside and individual violence increased with a wave of 30 to 40 abductions, according to the state radio.

TOKYO, April 2-Former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka broke a two-month silence today to deplore what he called the "speculation and irresponsible remarks" that have linked him to the Lockheed scandal here.

LUXEMBOURG, April 2 Jean Monnet, the Frenchman whose ideas and persistence earned him the title of "Mr. Europe" when he helped create the Common Market in the 1950's, was rewarded today by being made an Honorary Citizen of Europe.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 2 (UPI) Experiments with mice suggest that the ultraviolet part of sunlight might suppress body defenses against cancer an idea that could have implications in assessing the impact of man-made atmospheric changes.
ST. LOUIS, April 2 (AP) A fire fanned by high winds damaged today most of the buildings in a four-block commercial area near downtown St. Louis, the police said.

Frank D. Gilroy, a Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, won a verdict worth more than $1 million yesterday because a television network, a production company and two publishers had used the character Amos Burke, whom he had created in books, without his permission.

Jerome Solomon, president of the Biotic Drug Company of New York and the Minimac Company of Chicago as well as a vice president of Marcal Paper Mills here, died Thursday in Memorial. He was 65 years old and lived at 70-20 108th Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

Norma Greenstein, since 1963 associate program director at radio station WEVD, 1700 Broadway, died Thursday in New York Hospital after a long illness. Miss Greenstein, who lived at 315 East 72d Street, was 52 years old.

TEL AVIV, April 2 (Reuters) Campaigning began today for local elections in the occupied West Bank, where candidates sympathetic to the Palestine Liberation Organization are expected to find wide support.
PARIS, April 2 The British pound continued to topple in Europe's currency markets today, falling to $1.87 from $1.8840 yesterday and bringing the decline of the last two days to nearly 5 cents.

Rose Wagemann, who made her Metropolitan Opera debut Thursday night as Leonore in "Fidelio" had every qualification except one: Her voice did not have the quality or the control one expects to hear in a major opera house.
ALBANY, April 2 Governor Carey will oppose any plan this year to revamp the system of employer contributions to the state's nearly depleted unemployment insurance fund.
BUFFALO, April 2 (UPI) A Buffalo nursing home operator was convicted on six counts of grand larceny by extortion, the office of the Special Attorney General, Charles J. Hynes, announced today.

HARTFORD, April 2 After being defeated last night in her bid to have Connecticut's state employees work an hour longer each day, Gov. Ella T. Grasso said today that, to keep within the state's tight budget, she was left once again with the alternative of laying some workers off.
WASHINGTON, April 2 Employment in the United States posted a strong gain in March, rising by 375,000 to a record 86.7 million, the Labor Department reported today.

LUXEMBOURG, April 2 The nine Common Market leaders concluded their spring conference today acknowledging that their countries had drifted so far apart on key economic issues that they could no longer register even limited agreements.

The tennis players are coming out of their bubbles. The outdoor season is beginning. On April 10, New York City's 527 municipal courts will be in use. Last year, 50,000 people paid $25 for permits enabling them to play through November. This year, the permits cost $27.50, close to the cost of an hour's play at some private facilities.
The Vienna Philharmonic played at Carnegie Hall for the first time in 10 years Thursday night at the beginning of a brief tour it is making in this country in honor of the Bicentennial.

MIAMI, April 2 (AP) A Federal grand jury that reportedly is investigating three operations of the Internal Revenue Service resumed its work today after questioning Donald C. Alexander, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, for more than six hours yesterday.

NEW DELHI, April 2 (AP) India's four domestic news services merged today into a single national agency as part of a government-supported restructuring of the Indian press.

STORNOWAY, Scotland Murdo Murray is a crofter, a small tenant farmer of a sort that has changed little in hundreds of years in Scotland. He raises turnips and potatoes on the barely arable nine acres of his two crofts and keeps blackface sheep on a common grazing ground. Like nearly all the 15,000 crofters in Scotland, Mr. Murray has to do something else to make ends meet.

THERE will be much needless suffering if the United States Department of Agriculture's newly issued food-stamp regu lations are implemented in June. They incorporate the most reprehensible features of legislation currently before Congress and, following as they do Administration dictates, in effect represent a usurpation of Congressional decision-making powers. For the first time in modern history, the voters of this state have an opportunity to participate directly in the choice of a Presidential nominee. Changes in the law have enabled those seeking election as delegates to their party's national convention to list, below their names, the Presidential candidate whom they favor. This simple reform has altered the New York primary on Tuesday from an Easter egg hunt into a relatively rational political process.

Shea a major power in Democratic Party politics in the state and lawyer for the Security National Bank, which is on trial along with three of its former top officers on charges of violating Federal election laws.

Kissinger's chief adviser, told American ambassadors in Europe that it is in the long-term interest of the United States to encourage East European countries to develop "a more natural and organic" relationship with the Soviet Union, according to an official but nonverbatim summary of his remarks.

MOSCOW, April 6 A senior American diplomat was surrounded tonight by six or seven Russian men who grabbed his jacket and threatened him with retaliation for the harassment of Soviet diplomats by Jewish demonstrators in New York.

WASHINGTON, April 5 Helmut Sonnenfeldt, Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's chief adviser, told American ambassadors in Europe that it is in the long-term interest of the United States to encourage East European countries to develop "a more natural and organic" relationship with the Soviet Union, according to an official but nonverbatim summary of his remarks.

LONDON, April 5 (UPI) The pound, failing to sustain an early rally, fell more than three-quarters of a cent today, closing at $1.8675. Financial analysts said speculators were adopting a wait-and-see attitude after the election of James Callaghan as Britain's new Prime Minister.

DALLAS, April 5 Ronald Reagan's nationally televised appeal for campaign funds has so far brought in more than $200,000 in contributions, the Republican candidate's aides reported today, and the expectation was that the figure would substantially increase by the time all the mail is counted.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The General Accounting Office has criticized the quasi-public corporation that is developing a controversial kind of reactor because its employees are not subject to laws on bribery, graft and conflict-of-interest.
TOKYO, April 5 (AP) Two Japanese public prosecutors left for Washington today to receive information about alleged payoffs in Japan by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

More than anything else, what sets the Presidential primary in New York apart from all others is the influence of the Jewish voter. An insignificant political minority in most states, the Jews are a special dimension here, like the retired people in Florida, the independents who can vote in either primary in Wisconsin and the highly organized auto workers in Michigan.
A year ago Joseph S. Murphy, the president of Queens College, said that his institution had become "the best passport to the middle class." Today it is a ticket to a less certain destination.

NEWARK, April 5 Joel R. Jacobson, president of the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners, called today on the heads of the state's gas and electricity companies to "show some compassion" before discontinuing service for nonpayment of bills.

Powered initially by settlement of the nationwide trucking strike over the weekend, the stock market moved ahead sharply yesterday in accelerated trading. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead by 5 points at the end of the first hour, gained ground steadily during the session to finish at 1,004,09 with a sparkling advance of 12.51 points.

PHILADELPHIA, April 5 The president of the American College of Physicians said today that proposed legislation to regulate health manpower might not correct the problem of poor physician distribution.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 5 (UPI) School buses were halted and most taxicabs idled today in San Francisco's growing transportation tie-up resulting from a strike of craft workers employed by the city.

Leon Lowenstein, former president and chairman of M. Lowenstein, Sons Inc., a major textile corporation founded by his father and brother in 1889, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 92 years old and lived at 480 Park Avenue in New York and Lowenbrook Farm in Purchase, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, April 5 Yields were mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

The big jet returning the New York Islanders home took off in Atlanta's hot night air. In the humid, rear cabin the players slumped in the seats, ties askew, their faces showing fatigue, disappointment and apprehension.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 5 (UPI) The State Assembly, in an unprecedented move, approved and sent to the Senate today legislation to place severe restrictions on the future construction of atomic power plants in California.

Here is a simple test for aspirants to elected office. It is intended to reveal general, as against specialized knowledge. Score two points for each correct answer a score of 80 is passing. Those candidates who cannot equal or better that grade should immediately fall silent and disappear.

The principal of an elementary school in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn said yesterday that an outbreak of head lice and nits among the school's student body had reached "epidemic proportions" and was affecting school morale and instruction.

The three major candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination wound up their drives for today's New York primary with diverse campaigning yesterday that reflected their political priorities and strategy.

Members of the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians who have been on strike against the National Broadcasting Company since last week were told by their leadership yesterday to return to work early tomorrow morning.
Walter Arthur Gordon, Governor of the Virgin Islands from 1955 to 1958, died Thursday at the age of 81 in Oakland, Calif.

John J. McCloy, who headed a committee that investigated illegal political payoffs by the Gulf Oil Corporation, said yesterday that corporate attitudes on foreign payoffs had undergone a "revolutionary change since recent, public disclosures of the slush funds" and suggested that Congress delay enacting any new legislation to remedy these ills.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Urban Mass Transportation Administration announced today that it would help finance the construction of fully automated "people mover" systems in as many as three cities this fall.
The Board of Higher Education moved formally last night to approve its long-awaited plan for reducing the scope of the City University by closing or reducing several of the system's colleges.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) The Federal Bureau of Investigation targeted three black groups in Cleveland for counter-intelligence program disruptions in 1968 although agents said they had no information that the groups were actively planning violent protest, agency documents disclosed today.
Encouraged by the weekend settlement of the nationwide trucking strike, prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market registered gains yesterday in moderate trading.
Howard R. Lamar, a professor of American history at Yale University, is becoming a television producer. He's going to make westerns.

Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., which operates Bergdorf Goodman and Neiman-Marcus in its chain of 96 stores, attained record sales and earnings in the fourth quarter and fiscal year ended Jan. 31, the company reported yesterday.

MADRID, April 5 Thirty-one political prisoners, almost all of them Basques serving long terms, were reported tonight to have broken out of Segovia prison in one of the most spectacular acts of defiance yet staged by the Basque nationalist organization E.T.A.
ATHENS, April 5 Greece wants an American aid package comparable in size and duration to the one that Washington promised to Turkey last week, according to well-informed diplomatic sources.

WASHINGTON, April 5 The foreign policy and defense catch-phrases of the Presidential challengers have become virtually identical, but the slogans blur the decidedly different visions each holds of the future role of the United States in the world.

The Theater Guild will stage a Broadway production based on Golda Meir's life story next year, Philip Langner, president of the guild, said yesterday in Tel Aviv. He said his company had acquired dramatic rights to Mrs. Meir's recent best-selling autobiography, "My Life," for an undisclosed sum.
CALCUTTA, India Shanta Banerjee has what she concedes is a difficult ,job trying to lure foreign tourists to the troubled city of Calcutta.

WASHINGTON, April 5 (AP) Two flu bills, one authorizing a nationwide immunization program this fall and the other appropriating $135 million for it as sought by President Ford, were passed today by the House and sent to the Senate.

Spanish-language tours of the Metropolitan Museum of Art are now being conducted on Tuesdays and Saturdays at 2:30 P.M. under the sponsorship of the museum's community programs department.

Adin A. Brown, a mining engineer who retired in 1963 as a vice president and director of American Smelting and Refining Company, now Asarco Inc., died Sunday at his home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 78 years old.

GLASGOW, April 5 Some 200 prominent economists, paying homage to Adam Smith, ended a four-day observance here mainly in agreement that his economic philosophy is worth reading again after years of disregard by Socialist and liberal governments in the Western world.

Simply stated, the amendment is designed to cut food stamp usage in Puerto Rico in half. It does so by a complicated formula that would make the nation's most depressed areas either slash the benefits provided or pay money back to the Federal Treasury.

He lost the job when it was learned he was under surveillance by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
United Technologies said yesterday that an internal investigation had disclosed that nearly $2 million in improper foreign payments were made in 1974 and 1975.
