TEL AVIV, April 9 Israeli officials today criticized the United States Ambassador, Malcolm Toon, for having charged at a news briefing yesterday that Israel was trying to put pressure on Congress to approve more aid than requested by President Ford.
HOUSTON, April 9 (AP) Nine steel companies and nine steel executives were fined a total of nearly $600,000 today after pleading no contest to charges of conspiracy to fix prices.

SYDNEY, Nova Scotia, April 9 Research conducted at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia, indicates that Reye's Syndrome, a rare but often fatal children's disease, may be linked to chemicals used in pesticide spraying programs.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., April 9 The disconnecting of the respirator that has kept Karen Anne Quinlan alive for almost a year is likely to be delayed at least a week while her former court-appointed guardian and his lawyer review the New Jersey Supreme Court decision that allows her to die.

Charles Morgan Jr., a leading Southern lawyer long active in the civil, rights movement, has resigned as director of the Washington office of the American Civil Liberties Union because, he said, the A.C.L.U. "bureaucracy" tried to restrict his public statements.

SALT LAKE CITY A $3.75 million antitrust suit that offers an unusual peek into the huge, diversified business empire owned by the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints has been filed in Federal District Court here.
The Jewish Defense League said yesterday that it would step up demonstrations in front of the Soviet Mission to the United Nations at 136 East 67th Street despite arrests of its members.

NEWARK, April 9 Consolidated Rail Corporation, the single new federally backed rail system created from seven bankrupt carriers in the Northeast, petitioned the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners today for permission to reclose 10 commuter-station buildings.
Rome, April 9 The Italian government, battered by a new political crisis, is moving toward a decision to resign and make way for parliamentary elections this June, a year ahead of schedule.

WASHINGTON, April 9 A formal campaign by prominent Democrats to draft Senator Hubert H. Humphrey for their party's Presidential nomination is tentatively scheduled to begin late this month, after the Pennsylvania primary.
Alfred Dunhill Ltd., probably the world's best-known tobacconist, will offer men's wear this fall in its shop in London's West End in an effort to test the Dunhill name In a new field.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., April 9 (AP) A church review court announced today its decision reversing the conviction of the Rev. L. Peter Beebe for violating Episcopal Church laws by permitting women to celebrate holy communion with him.
BRUSSELS, April 9 (UPI) The British pound sank for a time to a low on European money markets today until the Bank of England intervened. The Italian lira sank to a low against the dollar.
TRENTON, April 9 A fullscale debate on the outlawing or censoring of pornographic and extremely violent movies seems to be building in the State Legislature and elsewhere in government.
JERUSALEM, April 9 (Reuters) Prime Minister John Vorster of South Africa began talks here today with Israeli leaders, who ordered rigorous security measures for his fourday visit.
Frederick Sherman Baker, a retired editor and the author of three novels, died Thursday in Huntington, L.I. He was 73 years old and lived in East Hampton, L.I.
LAGOS, Nigeria, April 8 After four years of relentless growth fueled by oil, Nigeria's economy is showing signs of distress.

Phil Ochs, the folk singer, guitarist and lyricist whose music provided some of the strongest notes of protest against the Vietnam War in the early 1960's, committed suicide yesterday morning at his sister's home in Far Rockaway, Queens, the family reported.

WASHINGTON, April 9 (AP) The Postal Service announced today increases of up to 33 percent in the fees for special delivery, registered mail and other services.

ATLANTA, April 9 Industrialists representing 10 of Japan's largest corporations pledged at a meeting today with Southern government and business leaders to increase their investment and trade in the Southeast.

At a time when Helmut Schmidt's prestige abroad may be at the highest point of his two years as West Germany's Chancellor, little seems to be going right on the home front for his coalition of Social and Free Democrats in this election year. The substantial losses sustained by both partners in state legislative elections in Baden-W rttemberg this week are only on the latest ina series of setbacks for Mr. Schmidt's Government.

A Manhattan grand jury yesterday charged William Zeckendorf Sr., ruler of America's largest real estate empire until its collapse in 1965, with failing to file state income taxes for 1972 and 1973 when due.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market declined yesterday for the third consecutive session in moderate trading.

District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn disclosed yesterday that a grand jury had started taking testimony in an investigation into the abduction on March 19 of the two daughters of Karen Boyd Mellon.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 9 (UPI) Former Mayor George Christopher withdrew today as impartial observer in negotiations between the city and Striking municipal craft workers, calling the 10-day-old walkout hopelessly deadlocked.

William D. Sherrerd Jr., a Philadelphia investment banker, died Tuesday at his home in Haverford, Pa. He was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 9 The Senate defeated today all attempts to amend the budget targets for the fiscal year 1977 that were made by its Budget Committee.

Ignoring new warnings from School Chancellor Irving Anker's trustee, seven of the 22 schools in a West Side district kept pupils in classes yesterday for a full day.

After six months of legal grappling, baseball reappeared in New York yesterday with bats and balls, and the Mets marked the occasion with a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Expos in chilly, windy Shea Stadium.

MOSCOW, April 9 (Reuters) Soviet authorities have again refused exit visas to a majority among about 60 Jews who were told in February to ask for a review of their requests to emigrate to Israel, Jewish sources said today.

HONG KONG, April 9 China's Foreign Minister and other senior officials led street demonstrations in Peking today expressing support for the ouster of Teng Hsiao-ping, the former senior Deputy Prime Minister, as the nation's leaders evidently sought to prevent any further outbreak of unrest like the rioting in Peking on Monday.

QUITO, Ecuador, April 9 (AP) Two strong earth tremors a minute apart shook the northern coast and mountains of Ecuador during the night. Authorities said that at least seven persons were killed and 50 injured and more victims were feared buried in rubble.

LOS ANGELES, April 9 Despite the recent disclosures of wrongdoing by the Central Intelligence Agency, the number of college students seeking jobs in the agency has increased 30 percent over the last year, according to C.I.A, officials.

WASHINGTON, April 9 The House approved today a $33.4 billion military authorization bill that would add about $2 billion to the Ford Administration's defense program, primarily for construction of nuclearpowered ships for the Navy.

HOUSTON, April 9 (AP) Harold Solomon, who could not win on his serve until the third game of the second set, posted a 1-6, 6-4, 6-3 victory over Ilie Nastase today in a World Championship of Tennis touranment at River Oaks Country Club.
BONN, April 9 (AP) Parliament today passed a law that grants West German women equal rights in marriage and allows uncontested divorces after a one-year separation.

TOKYO, April 9 Some Japanese businesses, which were able to carry unusually large corporate debt burdens in the days of rapid economic growth have begun long-term efforts in recent weeks to trim these debts in preparation for an era of lower growth.

WASHINGTON The first official American comment last week on the seismic shift in the Chinese leadership came from George Bush, director of the Central Intelligence Agency. But he said he was confident that relations between the United States and China would not be affected.

LISBON, April 11--The Portuguese Socialist leader, Mario Soares, predicted today a narrow victory for his party and important gains for the main conservative party in the April 25 national legislative elections.

The president of the World Bank, Robert S. McNamara, has defended its recent decision to grant a $33 million loan to Chile. The defense was explained in a letter to Representative Henry S. Reuss, Democrat of Wisconsin.

Santos Ortega, a veteran radio actor, best known to television audiences as Grandpa Hughes in the serial "As the World Turns" since it went on the air 20 years ago this month, died Saturday in Broward General Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he was visiting. The American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market finished lower yesterday in sluggish trading. Analysts noted that there was little economic news to firm the market.

"Family" reaches its sixth episode on ABC-TV tonight at 10 o'clock, concluding one of the more impressive and most encouraging series to cross a television screen this this year. BRUSSELS, April 13 (UPI) Italy's beleaguered lira plunged to a low of 910.50 to the dollar at the opening of the Milan market today, but rallied after heavy intervention by the Bank of Italy. The dollar closed slightly lower on European money markets.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation agreed to day on a settlement of charges by the commission that the de fense contractor had violated various securities laws in mar ing secret payments to foreign government officials totaling at least $25 million between 1968 and 1975.

Traveling alone on a midnight flight from California, 11-year-old Jimmy Pugh arrived at La Guardia Airport, where he was met by two Easter Bowl aides. "Who do I play in the first round?" was his opening question.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 13 (UPI) Miriam Cooper Walsh, who starred with Lillian Gish in the first featurelength motion picture, died yesterday at Cedars Nursing Home, where she had been staying since suffering a stroke this year. She was 84 years old.

PATRICK J. Cunningham has refused to sign a waiver of im munity before a special state grand jury and yesterday he went into Federal Court to challenge the Constitutionality of the state election law that would remove him as the Dem ocratic state chairman and the party's leader in the Bronx be cause of his refusal.
"'Dropping' a building is perceived as a failure," a Manhattan real-estate man remarked last week. "Many people hang on to them to protect their reputation."

KATOWICE, Poland, April 13 Jiri Holecek allowed a goal in the opening two minutes and then withstood the Finnish team's attack to keep Czechoslovakia undefeated in four games of the world hockey championships with a 7-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation agreed today on a settlement of charges by the commission that the defense contractor had violated various securities laws in making secret payments to foreign government officials totaling at least $25 million between 1968 and 1975.

WASHINGTON, April 13 The scene was a luncheon dungeon in the Shoreham Hotel, which rises at this lime of year out of a blaze of azalea and dogwood blossoms on a steep bank above Rock Creek Park in Washington. The audience was the American Society of Newspaper Editors, whose papers have lately been giving Secretary of State Kissinger a hard time. The speaker: Henry Kissinger.
WASHINGTON, April 13 A Democratic attempt to derail the Ford Administration's plan for phased decontrol of petroleum product prices failed today on the House floor.

Did the artist really do the painting, and if so, when? Or was it done by a talented apprentice? Such questions, long pondered by scholars of Western Art, are now beginning to surface in the more esoteric field of Oriental art, as the latter is increasingly shown on the museum circuit.

A clash between angry parents and Board of Education security officers broke out yesterday morning outside a West Side school after the officer refused to allow parents to accompany their children to classrooms.

BUFFALO, April 13 Danny Gare bounced overtime goal into the New York Islander net tonight with his chest for a 3-2 Buffalo victory. Gare and the Sabres have become overtime specialists it was their sixth consecutive overtime victory, going back to last spring's playoffs, and it was the third in their last four playoff games here. The goal came after 14 minutes 4 seconds of the extra period.

GLASSBORO, April 13 The American Civil Liberties Union, charging "gross underpayment of wages" to thousands of migrants, has filed a class-action suit to obtain the records of hundreds of South Jersey farmers.
WASHINGTON, April 13

Eggs, of course, in almost any form can be related to Easter. One of the most elegant and amusing egg dishes we've ever encountered is one we discovered at the famed Pot au Feu Restaurant at Eugenie-les-Bains in France. The patron-chef is, of course, Michel Guerard, who is among the most celebrated chefs of Europe.

The sixth and final installment of "Sandburg's Lincoln" can be seen on NBC-TV at 10 this evening. The series, which has been dropped into the schedule sporadically over the last couple of seasons, unfortunately ends on a note of singular weakness. "The Last Days," using a script by Philip Reisman Jr. seems stuffed with air. Highly dramatic events are reduced to curiously thin anecdotes. Perhaps the budg- et ran out at Episode Five.

HELSINKI, Finland, April 13 (UPI) A gunpowder explosion demolished an ammunition factory in southwestern Finland today, killing as many as 45 workers and injuring 70 others in the worst industrial accident in the nation's history.

The Justice Department un der Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy rejected or ignored repeated recommendations for a thorough investigation of Frank Sinatra and his rela tionships with Mafia leaders, according to former Federal officials.

HOUSTON, April 13 The first clue to the disposition of Howard R. Hughes's billiondollar fortune came to light here tonight when sources close to the Hughes industrial empire said that a local law firm, representing both Mr. Hughes's business interests and his relatives, would seek the appointment of a temporary administrator of his estate here tomorrow.
The Washington Bullets, experienced and heavily favored, and the Milwaukee Bucks, young and opportunistic, turned in close victories last night as the National Basketball Association playoffs began.

Delegates representing 12,000 nursing-home employees in the metropolitan area turned down a request yesterday that they put off a strike set for tomorrow in their long-drawn-out dispute over a wage increase and retroactive pay due under their current contract.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 Mrs. Pam Bristol of Flint, Mich., and Chris Kinard of Pasadena, Calif., regained the singles titles in the 36th United States amateur badminton championships today at the Drexel University fieldhouse.

ALBANY, April 14 Backers of the Stavisky-Goodman school-aid bill, which became law early this morning as the State Senate overrode Governor Carey's veto, made plans today for amendments that would assure more money to schools without necessarily binding New York City to allot a fixed portion of its budget to education.
LOS ANGELES, April 14 Evonne Goolagong of Australia was forced to three sets tonight before subduing Marita Redondo, 6-4, 5-7, 6-4, in the gold division of the $150,000 Virginia Slims tournament.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 Voters in sprawling, populous Los Angeles County, which once had one of the world's most extensive rail mass transit networks, will be offered their third chance in eight years to consider a rebuilding of the transit system.
PARIS, April 11 At the fall ready-to-wear showings here, designers obviously gave more thought to theatrics than to clothes.

MINOT, N.D., April 14 The big neon sign over the Chamber of Commerce headquarters on Broadway reads: "Why not, Minot?" the town's rhymed slogan. But this week the 33,000 residents of North Dakota's fourth largest city are asking "Why?" and "How many years more?"

Last week's play in the Negro Ensemble Company's series of studio productions, a "season-within-a-season," never should have left the author's typewriter. This week's offering, Samm Williams's "A Love Play," on the other hand, belongs exactly where is is in a workshop.
Silver Convention's new RCA album will appeal to those who liked the group's first, "Save Me," and who respond to this most scientifically disembodied of disco bands.

PALO ALTO, Calif., April 14 (AP)-A lung collapse such as the one suffered by patricia Hearst is "fairly common" among young people and often can be repaired without major medical effort, a respiratory specialist says.

WASHINGTON, April 14 The State Department said today that negotiations to sell Jordan an air-defense system "were very much alive" alfinancial arrange ments had become "more complicated and time-consuming than originally contemplated."

Philip Morris, Inc., the cigarette producer, reported yesterday a 27.6 percent increase in first-quarter earnings on a revenue gain of 17.8 percent, continuing an unbroken record of quarterly results for 12 years.

In its precipitous override of Governor Carey's veto of the Stavisky bill, the State Senate has stooped to a false promise to aid the city's schools. The action offers not the slightest hint how that promise is to be redeemed. The new law's requirement to restore $150 million to next year's school budget disposes of funds which simply do not exist. They could only be "found" by slashing other services.

Delegates representing 12,000 nursing-home employees in the metropolitan area turned down a request yesterday that they put off a strike set for tomorrow in their long-drawn-out dispute over a wage increase and retroactive pay due under their current contract.

LOS ANGELES, April 14 The illness of Patricia Hearst today forced the postponement for at least one week of her appearance in Los Angeles to start court proceedings in a case involving William and Emily Harris, her co-defendants.
JUNEAU, Alaska, April 14 (AP) A nine-day strike by state government white-collar workers that had made idle 5,000 employees ended today when tentative agreement was reached on a three-year contract.
ALBANY, April 14 Governor Carey signed a bill today making Sunday, May 30, instead of Monday the state's Memorial Day holiday this year.
Two things are certain around this time of year: income taxes and Bloomingdale's spring model rooms. Both have been known to separate New Yorkers from their money.

KATOWICE, Poland, April 14 (UPI) Tom Younghouse and Steve Jensen scored goals in the first five minutes of the game today to start the United States team off to its second victory in four games at the world ice hockey championship, a 4-2 triumph over Poland.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 14 (AP) Former President Mariano Ospina Perez of Columbia, died today. He was 84 years old.
NEWCASTLE-UPON-TYNE, England, April 14 (UPI) A teacher's wife gave birth to sextuplets, but two girls died, a spokesman at the maternity hospital here said today.

DETROIT, April 14 The Chrysler Corporation reported today that it had returned to a profitable basis in the first quarter, after having sustained 18 months of deficits. The company announced a net income of $72 million, or $1.20 a share, after a $15 million tax credit, for the three months to March 31. In the first quarter of last year Chrysler's net loss reached $94.1 million.

The college crew season will bloom on Saturday with 11 of the East's 16 major rowing institutions sending their varsity heavyweight eights into action. The Coast Guard Academy, an upstart among the 16, is challenging mighty Harvard in the first dual regatta between those two. It will be rowed on Boston's Charles River.

In an effort to defuse anti-American passion in Greece and disarm anti-Turkish sentiment on Capitol Hill, the Administration is ready to initial a four-year military aid agreement with Athens roughly parallel to the one concluded with Turkey last month. If approved by Congress, the pact would provide $700 million in military aid to Greece over a four-year period and continued American use of four military installations in that country.

BRUSSELS, April 14 (UPI) The dollar declined on most European money markets today. Italy's ailing lira continued to benefit from Bank of Italy intervention after the lira dropped to a new low the previous day.
CHICAGO, April 14 Legs proved the difference today in balmy Wrigley Field.
WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) The Senate is being asked to change its rules to require that all major international agreements be approved by a two-thirds Senate vote before becoming effective.

PARIS, April 15-French politicians, in a drastic departure from custom, have proclaimed that the campaign for the next national election is on although the voting is not scheduled until the spring of 1978.

In a case of divided loyalties, Leonard Probst, the critic and producer for NBC Radio, is walking a picket line as part of the strike by the National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians, while still reviewing plays on the radio for NBC's News and Information Service.

PHILADELPHIA, April 14 (AP) Judge William H. Hastie, the first black appointed to a Federal appeals court judgeship and a former Governor of the Virgin Islands, died today at Suburban General Hospital in East Norriton. He was 71 years old.
BUENOS AIRES, April 14 (AP) Gunmen killed a Chrysler Corporation executive, a navy captain and three policemen today.

MARION, Ala., April 14 (AP) An all-white jury has awarded damages of $20 in a $50,000 suit filed on behalf of a black youth who contended that a doctor after stitching a cut in his arm, took out the sutures immediately when the boy's full bill could not be paid on the spot.
Rats with high blood pressure should not ride the subways too often or too long. The stress of noise, vibration and crowding may kill some of them before their time.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, authorized the use of Congressional facilities "about 30 times over the past five years" for his wife's sightseeing business, an aide said today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 14 A judge dismissed today on technical grounds murder indictments against three men, identified as former Ku Klux Klansmen, who had been accused of foreing a young black man to jump to his death in the Alabama River 19 years ago, reportedly because he had smiled at a white woman.

Good to excellent first-quarter earnings reports notwithstanding, the stock market closed lower yesterday. The decline, carried out in moderate trading activity, almost erased Tuesday's technical upturn.

Representative Wayne L. Hays, the 14-term Ohio Democrat, made public yesterday his marriage in Arlington, Va., Tuesday to Patricia E. Peak, a longtime associate who has been administrative secretary in his Ohio office.

WELCOME BACK Walt Disney's "Fantasia" (1940) and "Alice in Wonderland" (1951) are back as family entertainment over the spring holidays, and there is a free showing today of another classic, the Soviet-made "Alexander Nevsky" (1939), at a midtown library.
William Sentman Taylor, professor emeritus of psychology at Smith College, died Monday in Cooley Dickinson Hospital, Northampton, Mass. His age was 82.

BUENOS AIRES, April 14 (AP) A plane owned by the Argentine state oil company crashed today in southern Argentina, killing all 37 people aboard, the authorities reported.
LONDON, April 14 (AP) Prime Minister James Callaghan announced 22 middle-rank changes in his Government today, nine days after succeeding Harold Wilson as Labor Party leader and head of Government.

WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI) The 94th Congress left today for a 12-day Easter recess. It has completed threequarters of its tenure; if the goal for final adjournment by Oct. 2 is met.

WASHINGTON, April 14 Seymour M. Hersh of The New York Times received the $5,000 Drew Pearson Award today for "general excellence in investigative reporting."

The RCA Corporation reported yesterday first-quarter net income of $34.3 million, equal to 44 cents a share. This was a gain of 101.8 percent over the $17 million, or 21 cents a share, reported in the three months ended March 31, 1975. Sales rose 15 percent to a new high of $1.26 billion from $1.09 billion a year ago.

WASHINGTON, April 14 Growing populations are laying waste wide areas of Africa, Asia and Latin America even as wealthier countries try to help the poorer lands develop their food-production resources, a new research study warns.
RIO DE JANEIRO, April 14 (AP) Zuzu Angel, the fashion designer who dressed such stars as Joan Crawford, Kim Novak and Dame Margot Fonteyn, died last night in an auto accident.

WASHINGTON, April 14 Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, with his emphasis upon constructing expensive, nuclearpowered ships, has become a "malady" afflicting and distorting the Navy, in the opinion of Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the former Chief of Naval Operations.

The Penn Relays Carnival is making its own contribution to Philadelphia's Bicentennial celebration this week by staging a meet that will be both historic and revolu tionary.

National Coin Week begins today, and it has seldom had more auspicious numismatic surroundings. Not only have coins and medals been playing the leading role in commemorating the nation's Bicentennial this year, but the public's attention has also just been even more dramatically refocused on numismatics as the result of last week's rebirth of the $2 bill. Now it is up to the individual collector and the local coin club to put it all together.

Spokesmen for the black community, noting a general decline in black voting and continuing low registration among blacks, have voiced concern that apathy and cynicism about politics could seriously dilute gains of recent years and hinder future progress.

Temple Emanu-E1 celebrated the Bicentennial yesterday morning with a special Sabbath service that emphasized the relationship of the nation's principles of independence and religious freedom with the Passover festival.
The city is earning about $1,000 a day on delayed 1975 income tax refunds, but it is not being deliberate or mean about it.

CLEVELAND, April 17 (AP) Austin Carr and Bobby Smith each scored 17 points today to spark the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 88-76 National Basketball Association playoff victory over the Washington Bullets.

Following hard on Jimmy Carter's unfortunate use of the phrase "ethnic purity," for which the former governor had the grace to apologize, President Ford only compounded the prohlem in attempting to explain it away.

The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States and the Goodman Company of Allentown, Pa., have started construction on a $35 million shopping, commercial and civic center in Ocean Township, N.J.

COLUMBUS, N.C., April 17 (UPI) Kenneth Lackey, a vaudeville actor who started his career on a dare and joined the original Three Stooges slapstick comedy team, died yesterday after a lengthy illness. He was 74 years old.

Every year some 10,000 to 20,000 American babies are born into what has been called a "legal no-man's land." With their numbers estimated around the half-million mark, these are children of artificial-insemination donation (A.I.D.), conceived with donated semen and raised as the "natural" offspring of their mothers and their mothers' husbands.
In 1939, John G. Martin bought a struggling little liquor company named Smirnoff for $14,000. "I'll never knew why," says Mr. Martin.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 16 President Ford has regained the lead over former Gov. Ronald Reagan of California in a contest for this state's 167 delegates to the Republican Presidential convention, according to the most recent California poll released this week.

With the rise of the fine electric guitar as the major instrument in the rock arsenal, there seems too have been a corresponding decline in the number of ordinary guitarists who measure up to the legacy of Django Reinhardt and Charlie Christian, those 30's pioneers of the guitar as a modern jazz instrument.

WASHINGTON The black-white issue in southern Africa is forcing American leaders to confront ever deeper levels of what is realistic and what is right in forming policy. The potential for human catastrophe imbedded in this vestige from another century can no longer be ignored in Washington now that Moscow and Havana, with the world looking on, are threatening to liberate the blacks by force.
In the spirit of '76 my house guest shouted, "The red-wings are coming! The red-wings are coming!" It was the first day of March and this was a signal that nature was truly preparing another spring.

POKHARA, Nepal, April 11 The road east from this sleepy little regional center is a highway that the Chinese built two years ago through the Himalayan foothills, and they plan to extend it through even rougher country to the west.
Loans to less developed countries are frequently cited as a major problem area in international banking. According to some observers, a crisis is developing and widespread defaults will occur.

Archie Bunker and his brood will be moving again next fall, this time to Wednesday nights. It will be the fourth address in six years for the CBS first family, and is an attempt at blockbusting on the part of the network.

CINCINNATI, April 17 (AP) Baseball was upstaged by honey bees today at Riverfront Stadium when a swarm estimated at between 5,000 and 10,000 in number, took up residence in the San Francisco Giants dugout before the game, forcing a 35-minute delay. The Reds went on to rout the Giants, 11-0.

MADRID, April 18 The Socialist General Union of Workers today ended its first congress in Spain in 44 years with a demand for political and labor freedom and for a complete break with the present state-run syndicate organizations which join labor and management.

TEL AVIV, April 18 About 30,000 Israeli nationalists, some carrying weapons, marched 11 miles through the Israeli-occupied West Bank to dramatize their belief in their historic title to the area and to demand the right to settle there.

Norton Simon Inc., maker of consumer products, achieved record sales and earnings in the quarter and nine months ended March 31. Its report, issued over the weekend, showed net income in the quarter at $20.8 million, or 45 cents a share, up 13.8 percent from the year-earlier $18.3 million, or 39 cents a share.

G. Wallace Conover, editor of the weekly Somerset (N.J.) Messenger-Gazette from 1931 to his retirement in 1972 and a past president of the New Jersey Press Association, died yesterday at Hunterdon County Medical Center in Flemington, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived at 87 East Spring Street in Somerville.

The super at an East Side apartment building fired the doorman again last week, according to a report reaching this column. He had done it two or three times before, usually when he was depressed or hung over. Each time, the dismissal was rescinded. This time he seemed determined to make it stick.

PORT HOPE, Ontario, April 14 Green buds are beginning to clothe the bare old maples along the hilly streets of this little town where the Ganaraska River spills into Lake Ontario, 60 miles northeast of Toronto. Fat salmon are fighting their way up the Ganaraska to their spawning grounds. Shopkeepers are changing their sporting-goods displays, putting away the skis and bringing out the fishing tackle.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Congress's General Accounting Office says that long lunches for Federal employees may be costing as much as $1.2 billion a year in lost production time.

CARLSBAD, Calif., April 18 Don January, who finally decided to play because last place was sure to be worth $4,347 took the $45,000 first prize today in the 24th Tournament of Champions, finishing five strokes ahead of Hubert Green.

WASHINGTON, April 18 The Georgetown cocktail party, by now, is as much of a political cliche as the rubber-chicken dinner, but one held here last week was a little different: they candidate was a man who would not accept Federal matching funds for his campaign if he could get them.

WASHINGTON, April 18 A civilian commission created by Congress to study the mounting costs of military manpower has concluded that over the next decade no significant reductions are possible in either the size or the cost of the armed services.

Robert Blake, the short, muscular star of "Baretta," television's No. 1 dramatic series, has taken on a new role television spokesman for STP oil-treatment and gasoline-treatment products. It marks his debut in 30second commercial dramas.

The Soviet atomic icebreaker Lenin, in an unusual Arctic experiment, has succeeded in convoying a freighter through heavy winter ice to open a Siberian natural gas field from the sea side for the first time, the Moscow press has reported.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia, April 14 Saudi Arabia is reported fitting out its armed forces with large amounts of new military facilities and equipment and may make further substantial purchases of warplanes.

Over the years, most states have sought to devise financial aid formulas that would equalize per-pupil school expenditures, only to find these formulas distorted by pressure from special interests. Instead of being narrowed, the gap between rich and poor school districts is growing wider.

Slightly more than a week ago, as the Dow Jones industrial average had struggled again above the 1,000 level, a well-known market anayst surprised Wall Street and investors generally with his out-of-the-blue forecast that the Dow would drop 100 or more points within the near future.

John Shumate of the Buffalo Braves and George Trapp of the Detroit Pistons, unlikely candidates for the hero's role, played key roles yesterday as their teams defied the home-court advantage and advanced in the National Basketball Association playoffs.
Easter, the feast of Christ's Resurrection, the most holy day of the Christian calendar, was celebrated yesterday in churches, at family outings and in displays of new fashions.

JASPER, Tenn., April 18 (AP) Forty cars on a 90-car freight train derailed coming down a mountain grade today, spilling a toxic wood preservative into Nickajack Lake, Civil Defense officials said. No injuries were reported.

This afternoon at 5 o'clock, in the New York State Theater at Lincoln Center, the 1976 National Book Awards will be announced. For the first time in weeks, the book community will have something else to talk about besides Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI) Russell E. Train, the Environmental Protection Agency head, said today that he expected some "bad air alert situations" in Washington as millions of tourists come here this summer for the Bicentennial.

SAN ANTONIO, April 18 With a lot of roughhouse at the beginning and some finesse in the last 40 seconds, the New York Nets evened their semifinal playoff series with the San Antonio Spurs this afternoon with a 110-108 victory at the HemisFair arena here.

New York City's white population declined by more than 600,000 between 1970 and 1975, according to an analysis of United States Census figures. During that period the Bronx became the first borough in the city's history with a majority black and Puerto Rican population, the figures showed.

Easter was observed in lowkeyed, neighborhood style yesterday in the Woodside section of Queens, with the emphasis on religion, family and old friendships. The fashion stars were little girls, frequently of preschool age.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., April 18 Agnes Kutkiewicz, who has lived in this Suffolk County community for nearly 66 years, was clearly annoyed.

Soma Morgenstern, the Polish-born novelist whose books reflected the simple, pastoral life of village and farm that once existed in Eastern Europe, died Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived at 61 West 74th Street.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 18 (Reuters) Three hundred Indonesan soldiers have been withdrawn from eastern Timor because peace has been restored there, Foreign Minster Adam Malik said here.

Robert Lowell's trilogy "The Old Glory" has become part of the younger glories of the American intellectual establishment. Seeing it reproduced by the American Place Theater as part of its Bicentennial celebrations, one idly wonders why. Mr. Lowell is a major American poet, but his sense of the theater is meager, and in these plays even his prosody is fundamentally prosaic.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., April 18 (AP) The police chief, an administrative assistant to the Mayor, the director of public safety and a police officer have been arrested here and charged with protecting illegal gambling.

In 1974, James R. Schlesinger, then United States Secretary of Defense, and West Germany's Defense Minister, Georg Leber, agreed on competitive trials of a new American tank vs. Germany's projected Leopard II. The general understanding was that the winner would be selected as the main battle tank for both countries.

BOSTON, April 18 The train that carried Paul Heyer here from New Jersey yesterday was air-conditioned, so Heyer did not know how hot it was outside. But when he saw the girls in their bikinis, wading in the Charles River, he knew that it was too hot for comfort. And he knew that tomorrow's running of the Boston Marathon would be a run for the hoses.

It seemed as if the major effort in preparing for yesterday afternoon's American Symphony Orchestra concert in Carnegie Hall had gone into the final work, and no wonder. For all its familiarity these days, Mahler's "Das Lied von der Erde" still makes gargantuan demands on the orchestra, the conductor and especially the two soloists. Most of these demends were met yesterday, but unfortunately without any special vision.

And because of its traditional association with the god Krishna, it calls up pastoral images of spring. The Indian flutist T. Viswanathan drew on these associations and images during his concert at Asia House yesterday afternoon, while Easter strollers took advantage of the balmy weather on nearby Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) Members of Congress are away for their EasterPassover recess, and President Ford is at his retreat in the Maryland mountains, but Washington far from empty over the holiday weekend.
DENVER, Monday, April 19 (Reuters) The hijacker of a light plane was shot to death early today inside a jet that he had demanded for a flight to Mexico.

James Augustus Hunter has given up so many home runs in his glittering career it won't be long before he forgets the latest pair he allowed, even though it cost him a game.
Foreign investment in manufacturing facilities in the United States was up sharply during the first three months of 1976, according to a survey conducted by the Conference Board and released today.
CAIRO, April 18 (Reuters) Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that he had been "strongly impressed" by the sincerity of President Anwar el-Sadat's search for peace in the Middle East.

At a low point in his years as Prime Minister, Harold Wilson was portrayed on the London stage as a pudgy little man in a wrinkled Batman suit, telling everyone what wonders he could perform. TOKYO, April 18 The Lockheed scandal that has shaken and preoccupied this nation for more than two months has begun to have long-term and deep-seated consequences for Japan's politics, economy, security and diplomacy.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia As the next ministerial meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries approaches, Saudi Arabia is standing by its stated opposition to an increase in the price of oil, according to well-placed Arab and Western sources.

LES GIRLS A cabaret bill shared by two women singers, no longer young and both new to local bistros, works nicely at Once Upon a Stove, 325 Third Avenue (between 24th and 25th Streets). Taina Elg and Denise Lor are the first "name" booking in the restaurant's Valentine Room, where singing waiters and waitresses previously mounted the podium. There's now a $3.50 cover charge and a minimum of two drinks (most are $2).

PITTSBURGH, April 18 Dave Kingman and the New York Mets won the home-run battle today, but Willie Stargell and the Pittsburgh Pirates won the egg hunt and the baseball game, 7-5.

MINOT, N.D., April 18 (AP) The Souris River began dropping today, reducing the danger of a fifth flood in seven years in low-lying sections of the city.

WASHINGTON Eunice Shriver, sister of John F. Kennedy, wrote a blistering letter to The Washington Star last week for publishing a United Press account of a story in The National Enquirer about her sister-inlaw, Joan Kennedy.

Governor Carey appointed last year a committee to seek an answer to the skyrocketing cost of medical malpractice insurance and its effect on the availability of medical care. That committee, headed by Columbia University's president, Dr. William J. McGill, reported some months ago, but the recommendations now put forward by the Governor bear so little relationship to those by the commission that Dr. McGill and his associates may well wonder why they bothered.

State auditors have found that controls and security over blank Medicaid identification cards by a city agency were "nonexistent" and that as a result the state's Medicaid program was being exposed to "many potential fraudulent abuses."
MELVILLE, L.I., April 18 The Rice Farms team of Huntington scored 24 points and won the Division A championship today at the Junior Olympic horse show.

TRENTON, April 18 Despite a hiring freeze and cutbacks in services, the state has been making significant progress through its affirmative-action program in hiring women and minority-group members, according to Governor Byrne.

Weather Report has long been a leader of the jazz-rock movement. But at the early show Saturday night at the Beacon Theater it was handily upstaged by the opening act.

A New York City couple in their late 30's have seen the income from their jointly operated beauty salon drop by half in the last two years because of the recession.

Frank E. Martin, former head of the industrial arts department at Glen Cove (L.I.) High School, died Friday at the home of his son, Dr. William F. Martin, at 1 St. Andrews Lane, Glen Cove. He was 84 years old.

Kelly Bishop believed "cross my heart, hope to die" that her good friend Priscilla Lopez would win the Tony award for best featured actress in a musical. Both, appearing in "A Chorus Line," had ben nominated for the award and accepted it with delighted radiance, blowing kisses to the audience.

Michael Bennett's "A Chorus Line" swept the honors as the best musical show of the 1975-76 season in the 30th annual Tony Awards last night in a glittering ceremonial production at its own house, the Shubert Theater.

Specifically, changes in the sex, age, educational and marital status of the work force may produce significantly different attitudes toward work in the future.

New York City's white population declined by more than 600,000 between 1970 and 1975, according to an analysis of United States Census figures. During that period the Bronx became the first borough in the city's history with a majority black and Puerto Rican population, the figures showed.

NARA, Japan When little Kazuhiro Sugiyama and the 719 other pupils of this city's newest elementary school donned their canvas slippers and shuffled down the shiny halls for the start of the new academic year here recently, they could sense something different about the year-old building.
BRAUNAU, Austria, April 18 (Reuters) The house where Adolf Hitler was born is to be converted to a school for retarded children, according to the deputy mayor of this border town.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare has affirmed that it is not mandatory for school districts to provide bilingual education for pupils whose primary language is not English.

Dr. John E. Buhler, dean emeritus of the school of dentistry of the Medical University of South Carolina, which he organized and led in its formative years, died yesterday in Charleston, S.C. He was 67 years old.
A nonprofit research group's survey of 22 cities yesterday reported that Baltimore was most responsive to its citizens and Chicago the least so with New York ranked 20th.

Abigail Margaret Cantwell, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Cantwell of New York, was married yesterday afternoon in Saugerties, N.Y., to John Charles Girr. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. August Girr of New York and Bay Shore, L.I.

Archeologists digging in Guatemala have unearthed evidence that may shed light on one of the oldest mysteries surrounding the ancient Maya civilization: why such an advanced culture should have arisen in so inhospitable a place as the hot, tropical lowlands of northern Guatemala and Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula where most of their ruined cities are found today.

WASHINGTON, April 18 A civilian commission created by Congress to study the mounting costs of military manpower has concluded that over the next decade no significant reductions are possible in either the size or the cost of the armed services.
Dr. Warren Irving Titus, an internist on Long Island for 50 years, died Friday at his home, 6 Highland Road, Glen Cove. He was 76 years old.
MERIDEN, Conn., April 18 (AP) Sanford H. Wendover, retired editor of The Meriden Journal, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.
Six masked gunmen yesterday raided a Brooklyn dance held to raise money to send Boy Scouts to summer camp. They fled with $1,700.

Two prison parolees one of them a convicted murderer accompanied by an Episcopal minister, surrendered yesterday to the police in the Bronx, in the holdup-slaying of two armed guards last Monday in a Times Square movie theater.

KANAB, Utah, April 18 (AP) More than 500 local residents cheered as they burned a blondwigged effigy of Robert Redford, the movie actor who opposed construction of a $3.5 billion power plant that was dropped last week.

When Mr. and Mrs. Lee Bogart moved into their newly built contemporary home in Virginia Beach, Va., last July, a lot of interior work remained to be done. Doors and closets were missing, the screen doors and windows were not installed and the stove and dishwasher were hanging out from their cabinets plus more than 40 other unfinished items.
NEW DELHI, April 19 India and Pakistan have taken a new step toward the resumption of normal relations, the Government announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The rupture of an overpressurized water tank in a basement set off the natural-gas explosion that demolished one side of a 25-story New York City building on April 22, 1974, the National Transportation Safety Board ruled today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 A multibillion-dollar decision by the Administration on whether to build up to a 600-ship Navy may depend in part upon the outcome of the Republican Presidential primary in Texas on May 1, Pentagon officials said today.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) Two housing loan organizations accused the Justice Department today of failing to investigate before charging them in a lawsuit with illegally downgrading property values in in integrated neighborhoods.

LONDON, April 19 Is she or isn't she? Is she a slim, straight-haired girl in her 20's? Is she dressed in a classic gabardine skirt, blazer, and good accessories Gucci shoes, Hermes scarf tied under the chin or knotted on a neat little bag? Is she educated at a good private school and then sent off to be finished by a Cordon Bleu course or a genteel secretarial school? Is she absolutely reliable?
The State Attorney General's Office is conducting an investigation into possible illegal payoffs by brokers to obtain tickets to hit shows on Broadway including "A Chorus Line" and "Chicago."

WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP) The Supreme Court declined today to decide by May 1 whether Representative Morris K. Udall is entitled to a place on the ballot in the May 4 Indiana Presidential primary. The Court rejected without dissent and without comment a request by the Arizona Democrat for expedited consideration of his appeal from an April 1 decision by a threejudge Federal court in Indianapolis.

BOSTON April 19 (AP) A gang of black youths dragged a white man from his car and beat him severely tonight in Boston's Roxbury section, while another gang about a mile away stoned railroad crewmen trying to clear the tracks of debris that halted a train, the police said.

Michael Greer, a prominent interior designer who had helped decorate a room in the White House during the Dwight D. Eisenhower and John F. Kennedy Administrations, was found dead yesterday in his apartment at 525 Park Avenue, at 60th Street, his feet bound by a red sash.

It seems modestly appropriate in this Bicentennial year that the British should be coming. Last night at the Metropolitan Opera House Britain's Royal Ballet opened a month-long season with Kenneth MacMillan's "Romeo and Juliet." Later in the week the Royal Shakespeare Company brings its production of "Henry V" to the Brooklyn Academy of Music. There is nothing quite like Shakespeare in the British theater or in any other theater for that matter.

The Northrop Corporation, the diversified aerospace products manufacturer, which has figured in reports of foreign payoffs and domestic political contributions reported yesterday first-quarter increases of 83 percent in profits and 34.6 percent in sales. Both set records.
Steel production for the week ended April 17 rose slightly, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

TRENTON, April 19 Chief Justice Richard J. Hughes of the State Supreme Court agreed today with Governor Byrne's call for speedier trials, and then gave the Governor the bill $18 million.

ANAHEIM, Calif., April 19 (AP) Bobby Bonds made his debut with California by drilling three singles and stealing a base tonight as the Angels erupted with a 13-hit attack and routed the Baltimore Orioles, 9-4 in a game marred by a beanball war.
"My wife had plastic surgery," said Henny Youngman. "They cut up her credit cards."

DALLAS, April 19 (AP) Nelson Bunker Hunt, son of the late billionaire H.L. Hunt, pleaded no contest today to a reduced charge in his wiretap coverup trial. All charges were dropped against Nelson's brother, W. Herbert Hunt.

Wagner College, which is stepping up its basketball program with 18 games against Division I opponents in National Collegiate Athletic Association play next season, has taken on a new coach to bring the Seahawks back to respectability.
City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin has asked the Corporation Counsel to bring suit to compel the state to permit him to audit sales-tax returns from city merchants.
Favorable economic news firmed prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-the-counter market yesterday in moderate trading.
The United Negro College Fund has acknowledged a $475,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

CLEVELAND, April 19 Negotiators for the United Rubber Workers and the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company met throughout the day today in an effort to head off a national rubber strike tomorrow night, but no new proposals were made by either side.

The latest contribution to the ongoing business effort to interest the American people in the free-enterprise system will be a series of five half-hour films underwritten by the Phillips Petroleum Company.

NEW DELHI, April 19 (AP) Slum dwellers fought with policemen today to prevent their forced resettlement and the razing of their shacks. As many as five policemen and seven slum dwellers were reported killed and dozens injured.
A special campers' fund has been established to replace $1,700 that six masked gunmen stole Sunday from a Brooklyn Boy Scout troop's fund-raising

For the third straight day, temperatures set a record for April in New York City and along the Eastern Seaboard yesterday. The peak for the day in New York City was 92 at 11:50 A.M., below Sunday's April record of 96, but still a record for the day. The National Weather Service predicted readings in the 80's for today.

DENVER Hop a subway downtown and ride to the foothills of the Rockies that's the vision of transportation planners here who are determined to sell the Federal Government this week on the need to fund a subway and rapid rail system for Denver.
If you want to reach 100 million people (65 million of them adults) with an ad in one day, try the Sunday comics.
As champagne corks popped and passengers cheered, the Staten Island Rapid Transit system returned to service yesterday for the first time since the line was shut down by a strike last Dec. ll.
The Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) yesterday raised their gasoline prices by 1 cent a gallon.

Marvin D. Cristenfeld, a Nassau County election commissioner and its former Democratic chairman, went on trial in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of extorting thousands of dollars in kickbacks from consulting engineers seeking county contracts.
SHORT HILLS, April 19 Max Rudolf today assumed the leadership of a movement to raise the prestige of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra.

Governor Carey said yesterday that city and state counsel had offered legal opinions that the current emergency ban on wage increases might not permit approval of the pending transit workers' agreement.
Next week Community Board 8 will consider a proposal to develop what even in today's depressed realestate market is one of the most valuable residential sites in the world.
In less than two weeks, Dave Kingman and Mike Schmidt have put baseball back into baseball. Never have so many fans owed so much to so few home runs.
MOSCOW, April 19 The sleek train from Moscow to Warsaw glided through the Russian countryside and eased to a stop at the town of Vyazma, 125 miles west of the Soviet capital.

The chief judge of a threejudge Federal panel expressed doubt yesterday about the constitutionality of a state law that would require Patrick J. Cunningham to waive immunity from prosecution or lose his job as Democratic state chairman and party leader in the Bronx.

BOSTON, April 19 (UPI) Ferguson Jenkins, who is being relied on heavily in Boston's quest for a second successive American League pennant, pitched a five-hitter today as the Red Sox scored a 2-0 victory over the Minnesota Twins in a Patriot's Day morning game.
ITHACA, N.Y., April 19 About 200 black students rampaged through Cornell's administration building today, breaking several windows in the financial aid office before leaving.
LONDON, April 19 (UPI) Liverpool defeated Manchester City, 3-0, today and moved within sight of winning the English League soccer championship for a record eighth time.
Denis Potvin said, "Whatever they got, we gave them," as he assessed yesterday the New York Islanders' Stanley Cup quarterfinal series with the Buffalo Sabres, which is tied at two games apiece.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The nation's economic recovery picked up speed in the first quarter after a modest pause in the final quarter of 1975, with a 7.5 percent "real" rise in the gross national product from January to March, the Commerce Department reported today.

The 95 children in the Queens Children's Shelter live there because they have no place else to go. Some were separated from their families by the courts because they had been beaten, neglected or abandoned, and some were voluntarily placed by their parents who could not take care of them. Others are orphans. All of the children are lonely and all need individual attention.

Jeanne Bolan, an actress and director, died Saturday of a heart ailment at the home of her mother, Lillian Bolan, in Chicago, where she was directing a musical comedy for the Chateau Louise Theater. Her age was 49. Miss Bolan was the wife of James B. McKenzie, a producer, and lived in Westport, Conn.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The Federal Election Commission, immobilized by Congressional failure to restore its powers, is deadlocked over selection of a new chairman to succeed Thomas B. Curtis of Missouri, who is required by law to step down.

DETROIT, April 19 The American Motors Corporation reported today net earnings of $1.2 million, or 4 cents a share, for the second quarter of its fiscal year, which ended March 31 in contrast to a net loss of $47.8 million a year ago.

BOSTON, April 19 (AP) Cannons went off at dawn in Concord and a Paul Revere look-alike rode from Boston for Lexington as Massachusetts celebrated Patriots' Day, commemorating the start of the Revolutionary War.

His home state of Utah is going to pay Terrel H. Bell $11,000 a year more than his salary as United States Commissioner of Education, Mr. Bell said yesterday in announcing his resignation, effective Aug. 1. He has served less than two years in the $37,800 post in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.

BOSTON, April 19 At the start of the race, Jack Fultz was just one of 1,898 numbered runners, just another face in the crowd sweltering in the 93-degree heat. The people gathered in the Hopkinton Green were busy pointing out the favorites: Jack Foster of New Zealand, Mario Cuevas of Mexico, Jose DeJesus of Puerto Rico. Nobody pointed out Fultz. Nobody seemed to know him.

Teamwork is one of the purest forms of romance. In an age marked by egocentrism and interpersonal distrust, teamwork is one of the few surviving rituals of togetherness. The idea of a team is rich in associations; it suggests primitive kinship systems, knighthood, the guilds of the middle ages, the instinct of workmanship, the selflessness of patriotism. When the New York Knicks were at their best, their work resembled courtly love.

Vincent J. Porcaro, who retired Jan. 1 as assistant foreman of The New York Times press room, where he had worked since 1925, died Saturday at his home, 102 Kenwood Road, Garden City, L.I. He was 80 years old.
The stock market, responding to an encouraging Government report on business activity in the opening quarter of 1976, posted a modest gain yesterday.

NEW DELHI, April 19 (AP) Ambassador William B. Saxbe said today that relations between India and the United States were beginning to thaw, and that President Ford planned to include $60 million in development assistance to India in his new budget.

Negotiations for a new wage agreement in the Big Four rubber companies are heading toward a midnight deadline, with little hope for a strike-free settlement. Harry Huntt Ransom, chancellor emeritus of the University of Texas and a key figure in establishing its Humanities Research Center, died yesterday of a heart attack while visiting his wife's parents in Dripping Springs, Tex. He was 67 years old and lived in Austin.

The question of whether there is life after death, long the province of theologians, psychics and ordinary speculators, has recently become a subject of investigation among members of the scientific community.

PHILADELPHIA, April 19 When local Democrats gather here tomorrow night for their annual fund-raising banquet, they will witness one of the year's unusual political events. Senator Henry M. Jackson and Mayor Frank L. Rizzo will appear together in public.

WASHINGTON, April 19 A multibillion-dollar decision by the Administration on whether to build up to a 600-ship Navy may depend in part upon the outcome of the Republican Presidential primary in Texas on May 1, Pentagon officials said today.
Jules Tilles, a leading contract bridge player and administrator, died Sunday in Lebanon Hospital after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 19 Yields were mixed on Treasury bills auctioned today in both the 91-day and 180-day maturities.

The European bridge scene in the 1930's was dominated by teams from Austria, and it is a matter for regret that the best Austrian team never met the Four Aces, who were equally dominant on this side of the Atlantic.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The Department of Health, Education and Welfare, has issued a memorandum to its civil rights enforcers that clarifies its policy on bilingual education, and states as did the Supreme Court decision on which the policy is based that bilingual education is not required for non-English speaking students.

The chief judge of a threejudge Federal panel expressed doubt yesterday about the constitutionality of a state law that would require Patrick J. Cunningham to waive immunity from prosecution or lose his jobs as Democratic state chairman and party leader in the Bronx.
People from the community who have been sitting-in at Fordham Hospital since last Tuesday have been told to leave by noon today or face the possibility of being removed by the police.

Dr. Marian Anthon Bruen, a descendant of Robert Livingston and John Jay, was married yesterday afternoon to Dr. Charles Ainsworth Staveley Marrin, a greatgrandson of Admiral of the Fleet Sir Doveton Sturdee, who was victorious in the Battle of the Falkland Islands in 1914.

Perhaps it was the hot Easter Sunday evening, but the first of the Netherlands Chamber Orchestra's two Bach concerts at Carnegie Hall was lamentably underattended. One hopes the second, tomorrow night, will be better patronized, because the performances by and large were most attractive.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) The Supreme Court today agreed to hear as appeal brought by eight major chemical companies contending the Environmental Protection Agency exceeded its powers by establishing nationwide standards for discharge of pollutants into the nation's rivers and streams.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 19 (UPI) A reproduction of Columbus's flagship "Santa Maria" will sail here in July in a program designed to rebuild this city's historic waterfront, it was announced today.
Frederick Frye Rockwell of Orleans, Mass., author of 25 garden books and many magazine articles, died Sunday in Orleans Convalescent and Retirement Center. His age was 92.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 19 Three white South African motorcyclists were killed by black nationalist guerrillas today and the Government announced that a section of Rhodesia's only direct rail link to South Africa had been blown up.

The Public Service Commission ordered the New York Telephone Company yesterday to cut to $1 the monthly charge it makes for the use of its interconnecting devices for customer-owned answering and other auxiliary equipment and to drop its $30 charge for installing the devices.

WASHINGTON, April 19 (UPI) The Justice Department plans to create a neutral agency to take over the F.B.I.'s crime reports and statistical work to make sure that the figures are more credible and are put to better use.
BRUSSELS Pakhoed, a Rotterdam-based oil storage and transport concern, plans a major expansion of its current foothold in the United States, according to its managing director, Ger Verhagen.

The entering freshman class at City University will be 40 percent smaller next fall than it was last fall, with the greatest declines occurring in the senior colleges, admissions data from the university show.

WASHINGTON, April 19 The Energy Research and Development Administration said today that it would give "the highest priority" to conservation of energy, putting that on a par with development of new energy supplies.

As the earlier three concerts in this season's Eastman Series have demonstrated, the famous music school in Rochester boasts many superlative performers on its artist faculty. Sunday night a fine sonata team came to Alice Tully Hall for the first time: Francis Tursi, Eastman's professor of viola, and Barry Snyder ,who has been a pianist-teacher there since 1970.

WASHINGTON, April 19 Union pressmen and The Washington Star have reached a tentative agreement on a new contract. The agreement came, according to union sources, after management said that the paper would close if the unions did not accept layoffs and a wage freeze.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., April 19 Plans for a children's medical center capable of caring for 40,000 to 50,000 patients a year were announced today by the Long Island Jewish-Hillside Medical Center and the Children's Medical Center of New York Fund.

CANBERRA, Australia A remarkable rise in wages, which have already well surpassed those in the United States, is causing serious concern about the future of this comfortable country, whose economy has long been thought to have great potential because of Australia's bountiful natural resources.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday filed proposed rate changes in a highly competitive part of the telephone business voicegrade, interstate private-line service.

PEKING, April 19 (Reuters) Seven Soviet-bloc countries tonight boycotted a welcoming banquet here for Vice President Husni Mubarak of Egypt.
Capt. Johnny Harms, veteran charter boat skipper and big game angler of St. Thomas, the Virgin Islands, writes "let's put the sport back in sport fishing."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 19 (UPI) Firemen in Ohio's capital city began a sick-call strike today in a wage dispute, and 121 members of the 200-man first shift did not report for work.

"J.R" by William Gaddis took the fiction prize yesterday when the National Institute of Arts and Letters named the six winners of the 27th annual National Book Awards. It was the first time that the awards were administered by the institute.

HAVANA, April 19 (Reuters) Prime Minister Fidel Castro threatened tonight to call off the antihijacking agreement between the United States and Cuba if Cuban refugee groups based in the United States continued attacking Cuban fishing boats.

ALBANY, April 19 The General Electric Company filed with the state today an engineering report that indicates it may be able to lower to almost nothing its discharges of toxic polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) into the Hudson River, to comply with Federal orders that are to become effective July 1, 1977.

DENVER, April 19 (AP) Federal Bureau of Investigator agents shot and killed a gunman early today as he boarded an airline jet he thought was to fly him to Mexico, an F.B.I. spokesman said. The gunman had held two hostages on a private plane for seven hours.

Katherine Urquhart Warren, founder in 1945 of the Preservation Society of Newport County and its president until her resignation last year, died Sunday at Paulholme, her home in Newport, R.I. She was 79 years old.

ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, April 20 Rain delayed the start of last night's game between the New York Mets and St. Louis Cardinals, but both teams delayed the ending a lot longer, taking 4 hours 46 minutes to play 17 innings before the Mets broke the deadlock on Del Unser's home run to win, 4-3.

By proclamation of Governor Carey and Mayor Bcame, April 29 will be Duke Ellington Day. A memorial concert to benefit Cuttington College of Liberia, the only independent liberal arts college in sub-Saharan West Africa, will feature Ellington's old orchestra, conducted by Mercer Ellington, his son, at 7:30 P.M. that day at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Moving swiftly to put together his own team, Robert J. Wussler, who became president of the CBS television network eight days ago, yesterday appointed a new head of programs and a new head of sports. WASHINGTON, April 19 Lawyers representing many of the nation's news organizations urged the Supreme Court today to prohibit judges from imposing gag orders limiting press coverage of criminal cases on the ground that the orders violate the First Amendment's free press guarantee and are neither necessary nor effective in assuring fair trials.

Hermann Prey, that experienced opera singer and concert artist, sang a sturdy program of lieder last night in Carnegie Hall. He devoted his program to two composers, Schumann and Brahma. NORFOLK, Conn. In 1966, R. Allen Gardner's and Beatrice Gardner's infant chimpanzee said "more" in Ameslan, the American Sign Language for the deaf. MINOT, N.D., April 19 (UPI) The City of Minot appeared today to be winning its latest battle with the Souris River. The Souris, which has flooded in five of the last seven years, has fallen six inches from its crest yesterday, seven feet above flood stage. But the 13,000 residents who were evacuated from the city of 32,000 will not be able to return to their homes until next weekend.

WASHINGTON, April 21 Eight paintings by the Spanish painter Francisco de Goya, including the famous naked and clothed "Majas," will go on exhibition at the National Gallery of Art early next month, a loan from the Spanish Government to honor the United States Bicentennial.

BUFFALO, April 21 Shareholders at the annual meeting of Marine Midland Banks Inc. expressed concern here today that directors might omit the dividend when they meet in May.
WASHINGTON, April 21- The first flu shots were given today to begin the largest and most intensive immunization program ever attempted in the United States.

Eleven persons and two corporations have been indicted on charges of using fraudulent newspaper advertising to sell cars on which the odometers had been turned back to show they had low mileage, District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn announced yesterday.
A Criminal Court judge ruled yesterday that a police officer can arrest a nude dancer without a judge's warrant if he thinks the dancing is obscene.

Tomorrow Entertainment returns to television this evening with every encouraging indication that it will continue to deal in quality productions. Past credits have included "The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman."

A fire that has engulfed nearly 1,000 acres of prime forest in the Kittatinny Mountain range in Warren County seemed to be under control yesterday, although firefighters were hoping for a predicted rainfall to aid their extinguishing operations.

For those who follow pro football on television, the National Football League's schedule for the coming season could hardly be better. Unwilling to give the Yankees the shirts off their arms, the Chicago White Sox lodged one protest and extracted an $18 check from George Steinbrenner yesterday. Steinbrenner, however, received an apology from Paul Richards, the Chicago manager.

Sam Pope Brewer, a former correspondent for The New York Times in Europe and South America and a member of the newspaper's United Nations bureau until his retirement in 1972, died yesterday in Columbus Hospital after a heart attack. He lived at 201 East 21st Street and was 66 years old.
TEHERAN, Iran, April 21 Talks were resumed today between Iran and Western oil companies that have been seeking a revision of the 1973 agreement under which they buy most of Iran's oil.

William Cahn, the former Nassau County District Attorney who will be retried next month on Federal fraud charges is under Investigation for an alleged conspiracy involving falsified severance payments to 12 former aides.

The title of "Sir Harold" is in store for Harold Wilson, the former Prime Minister and Labor Party leader, Buckingham Palace announced yesterday. Queen Elizabeth II has named him a Knight Companion of the Most Noble Order of the Garter, one of Britain's highest order of chivalry. The title is nonhereditary.

ROME, April 22--Italian newspapers, citing United States Senate documents, asserted today that a former prime minister was involved in the scandal over bribes by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. The identity of the prime minister was not specified, however.

WASHINGTON, April 22--Maybe Hubert H. Humphrey can win the Democratic Presidential nomination by following his present strategy, but if so it is hard to see how he could unify the Democratic Party and go on to defeat President Ford--if he is the Republican nominee--in the fall campaign.

Emergency-room patients at Kings County Hospital now have to wait four to seven hours for treatment, members of the hospital's community board of directors said yesterday. The Park Department held a tree-planting ceremony yesterday in front of the building at 330 West 48th Street, where a concrete-cutting saw was presented to the department to help what the department called its first in-house treeplanting program. The saw was used to cut through the pavement.

Richard D. Abelson has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of the Maremont Corporation, a leading maker of automotive parts.

The festering troubles between Greece and Turkey are highly perilous for both countries, for stricken Cyprus and for the West's defense posture in the Mediterranean. Recognizing this fact, Greece's Prime Minister Caramanlis has now taken the initiative to ease the situation by proposing a nonaggression pact with Turkey, agreement to settle all differences through peaceful means, and an end to the arms race between the two countries.

In exchange for a promise ofno layoffs during the 1977 fiscal year, the union representing Park Department employees has agreed to a three-day work week for seasonal employees and to the use of volunteers to keep parks and beaches operating throughout the summer, city and union officials disclosed yesterday.

Complaints by air travelers about the abuses of freewheeling charter tour operators have mounted to the point that the consumer protection arm of the Civil Aeronautics Board petitioned the agency yesterday for tough new controls, including national licensing of tour organizers.
John A. Fiesler, who retired last July as executive director of the New York State Thruway Authority, died Wednesday in his home in Loudonville, N.Y., a suburb of Albany. His age was 70.

LOS ANGELES, April 22-- A controversial machine, said by its developers to extract cheap energy from water, has triggered an unusual scientific analysis by the Securities and Exchange Commission and has evoked the cautious patronage of Senator Barry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona.

The persistent disagreement between the Ford Administration and the Democratic-controlled Congress over legislation to provide public jobs for the unemployed and financial assistance for hard-pressed cities has broken out again. I am sitting on the 7:37 out of Tarrytown bound for New York City. The day is bright and dazzling, with sunlight danc ing on the Hudson beyond my window. My eyes dip periodically into the newspaper on my lap. They try to absorb some meaning but are unable to do so. Again and again my gaze turns back to the river, to the billion gold coins glittering on its surface.

Two one-act operas new to this city were somewhat less than enthusiastically received last night at the Juilliard American Opera Theater. Both works were composed by men of reputation. But the two composers represented a dated era of music, and the scores gave the impression of having more manner than substance. The best thing about the evening was the singing. Before a nine-tiered altar decorated with wine, fruit and dairy products, 50 Mongolians who live in the New York City area chanted songs and recited poems yesterday in memory of Genghis Khan, the Mongol conqueror who created a vast Asian empire in the 13th century.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Senator Henry M. Jackson, Representative Morris K. Udall and their political allies today attacked Jimmy Carter, their rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, as being unsympathetic to organized labor and blacks.

LISBON, Monday, April 26 The Portuguese Socialist Party led this morning in returns from the nation's first free parliamentary elections in half a century, but centrist and conservative parties made stronger showings than had been expected.

The projected 40 percent drop in the number of freshmen who will enter the City University's senior colleges in September is more than a matter of academic statistics. Together with the Lesser, but still substantial, decline in the anticipated admissions to the community colleges, this drastic shrinkage represents the end of a dream.

HONG KONG, April 25 North Vietnam's leaders did not expect their offensive last year to achieve complete victory and were surprised by the speed of Saigon's collapse, according to a lengthy new account by Hanoi's Chief of Staff of the war's final battles.

Despite a light, steady rain, some 20,000 New Yorkers most of them teen-agers spent the day yesterday walking along a 20-mile route Between Central Park and the Battery to raise money for the March of Dimes fight against birth defects.
MIAMI, April 25 Alfredo Duran, a 39-year-old Cubanborn Miami lawyer who fought in the Bay of Pigs invasion 15 years ago, was elected state Democratic chairman yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Safe in their Philadelphia Spectrum out of the domain of Ontario's attorney general, the Philadelphia Flyers attended strictly to hockey tonight and routed the Toronto Maple Leafs, 7-3. The convincing victory, with the Flyers scoring five goals in the second period, advanced the defending Stanley Cup

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) Two committee chairmen said today that Congress would conduct its own investigation of the Scotia coat mine explosions that killed 26 men, even though the Department of the Interior is already investigating the disaster.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 Senator Henry M. Jackson, appearing before Jewish audiences in the Philadelphia suburbs, stepped up his attack today on Vice President Rockefeller. At one point he suggested that Mr. Rockefeller's position on the emigration of Russian Jews might be related to Rockefeller connections with Arabian oil.

MOSCOW, April 25 The Kremlin, which is thought to be carefully watching Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's trip to Africa for a cue to its own future policy on the continent, has painted a gloomy picture of his prospects for success.

TRENTON, April 25 A challenge by two state Assemblymen of the New Jersey Supreme Court's order to the Legislature to give $378 million additional to public schools will be argued in Superior Court in Jersey City this week.

WASHINGTON, April 25 On Sixth Street, near the Capi tol, there are two chunky, 14foot-high statues suggestive of the socialist realist school. They represent the violent efforts of a shirtless man, with bulging muscles, to rein in an untamed horse.

The Very Rev. Hays Hamilton Rockwell, dean of Bexley Hall, the Episcopal member of a cluster of seminaries in Rochester, will become rector of St. James' Episcopal Church at 71st Street and Madison Avenue in New York City.

BOSTON, April 25 Mr. Kissinger's African tour is a sign, at least, that the American Government may finally be taking Africa seriously. An optimist would hope for more: the beginning of a considered and rational African policy. But before that could happen, Washington would have to understand the consequences of its past folly in the area.
DENVER, April 25 (AP) Top-seeded Jimmy Connors, always the aggressor, vanquished Ross Case of Australia, 7-6, 6-2, and won the $65,000 World Championship Tennis circuit tournament today.
PRISTINA, Yugoslavia The surging growth rate of Yugoslavia's largest non-Slavic minority group the Albanians has led to growing fears of a new and dangerous source of friction in this country.
