Seventeen days after the Cincinnati Reds opened the National League baseball season Don Gullett finally made his first start of the season yesterday. The ace of the Red's staff pitched six scoreless innings, giving up only five hits, as Cincinnati topped the Expos, 7-0, In Montreal.

Ever since "A Chorus Line" opened, it has been impossible to look at the boys and girls who sing and dance in musical comedies in the same old way rating them on the brilliance of their smiles, their agility, their faces and forms. Nowadays the sensitive spectator looks for signs of emotional trauma beneath the grease paint.
TRENTON, April 25 (UPI) Governor Byrne urged the Legislature this weekend not to approve a proposal to cut $1 million from the state's air pollution control program.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 The Swedish film director Ingmar Bergman, beset by tax problems, arrived here today and announced that he would meet with Dino De Laurentiis tomorrow to discuss new films.
Three Manhattan Legislators urged the Board of Estimate yesterday to negotiate a better deal for the city on a tax-abatement plan now pending for the renovation of the Commodore Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (AP) The Samuel Melville-Jonathan Jackson Unit, which said it was responsible for the Boston courthouse bombing that injured 22 people last Thursday, is part of the terrorist New World Liberation Front, so its threats should not be taken lightly, a man who acts as a messenger for the front said today.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., April 25 (UPI) King Carl XVI Gustav of Sweden arrived here today after a brief stop at Bradford, Pa., where his plane was forced to land because of bad weather.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 25 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with the heads of state of both Kenya and Tanzania on the first full day of his tour of Africa.

Two days before the big game, Bob Cahill, ticket manager at Notre Dame, had a call from a doctor who was an alumnus. "You won't believe this," the caller said, "but my kids made a bonfire of my two tickets on the kitchen floor. I've got the ashes."

The Rev. David Sanford Duncombe, administrator of St. Michael's Episcopal Mission to the Northern Arapahoe Indian Tribe and vicar of the church in Ethete, Wyo., was stabbed to death early Saturday on the Wind River Indian Reservation in Wyoming.

DERBY, Conn., April 25 Yale's heavyweight crew continued its resurgence in eastern rowing today by sweeping all five races against Navy and Trinity College in the rain on the Housantonic River. The weather could not dampen the spirits of the spectators, most of whom were parents of Yale oarsmen.

WASHINGTON, April 25 One of the nation's leading exports on the lethal dangers of radiation says that the managers of an Oklahoma plutonium factory appear to have shown "little concern" about the longterm cancer risks of plutonium.
CAMERON, La., April 25 (AP) Part of a helicopter that crashed into the sea near here last week, killng 12 offshore oil workers, was recovered today by divers and a salvage boat.
Maralin Niska did a full evening's work Saturday night with the New York City Opera when she sang the leading soprano roles in both "Pagliacci" and "Cavalleria Rusticana."

TITUSVILLE, April 25 After schools close this spring, Bicentennial planners expect a sharp increase in visitors to the site of Washington's historic crossing of the Delaware 200 years ago. To handle weekend traffic, New Jersey plans to propose that the narrow bridge at the site be closed to cars and trucks.

BRIDGEWATER, Conn., April 24 It was like a Greek statue suddenly taking life; the horse bursting from the barn, neck arched, nostrils flaring, veins standing out beneath the satin coat.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 (UPI) Danny Ozark, manager of the Philadelphia Phillies, had to be physically restrained from throwing a punch at a sports writer today following the team's 3-2 loss to the Atlanta Braves. The club's vice president, Bill Giles, apologized on behalf of the Phillies when the writers protested the incident, which included Ozark ordering all the writers from the dressing room.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 Lebanan's barely visible presidential election campaign shifted into second gear today following President Suleiman Franjieh's decision yesterday to sign a constitutional amendment permitting Parliament to pick a new head of state.
UNIONDALE, L.I, April 25 Rich (House) Jones, the Nets' power forward, surveyed his team's happy dressing room after their playoff victory over San Antonio last night.
DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 25 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger met today with the heads of state of both Kenya and Tanzania on the first full day of his tour of Africa.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 25 The keyboard postures ranged from Vladimir Horowitz to Victor Borge and the nimble fingers beat a silent tattoo to the tobaccoauctioneer delivery of a reader.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I, April 25 The chairman of the Suffolk Legislature Finance Committee proposed today that all engineering contracts for future, sewer work be reviewed and approved by the County Legislature and that the Legislature monitor the spending and procedures of the controversial $700 million Southwest Sewer District project.

Festivities and dancing brought cheer to the balmy Mariana Islands last week but not to Americans concerned with the future of the United States position in the Western Pacific. The 14,000 residents of those farflung island outposts have received what they asked for, the covenant which leads them eventually into an illdefined commonwealth status under American sovereignty, flag and, not incidentally, social security.

Newspapers selling for 2 and 3 cents an issue and reporting on such topics of current interest as shipping accidents and the untimely death of a young sharpshooter were found yesterday in a lead box taken from the cornerstone of a Brooklyn church.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) Proposals to increase dramatically the mining of Federal phosphate deposits in southeastern Idaho would reduce air and water quality and cut down the area's recreation resources, according to a draft environmental impact statement released today.
MIAMI, April 24 A doctor who treated Howard R. Hughes in his last months says that "a forum" is needed to clarify why Mr. Hughes died of untreated kidney failure.

More than a million acres of forest in central and southern New Jersey were to remain closed today as showers that fell yesterday in many parts of the state proved too light to douse a number of blazes burning stubbornly in a parched 3,500-acre area.

PARIS, April 25-Declaring that the choice for France lies between reform and upheaval, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing is pressing ahead with plans to increase worker rights in industry and to spread the tax burden more equitably, despite skepticism and even open hostility expressed by the political left and right.
BLOOMFIELD, April 24 Residents here began observing Earth Week today by hearing lectures, viewing environmental exhibits and learning about home care and gardening from volunteers.

LISBON, April 25 The parties on either side of Portugal's political spectrum steered clear of each other's strongholds today as Portuguese elected a Parliament. They didn't even bother to send poll watchers to preserves on the opposite side.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) The Chinese are "emphatically not interested" in formal defense agreements with the United States or in purchasing United States arms, a Congressional delegation reported today on its return from a seven-day visit to China.

WASHINGTON, April 25 Some members of Congress, accustomed to hearing complaints about the economy and energy from their constituents, have encountered a strong anti-Government sentiment in visits with the voters back home during the Congressional Easter recess.
IPOH, Malaysia, April 25 (Reuters) Communist guerrillas today blew up a stretch of Malaysia's main northern rail line in the state of Perak, the police said.

David B. Friedland, a member of the City Council from the Washington Heights-Inwood district of northern Manhattan since 1965, died Saturday in a nursing home in Westwood, N.J. He was 73 years old and lived at 615 West 172d Street.

LONDON, April 25 (Reuters) Princess Anne of Britain, looking pale and slightly unsteady, was discharged tonight from a London hospital where she had spent four days recovering from a horse-riding accident.

DUBLIN, April 25-Thousands of Irish Republican Army supporters defied the Dublin Government today and marched through the city to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the 1916 Easter uprising.

PHILADELPHIA, April 25 The three active Democratic candidates in the crucial Pennsylvania primary, taken together, will spend less than half the limit the new campaign law imposes on a single candidate running in the state.

Ronald Reagan's challenge to President Ford for the Repubican Presidential nomination was bolstered during the weekend as the process of selecting delegates to the Republican and Democratic national conventions advanced in six states and the Virgin Islands.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the nation's ninth largest steel maker, took the lead yesterday in announcing a long-expected increase in prices for flat-rolled steel. The increase of almost 8 percent on some products, which is effective June 1, is part of a general movement of higher metals prices that has gathered force in the last few weeks.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 26 For the nine horses now considered likely starters, the ordeal of a Kentucky Derby won't have to be faced until next Saturday. For their trainers, it began today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The report of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities, part of which was released today, is the result of the most intensive investigation ever conducted into America's foreign and domestic intelligence system.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Federal Election Commission, barred by court order from providing subsidies for primary elections, has also lost a less publicized but important power the pursuit of complaints of illegal campaign activities.

Speculators flocked to buy copper futures yesterday much to the surprise of some leading metals analysts, who said they were bewildered by the sudden interest. Buying involved 7,869 contracts on the Commodity Exchange in New York.
Winning, and losing, by a nose is a not uncommon event at the Belmont race track, but until this weekend no horse has been involved in four such finishes within three days.

Mickey Lolich reached two milestones yesterday as the Mets defeated the Atlanta Braves, 3-1. He needed 463 starts and 3,386 innings to reach the first and only four starts and 23 innings to achieve the second. Yet the second had to be more meaningful.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP) Federal computers that issue checks and make decisions automatically are wasting millions of dollars each year because of mistakes programmed into their systems, Congressional auditors said today.

The "Boulder Boys," the Navy's World War II intelligence organization in the Pacific, have been reunited for the first time in over 30 years. Swapping stories in Washington over drinks and hors d'oeuvres were 220 of some 2,000 graduates of a naval intelligence Japaneselanguage program, established less than a year before the attack on Pearl Harbor, at the University of Colorado in Boulder, Colo.

WASHINGTON, April 26 The Central Intelligence Agency plans to continue to employ as agents more than 25 journalists or other representatives of American news organizations, according to the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence Activities.

A tax-abatement plan to make possible the reconstruction of the Commodore Hotel into a hotel run by the Hyatt chain will come before the Board of Estimate today. LUSAKA, Zambia, April 26 Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger's assurance of United States' support for the concept of majority rule in Southern Africa was welcomed with slightly qualified enthusiasm today by President Julius K. Nyerere of Tanzania.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 26 (UPI) Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr, said today that he would leave California this week for the first time since he took office and would campaign for the Maryland primary wednesday.
Giorgio Chinaglia, a 29year-old Italian soccer star, arrived from Rome yesterday and was met by Clive Toye, the president of the New York Cosmos of the North American Soccer League.
Stock prices recovered somewhat from a weak opening yesterday and the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 2.05 points to close at 1,002.76.
CHICAGO, April 26 The National League again refused to expand today. It voted down a proposal to add Washington and Toronto and increase the league to 14 teams.

LAS PALMAS, Canary Islands, April 25 Efim Geller came from behind in the last round to win the fifth Las Palmas International Tournament here in the Santa Cata- lina Hotel with a score of 10 -4 . HACKENSACK, April 26 A new Bergen County program for combating child abuse and neglect at the family level was announced jointly today by the State Department of Institutions and Agencies and the County Board of Chosen Freeholders.

DETROIT, April 26 (UPI) Howard Porter sank two free throws with seven seconds to play tonight to seal the Detroit Pistons' 106-102 victory over the Golden State Warriors. The Pistons' victory tied the National Basketball Association playoff series with the defending champions at two games apiece.
Jim Miller bought $2,814 worth of fat the other day.

ALBANY, April 26 The State Legislature will return from its Easter-Passover recess tomorrow to face the prospect of its fragile unity, forged by the state's budget crisis and badly strained by the centrifugal forces of partisanship and regional self-interest.

OTTAWA, April 26 (Reuters) The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has almost reached agreement with a consortium of banks for a $300 million loan to finance the early stages of Canada's purchase of 18 Orion patrol planes, Defense Minister James Richardson said today.

Bill D. Moyers, the former press secretary to President Johnson who in recent years has been a principal journalist for the Public Broadcasting Service, has been hired by CBS News as a correspondent for the monthly documentaries "CBS Reports."

Jerome Robbins, the choreographer and stage director, received this year's Capezio Award in dance yesterday. Edward Villella and Patricia McBride, principal dancers of the New York Ballet, where Mr. Robbins is a balletmaster, made the presentation at the Pierre Hotel before many members of the dance world.

Kurt Tucholsky is, at least to American audiences, largely an unknown figure. A German satirist and journalist, he wrote songs and sketches for Berlin cabarets in the 1920's and early 30's, Persecuted because he was Jewish, he fled the country, and, in 1935, killed himself. But, as the program for "Tickles by Tucholsky," the revue that opened last night at Theater Four, indicates, "he has achieved a posthumous fame throughout Europe."

CLEVELAND, April 26 (AP) Negotiators faced a new issue today as they returned to the bargaining table for another attempt to end the six-day-old strike by the United Rubber Workers against the industry's four biggest companies.

David Craighead presented a varied program of organ works Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall, but its sum did not equal the parts. The program included, from the 17th century, Samuel Scheidt's pleasant variations on "Warum betrithst du dich, mein Hertz," from the 18th, the Bach Sonata No. 4 in E minor and the Mozart Fantasy (K. 608), and four works from the 20th century.

TRENTON, April 26 Governor Byrne issued today a proclamation reopening as of noon tomorrow the state's forests and woodlands of South and Central Jersey, which had been closed to the public since Saturday because of forest fires.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 Patricia Hearst, gaining weight and much recovered from a deflated lung, was moved from her Redwood City hospital room today to a Federal prison at Pleasanton, Calif.
A New York State appellate court ruled yesterday that the city must pay policemen $19.5 million in wage increases that had been postponed until at least 1978 because of the city's fiscal crisis.

HARTFORD, April 26 With Democratic caucuses looming in all 169 towns in Connecticut tomorrow night, party workers around the state were working today to complete the slates of delegates committed to the six candidates left in the stae's Presidenial voing on May 11.

Contracts for future construction rose 42 percent to $8.9 billion in March, the F.W Dodge division of the McGraw Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) The United States does not believe that Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's formula for bringing blacks into his Government meets its conception of representative government for Rhodesia, a State Department spokesman said today.

MONTREAL, April 29 The Montreal Canadiens hung on and beat the New York Islanders, 4-3, tonight, chiefly on the goaltending of Ken Dryden, who faced 41 shots in a contest that was hardly the tight, defensive game Montreal cultivated during the regular season.

DETROIT, April 29 The Ford Motor Company joined General Motors and Chrysler today in the rebound to high car sales and profits, reporting net income of $343 million, or $3.65 a share, for the first quarter of 1976. This contrasts with a loss of $11 million, or 11 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1975, when the whole industry was in the severest downturn since the Depression.
WASHINGTON, April 29 The Smithsonian Institution, having looked a gift horse in the mouth, has reluctantly decided that inflation has transformed it into a white elephant.

General James Van Fleet (Ret.), a former Army fullback, was named yesterday to receive the Distinguished American Award for 1976 from the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame. He will be honored at the foundation's awards dinner in New York next Dec. 7.

HOUSTON, April 29 The Panama Canal is playing an increasingly prominent role in the Texas Presidential primary election, largely because of Ronald Reagan's "give-away" charges against the Ford Administration.
NEW HAVEN, April 29 Connecticut's statewide network of offtrack betting parlors opened this morning amid hopes that it will help ease the state's fiscal plight and stave off the need for new taxes.

Julius Rudel, moving into his 20th season as director of the New York City Opera, announced yesterday seven new productions for 1976-77 that range from Poulenc and Mozart to Gilbert and Sullivan and Saul Bellow.

Once he has seriously imagined himself as the occupant of the most powerful job in the world, no man is ever quite the same again. Defeat redoubles desire. Hope crushed to earth inevitably rises again and lurks forever in the recesses of the mind.

Thus put on guard against condescension by the 89-year-old master himself, a listener goes to these records in an especially demanding frame of mind. But it's no use.

LLOYD HARBOR, L.I., April 29 Federal agents and Suffolk County Police detectives sought clues and witnesses today in what the police called a "bizarre" abduction of a motorcycle dealer from his home in this affluent North Shore community before dawn yesterday.

Earliest of the primroses are the P. juliae. The bright purple, deep red, claret, or sometimes white flowers of this diminutive species and its many hybrids often break right through the crust of late March snow. Used to the alpine climate of their original Transcaucasian homeland, the flowers remain unaffected by the snow except esthetically, the white crystal blanket draping like ermine around them.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia "Be Arabia what it may, it is ours," the Emir Faisal ibn Turki, great-grandfather and predecessor of King Khalid of Saudi Arabia, said III years ago to a hardy British colonel who had turned up here in the isolated Saudi capital in the heart of the Arabian Peninsula.

NEOPRIMITIVE art-rock, with those determined twanging variants on the same three chords, should by rights be indistinguishable, and, in truth, a lot of it does sound alike. EVA'S MAN, By Gayl Jones, 177 pages, Random House, $6.95. "Eva's Man" may be one of the most unpleasant novels of the season. It is also one of the most accomplished.

Robert Ludlum cooks up generously portioned thrillers, combining the fast hands of a good short-order cook with the flair of a chef at Chicago's late lamented Pump Room. The flaming skewers, rich sauces, spectacular cuts of beef, sinful desserts they're all working in his kitchen. As a writer, Mr. Ludlum may not be Escoffier, but neither is Ronald MacDonald.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Deputy Defense Secretary William P. Clements Jr. said today that some private shipbuilders were refusing to construct naval ships unless there was an "equitable adjustment" of their claims against the Navy for past contracts.

WASHINGTON, April 29 Hubert Humphrey hesitated briefly at the end, when his wife Muriel and three of their four children changed their minds and urged him to challenge Jimmy Carter for the Democratic Presidential nomination, but his doubts didn't last for long.
TOKYO, Friday, April 30 (AP) The Pyongyang radio, monitored here said today that North Korea had named Deputy Prime Minister Pak Sung Chul its new Prime Minister, succeeding Kim Il.

TRENTON, April 29 With State Treasury officials predicting an increase in revenues from sales and corporate taxes, the chairman of the Joint Legislative Appropriations Committee said to day that he hoped to add about $150 million to Governor Byrnes's $2.76 billion budget for the coming fiscal year.

Aides to President Ford and Vice President Rockefeller are among several black Republicans who have condemned the black-led effort promoting Senator Edward W. Brooke of Massachusetts as the Republican nominee for Vice President.

MANILA, the Philippines, April 29 (AP) In a 100page pamphlet distributed through the Roman Catholic Church in the Philippines, the Association of Major Religious Superiors has accused the Government of torturing and killing political detainees.

Two New York City journalists were named by Columbia University yesterday as the winners of the 16th annual Mike Berger Award. They are Israel Shenker, a reporter for The New York Times, and Howard Blum, a staff writer for The Village Voice.

WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP) Amtrak operations over the next five years will require a Federal subsidy of at least $6.2 billion, the General Accounting Office said today.
The stock market closed yesterday with a slight gain in continued light turnover. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrial stocks ended at 1,002,13, up 1.42.

PARIS May Day has been widely observed since pre-Christian times, starting as a pagan celebration of spring sowing and eventually gaining acceptance simply as an occasion of happiness and dancing around bedecked May poles. Only in 1889 was it internationally designated by a Socialist congress as an occasion to honor labor.
LUBBOCK, Tex., April 30 President Ford completed his Texas primary campaign today after charging that Ronald Reagan's "credibility is severely at stake" in the debate over national security policy.
Jimmy Young started boxin when he was 14 years old because he had to lose weight.

The second annual monthlong New York City Theater Festival, co-sponsored by the Department of Cultural Affairs and the Andora Hodgin Total Theater Inc., gets under way today.

Johan Willem Beyen, former Foreign Minister of the Netherlands and an architect of European unity after World War II, died Thursday evening in The Hague after a brief illness. He was 78 years old and had been living in the south of France since his retirement a few years ago.

When the Brooklyn Academy of Music presented its first experimental-dance series last year, the joint concert by the choreographerdancer Laura Dean and the composer Steve Reich was easily the most spectacular program.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 30 A purported will of Howard R. Hughes was offered for probate here tonight amid speculation that a protracted court fight would ensue over its authenticity.

PASSAIC, April 30 Porky Zaentz and Beansie Lieberman came home today, and Mayor Gerald Goldman, members of the City Council and 200 others gathered on the steps of City Hall to honor the two local boys who had made good.

One of the country's most exclusive organizations, the Colonial Dames of America, held its annual luncheon meeting here yesterday, and this time it was more than just another catered luncheon of cold fried chicken and ratatouille.

TOKYO, April 30 (Reuters) Japan today named Shizuo Saito, a former representative at the United Nations, as a special envoy to the United States to seek further cooperation in the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation payments case.

Nearly 40 elected officials and a tenants' group denounced yesterday suggestions that rent control be removed from apartments in New York City that rent for $300 or more a month. Real estate groups are pressing for such a move, but the officials and the tenant organization held that it would hurt "the very group" of rental families that the city "needs the most for a stable population and a solid tax base."

The new Council on the Economy, whose chairman is Governor Carey and whose cochairman is Mayor Beame, decided yesterday to seek immediate repeal of the city's estate tax and an easing of the stocktransfer tax burden on brokers and dealers as the first steps in a program to dramatically improve the business climate of the state and the city.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y. April 29 Tom Jones, the Welsh pop singer now securely embarked into his second decade of show business, began a long American tour at the Westchester Premier Theater here tonight.

WARSAW, April 30 (Reuters) Poland has merged groups in the army, in rural communities and in work places to form a 2,000,000-strong, centralized youth organization better adapted to implement Communist programs.

Reggie Jackson, who held out for four weeks while asking his new team, Baltimore, for a higher salary, agreed to join the Orioles last night.

MOSCOW--For all its ambitions elsewhere in the world, the Soviet Union has always seen its first interests in Europe. The priority is rooted in more than an historical fear of invasion from the West, as was realized twice in this century. It also reflects an envy of Western technology and culture, coupled with the desire to win Europe's acceptance as an equal.
